I probably wouldn't do it again for take out because it's kind of pricey for that, but would definitely go for a night out if I wanted to go out for a couple drinks and have some good food!
author: Annette E.

description: If you know of a better burger in San Francisco, please let me know. I've yet to find it and I've had plenty. The burgers here are outstanding!! The mac 'n cheese, flash-fried calamari with spicy thai dipping sauce, and fried chicken (on Sunday nights) are also great. And the food ALWAYS comes out piping hot! That's a major plus in my book. Wash it all down with one of their signature cocktails and you'll be good to go. The Moscow Mule with house made ginger syrup and the Manhattan are both excellent. If you're looking for a casual spot with a friendly vibe and good ole fashioned comfort food, look no further.
author: Rich M.

description: The food was okay, nothing particularly special. I wasn't a fan of the appetizers or even my burger, but the ravioli was pretty good. Would recommend if you lived in the area but probably not worth a trip otherwise.
author: Michael M.

description:
This restaurant is exemplified by what they hand make everyday: sausages, pasta, infused vodka, and every dessert they serve (these are just the examples from our groups order). A couple thoughts on our experience

-They don't take reservations, and the seating area is small. We arrived at six when food service began and got right in, but the place filled up fast
-Definitely have a cocktail or two(or three, no judgement), the drink menu is a mix of classic and modern drinks. The sparkle barbie (complete with a colored sugar rim made to look like sparkles) and the yellowtail were among our group favorites
-the dinner menu changes a bit nightly. I had the burger and my wife had the tagliatelle bolognese, the burger was perfectly cooked,  juicy and full of flavor. The handmade tagliatelle was perfectly al dente nestled in a tasty bolognese sauce
-Service was slow, but in a good way. The waitress was attentive and we felt comfortable.
-the desserts were perfect. The desserts earned this place their 5 rating. All made in house and all equally delicious. We tried the bread pudding, Meyer lemon cheese cake, and hand made peanut butter ice cream. Devoured within seconds.

This place is a must if you are in the Russian Hill area
author: Erik C.

description:
Neighborhood friendly restaurant. Perfect first, second and even third date spot :) hehe just a perfect date spot. Comfy, cozy and great food, what else can you ask for!? oh ya and the service is great, they are friendly and will make you feel at home!
Def try the fried chicken dish...so ggggoooood!!
author: Kajal P.

description: I have to say, the Fried Chicken at Street is the best I've EVER had. Not only is the Chicken moist & crispy, the set up is really over the top. Sautéed corn off the cob under homemade cornbread, along with mashed potatoes with delicious gravy. Sunday's are my favorite day of the week!
author: Rachel C.

description:
I think the desserts that you grow up with, can have a huge impact on all of your future dessert decisions and obsessions.

As a kid, I was addicted to my grandmother's rice pudding. It was perfect. Baked thick rice swimming in fresh hot cream sauce - with thick amazingly sweet skin of slightly browned cream on the top.  

When we used to make the trip back to Wales to see our grandparents - it was the first thing I'd ask my grandmother about on the phone. I was obsessed with that stuff. Still haven't found anything quite as good.

That rice pudding - stirred on my fascination with comfort desserts like bread pudding (my mom makes a mean one. Mostly cause she doesn't really believe in recipes and like to improvise)

So when I read about the bread pudding here - I knew I had to try Street.

Street doesn't disappoint on all fronts. The food is well done. The food portions are great. The prices are reasonable, considering the presentation and quality of the food. The ambiance is edgy and sexy, but strangely - still warm and inviting.

I wasn't wowed over by my ahi fish dish - but my dining companion's egg noodle pasta dish with the ideal amount of cream sauce - was incredible and undeniably one of the best entree choices on the menu.

And looking around us - as plate, after plate of lightly browned fried chicken made their way to all of the tables around us - I suspect the fried chicken may even be the Ace of the place.

But to get to my favorite part of any meal and every review - dessert.

Three words for you:

do bread-pudding here. (let's consider bread pudding one word to make this sentence more more poignant)

Street's Def. of Bread Pudding: A beautifully formed and textured cake of soft sweetness - sitting pretty on top of a nutty toffee sauce, and dressed lightly with just whipped cream sauce.

Trying to find words to accurately capture it's borderline divine nature - is hard.

Check out Street. They don't take reservations, but if you're a small party you should be fine. Try their pasta or fried chicken, and go for the bread pudding. Maybe even come here just for a drink and some bread pudding.

Revisit a favorite childhood dessert done right. And then some.

Trust.
author: Jessica T.

description:
"Strong Food. Real Drinks."

Food was not powerful as I imagined. We had brussel sprouts, pate, truffle mac & cheese and fried calamari -- I rate all dishes average. Nothing outstanding.

The cocktails were mostly cheaper than the wine selection, so we had fig martini (which was like a dessert in a glass) and the apricot-infused vodka martini (which was not as delectable as the fig martini). 

The best part of dinner: house-made peanut butter ice-cream! We were both quiet after a taste. It is memorable. (And I'm not a dessert fan.)
author: Kit S.

description:
I want to give this place a good review, but I just can't. The food is okay. The burger is fantastic but everything thing else is so inconsistent. My problem is not with the restaurant's food, but mostly with the unsanitary way the food is prepared. 

Street has a fairly open kitchen. So you would think that you would be careful when preparing the food because people are watching. 

The last few times I have been in there I have sat at the bar and watched the owner/"chef" dipping tobacco and spitting all over the kitchen. He just happens to spit into a conveniently placed garbage can placed right next his work station where every plate of food that goes out is prepared. GROSSSSSSS

I used to love this place until I saw that. I will not be coming back. That is gross, unsanitary, and I can not believe that someone running a restaurant would think that is at all okay.
author: Kristen J.

description:
Street is a cozy little spot that offers both a neighborhood-y and chic vibe at the same time. It's tight up in there, but dark enough so that you don't feel like you're shoulder to shoulder with everyone else (even though you are). 

The menu offerings drift to the new American comfort food side of the street, with solid burger and fried chicken dishes alongside international comfort food faves like gnocchi with a house-made sausage. I opted for the house-made egg noodle dish in a light cream sauce with some sort of nuts and spinach. This came after a starter of a goat cheese custard with greens. Both dishes were fantastic, which was to be expected as they were recommendations of the server. The creamy noodles dish was light and complex, definitely creamy but not too rich. The spinach cut the richness nicely and added a solid green flavor to the dish. The goat cheese souffle was warm and delicious. 

Dinner was followed by an amazing pecan bread pudding with pecan sauce and a meyer lemon cheesecake. While the cheesecake was tasty, the bread pudding definitely stole the show. Imagine a delicious (and very consistent in texture) bread pudding mixed with a pecan pie. Delicious. 

Pair this good environment with tasty food and very reasonable prices (in the $10-$18 range), and you have a winner. Inconsistency amongst dishes (the ahi was only so-so) leaves me at 4-stars for now.
author: Don B.

description: Yet another stellar meal!  Tonight was the lamb salad. A new addition. Flavorful healthy greens and yummy lamb. If you were a vegetarian this would be perfectly fine without the lamb, but for me it was delightful!
author: Laurie P.

description:
"It tastes like a fucking unicorn jumped over a double rainbow, all your favorite musicians collaborate on a song just for you, while you bust a nut right over Scarlett Johansson's face." - Jason C.

More of his genius review: http://www.yelp.com/biz/street-san-francisco#hrid:yC7dEtNuAiN_Pm3cieBDBQ

If you decide to come here like I did after reading Jason's review on Street, then I hope you get Stephen as your waiter because he is AWESOME. He is very sweet and he took good care of us. I ordered the homemade bolognese pasta along with the chocolate cake with peanut butter ice cream, and I died - everything was so divine! I can't wait to come back and try each item on the menu.

Oh, and if you love red wine, then don't forget to order a glass of Justin Cabernet Sauvignon, Paso Robles 2008 - delicious!
author: Angellica Y.

description: Definitely one of my new favorite restaurants in SF! Great service, lovely ambiance, cute, cozy, & quiet. I came here with a party of 4 and we had a wonderful experience. The wine was great and the food was delicious! I recommend trying the mushroom risotto, so amazing. The Brussel sprouts are also a must!
author: Dori G.

description: I live a block and a half from this restaurant and for the past 8 years I've frequented Street at least once a month. The Sunday fried chicken is out of control. John the chef pretty much rocks with all the dishes he serves. The steak is outrageous, as is the hummus appetizer. Very fair prices. Nice staff. Highly recommend.
author: Dan F.

description:
I'm somewhat of a regular here, and I think most of the clientele are also regulars. The food is always good, albeit in no way is it healthy. The fried chicken is my favorite dish. I'm from the south, and this is definitely comfort food.  The bolognese and the ahi tuna are also favorites. I wouldn't say anything is great, but I've never been disappointed with an order.

The best part of the place is the inviting bar area. It's a relatively large bar with approximately 10 stools.  Whether I'm meeting a friend or grabbing food alone, I'm sure to have friendly service and good conversation. It's the kind of place where you'll always meet someone from the neighborhood.
author: Brad C.

description:
What a charming find!

DECOR/AMBIANCE: The inside kind of reminds me of a red light district...but I think that was their intention.  Dim lighting...I think this would be a great place for a date.  Small and cozy, a great place for good conversation and a glass of wine.

SERVICE: Our waitress was adorable...Seriously, I've never had such great service in an American restaurant.  She waited on us hand and foot, and even alerted us when the kitchen was closing.  She selected a great bottle of wine for us and made our dining experience all the more special.

CUISINE: They have an array of pastas, meats, seafood, etc.  I had the vegetable risotto (toothsome) and my friend had a seafood pasta dish.  

PRICE: The place is a bit pricey, maybe $20+ a plate, but the food is high-quality, and I think it's worth it!
author: Lauren C.

description: I just love this place, but am hardly ever in the city on Sundays when they serve their fried chicken!  My parents were on a trip last weekend and brought me home a to-go box with 4 pieces.  It was the best souvenir anyone could ever give me!  On my way to pick up carpool this afternoon, I grabbed the last piece and ate it on the way.  I got a few strange looks at the traffic lights, but they just DON'T understand.  Any night of the week you'll have a superb meal and a strong, classic cocktail, but Sunday dinner . . . ?  You just HAVE to go to Street for their fried chicken!
author: Hilary M.

description: Fantastic spot!  I can't believe I did not know about this place after living in SF for so long.  The food is fantastic and the service was very courteous.  The menu is printed daily when the chef arrives and everything is so delicious.  Great cocktails too.
author: Alex A.

description:
Really disappointed. 

The food was bland and the drinks were poorly made. The calemare looked like bad onion rings (you know the thin light tan batter). It needed something else: spice, garlic, lemon or cocktail sauce.  The pappardelle pasta didn't taste like anything but starch. The sea food pasta was all butter. It felt like we were paying double price at Olive Garden.

To drink we ordered a dark and stormy and I ordered a house cocktail with grapefruit juice, elderflower and tequilla. All I could taste was grapefruit--minute maid style. My date wasn't thrilled with his drink. 

 The only two good things were the service and the fact that we walked in at 5:30pm on a Friday night without a reservation. Our waitress was great: friendly and helpful. She just over sold the food.
author: Jacqueline S.

description:
The steak sandwich (sorry no pictures), basically goes like this: huge, happy chunks of medium rare steak, crispy edges around the soft chewy baguette, sans mayo, a delicate serving of organic greens and sweet caramelized onions. 

It tastes like a fucking unicorn jumped over a double rainbow, all your favorite musicians collaborate on a song just for you, while you bust a nut right over Scarlett Johansson's face. 

Eat it at least once - the same way you use internet explorer once just to download firefox or chrome.

Peace.
author: Jason C.

description:
The burger: Medium rare with fire roast onions, gruyere cheese with kennebec fries. Do this, and you can't go wrong. Street has built itself an impressive following of hip patrons, bringing out the louder version of Nob Hill. It's a local favorite, and considering the kitchen set up this is an even more impressive feat than captured on film.

TAKE AWAYS: 
- The gruyere cheese wasn't overwhelming the burger despite its thickness seeping into the patty, and the onions played a pivoting supporting actor in bring everything together. 
- Truth be told, this burger is my litmus test for all burgers I've eaten..and will eat. It's a good cut above the diner-esque burger, but not super fancy where we get caught up in its sourced, organic DNA.

Definitely a great scene grab of Nob Hill and the transitional state of Polk Street. My unique, ace burger.

See the rest of the Best SF Burgers list here: http://abelin.net/5-must-try-burgers-in-san-francisco-2012/
author: Abel L.

description:
The first time I went here with a large group, it was a decent experience. We had to wait for setting, but with no reservations, thats what we get. Food was cooked quickly and served quickly, waitstaff was courteous, everyone was happy.

Second time went there with just a few other people. We ordered the lamb, and were told incorrectly about how large the portion was. When I questioned the waitress on the lamb portion, she told me it was two pieces. It was obvious one, cut into two.  It took forever to get our bill we had questioned the waitress, I was literally screaming "excuse me" when she was walking by, and she was ignoring me.

We gave them a third chance tonite. It may be the last. The waitress and hostess were very courteous. First we ordered two wines and a cocktail. Got those within about 5m.

We then ordered two steak salads and a seafood pasta. For a restaraunt relatively dead, it took them 15 minutes to bring us the salads.  It then took another 10 minutes on top of that to bring the pasta dish.

The food quality is very good in my opinion. However, for the portion size you get, and the wait time you may experience (either for a seat or for your food), its not worth the price they ask.

If they reduced prices down 30%, it may be worth four stars and more more even get-what-you-pay for deal.
author: dutchy s.

description:
Right off the bat, who charges 5 dollars for a PBR? Is that an 800% markup? 

Anyways, aside from that sore thumb, there's a lot to like at Street. It's a smaller restaurant, but you can still get a group in if you come at the right time. I can't comment on the drinks, but the food (the fried chicken and the truffle mac n' cheese) was fantastic. We started with the mac n' cheese, which was on the creamy side and really hit the spot. Then it was on to the entrees: The fried chicken was well prepared and juicy, and the sides didn't disappoint: delicious mashed potatoes and gravy, hot cornbread and corn on the cob. Prepare to eat if you're ordering the fried chicken too, its a hefty plate of food. Servers were friendly and quick, and our food came out extremely quickly. All in all recommended for a dinner out on Polk
author: Taylor C.

description:
Do your best and get the steak EVERY TIME.

Dynamite with their fries, red wine... had it more than I care to admit.
author: Mandy S.

description: Great service, great food, great drinks what more can you ask for? Ordered calamari ,  grilled artichoke, crab cakes and they were all delish.  My friends said their bread pudding was great as well They do not take reservations so try coming earlier to get a table.  Ambiance is fun and vibrant , great place for dinner before hitting the bars.
author: Claudine V.

description:
Stop your search and just go to Street. 

It had been a rough week. We're gathered around on a late Friday night and we get are deciding where to eat in SF. I said "American" and we started the yelp search. My friend Samir said "How about steak?" both of our mouths started watering and Street was the lucky name of the night. 

We ordered our New York Strip steaks and told Dakota "As done as the chef wants" and when we bit into our medium rare steaks, our satisfaction was enough to send that delicious cow to heaven. And a potato because those french fries were great. 

A little dark, didn't feel like a bar but more like a bistro.  Just check it out, you'll like it.
author: Zahir A.

description:
Given the stellar reviews, I WANTED to love Street.  I really did.  I had heard, read and smelled great things about that restaurant.  Unfortunately, I found it to be 'par' at best.  ...Further, a 'par' restaurant is fine when it's under $10 a plate...not when it's $15-$25 (hence my grumpy 2-star rating).  

Quick and dirty:  My wife and I came here for some much needed reprieve from our newborn only to find the portions small, the prices a little high, and the food (and service) average.  I had the crab cakes.  You get two (yay!).  They were good but unremarkable.  My wife crushed some vegetable risotto...also good, but unremarkable.  

I don't want this review to be completely negative, however, as we enjoyed the cocktails and ambiance.  

My advice would be to get the burger.  I didn't get the burger but immediately regretted my decision upon seeing the table next to me receive said burgers.  Fortune (and Street) favors the bold burger eaters, not the lame a**es getting crab cakes and risotto.
author: Kaare W.

description:
I've been living in the Nob Hill/Russian Hill area for a year and a half now and for some reason had no idea Street even existed until last night. 

I know, I know, admitting this may lead to my elite status being revoked, but if I learned anything in grad school it was admit ignorance. 

My friend Mike K. SWEARS by their burgers so while out celebrating a mutual friends birthday we decided to stop for some post happy hour fare. Everyone was getting burgers no questions asked, but as soon as I saw the words "PORK BELLY" on the menu I couldn't look back, there would be no burger on my plate. I was incredibly happy with my decision. The flavors worked incredibly well together, and by missing out on the burger I have an excuse to come back asap. 

Our server, the ever famous Amy, was incredible. She's fun, sarcastic, attentive, and well, just makes you want to be BFFs. I told her it was our friend Max's birthday and before she brought out the check she "sang" happy birthday and handed him a tequilla shot followed by an incredible chocolate desert complete with a candle. Max begged to know who told her to do that, and we didn't dare take credit, it was all her. 

PHENOMENAL. That is truly the only way to describe that kind of service. And the price is right, I'd pay just to sit there and hang out with the staff.

P.S. For those of you counting, yes I used the word incredible way to many times... next review I will bust out the thesaurus. Promise.
author: Hailey P.

description:
I didn't love this place. But I didn't hate it either. I guess my main problem was that there was nothing super memorable about Street to keep me coming back for more. Out of everything I tried on the menu, their Dark and Stormy was by far the best. The server recommended this drink to me and he was right on. I also tried the Apripolitan which was tasty too, but nothing like the Dark and Stormy. 

These are the food items that I tried off of the menu:

Spicy hummus: Tasty, flavorful, and satisfying. But equivalent to what I've purchased at stores. No wow factor here -- just good tasting hummus.

Truffle Mac & Cheese: The crust on top of this really was the finishing touch. Perfect texture with a nice balance of crunchy and creamy. Yummm.

Summer Vegetable Risotto: Eh. It was fine. It was good. But it wasn't anything special. I've had a million different risottos (it feels like) and this just wasn't on the top of my list. Too expensive for what it is.

I don't know if I'd go back to street, but it definitely wasn't a waste of a good night. It was fine. But that's all it was. Fine.
author: Sara K.

description: Went here on a Sunday night because I heard rave reviews about their fried chicken, served only on Sundays. Unfortunately the meal didn't live up to my high expectations - relatively small pieces of semi-dry chicken...I've had better (that's what she said). My brother in law tried a pasta dish (it was obviously not that memorable because I don't even know what kind it was) and wasn't that impressed with it either. Not a great meal but definitely not the worst.
author: Tiffany F.

description:
I don't understand how this restaurant has 4 stars.
It's just a plain restaurant with below average food.
The food actually tasted as though it could have been microwaved out of a frozen box.  Nothing special here at all.
Bland/boring food - not worth the $80 spent on it at all
Service was fast - almost too fast
Drinks were ok - very strong but nothing special here either.
There is no ambiance or personality.
Very very forgettable.  :(
author: KJ G.

description: Friendly service and really really good food. I'm convinced the Street Burger is the best burger in town. We also love the Neighborhood vibe.
author: C K.

description:
I came here with my boyfriend when we wanted to try something new apart from our usual favorite places around his apartment.  After reading the great reviews on Yelp and then seeing that it was packed once we arrived, I was excited and optimistic about what Street had to offer. Unfortunately, it didn't exactly live up to its rep for me.  

We arrived, around 9pm on a Friday night, and there was no visible hostess desk, and nobody greeted us, so we just kind of wandered through the restaurant to the bar where some waitresses were standing.  Still, nobody approached us, and we had to ask ourselves how the seating worked.  After a few minutes of waiting by the kitchen, we were seated, but not before overhearing the cooks say there was one pork loin left (which is the reason I chose the restaurant!). 

Once we were seated, our waiter came over, without introducing himself, and quickly took our order. And when I say quickly, I'm talking lightning speed.  There was no polite conversation or listing of specials or anything! Definitely the service thus far was not impressive- but I did get the pork loin!

The server came back after to get our drinks (we wanted to put in my order so I could get the last one) and I got some wine, and my boyfriend got a beer. My wine came out relatively quickly (though we still did not have water) and then the beer did not follow for at least 5 minutes, which was annoying. 

The only thing that saved this place was its food.The pork loin was amazing, and my boyfriend's burger was one of the best I've tasted in a while.  We didn't have dessert, but the couple next to us did, and that also looked out of this world.  This place might be better if you came on a night that wasn't so packed (weeknight?) but until the service gets better, I am going to stick with our other favorites in the neighborhood.
author: Julia P.

description:
We were looking for a place to eat in this part of Polk St and were able to get seated right away at Street. The food was really delicious. We started with a dish that I don't think is any longer on the menu, but they must bring it back. They were lobster corn dogs with a great sauce to go with. We only ordered these because they sounded different, but they were fantastic.

For dinner we had Maine Crab Cakes and a surprisingly good bolognese. The crab cakes were good, but not outstanding, but I would go back again just to have the bolognese, so hopefully they keep it on their menu.

The prices were where you would expect them to be for what you get. The atmosphere is nice, but it is a pretty small space and the noise really carries. If you are looking for a quiet evening this is probably not your spot. If you want a very good meal with great drink options you should definitely give Street a try.

I have recommended friends to go here as well and they were not disappointed.
author: Frank J.

description:
Love their dark & stormy cocktail made with the homemade ginger ale.

I would give this place 4 stars if they were more consistent.

Big steak salad - good
Burger - has been great and then not so much twice.

I've had other items from the menu....salty or blah.  Too bad.
author: Mela C.

description:
SPARKLY BARBIE! Enough said.

This place. Amazing. I honestly think I found my favorite new place. Jim G. and I had our weekly dine out and we decided to try Street. Why not.
Our waiter who was extremely nice and extremely cute knew the menu front and back. He had great suggestions. Once I had my cocktail, the Sparkly Barbie- I died. A delicious martini. I indulged. I got two and was perfectly buzzed for a while.

I had the crab cakes which shut the front door- SO good! Was it worth 15 bucks? Maybe not but they were a decent size and yum yumm yummy! Jim got raviolis and said they were great. I stole a bite (ok! maybe two!) and I agree full heartedly. We both got dessert. I had the bread pudding which to be honest can be a little too rich for my taste. This was like God herself made this out of the oven and gave me a huge delicious serving. It was perfect. And the vanilla bean ice cream made it sooo much more better. I think Jim got the pana cotta. I can't remember. But it was great.

Our bill totaled about $100 including tax and tip which was more than we were planning on spending, but I had no complaints. The meal was delish. I left feeling content (the food didn't weigh me down, not too heavy) and their drinks were strong! My compliments to the bartender!
author: Amanda S.

description:
Service: Excellent. I can't remember our waiter's name (I've had her three times in a row), but she's fabulous.

Drinks: If you can handle it, get the Sparkle Barbie. Delicious.

Food: Fresh and fabulous. Risotto is one of my favorites, but you can't go wrong with the seafood either.

Ambiance: Cozy (but the tables aren't too close together), high-end but not snobby, vibrant but not crazy loud.
author: Aggie N.

description:
This place is oddly dark... like VERY dark. 
I don't know why I'm mentioning this; it just stood out to me. 

But anyway, I liked this place because it seems like it would be a good place to pregame. It's a bar but also a restaurant and all the cocktails look really tasty.

Their burger is.. average. Not bad but not amazing. Definitely would satisfy a burger craving though. 

It's the kinda place I would suggest taking a smaller group of friends. 

I will be returning!
author: Allie E.

description:
Hello Street, I greatly appreciate how you gave me shelter from this past weekend's rainy onslaught.

Unfortunately, I do not appreciate waiting 15min longer than what was quoted when we walked in.  I did not appreciate getting seated AFTER the party that strolled in 10 minutes after us. I did not appreciate having to wave down the waitresses several times to get a 2oz serving of ketchup to share between four people. And most importantly, I did not appreciate a crab and fettucine dish completely devoid of developed flavors.

From what I read, the burger might be the best thing on their menu, but rather than experience another bout of abominable service, I will just mosey on over to Polker's Gourmet Burgers instead.
author: Nick W.

description: Food was fantastic and at a good price. I had the new York steak and it was easily one of the best steaks I've ever had. My wife had the macaroni and cheese which was also excellent.
author: Chris C.

description: Where do I start!! I'd love to start with the clam and rock shrimp chowder but let's start from when I walked in the door. I was offered a table but knew instantly that I needed to sit at the bar with the heart of the restaurant. I could almost hear her praises from the polar opposite side of the world and what I heard was AMY AMY AMY!! I hardly toot horns but she was so on top of not just the drinks but the menu as well! If you have a night to spare or just a spare hour stop by and say hi!! P.S. The souffléd goat cheese and arugula meal is over the top!!
author: Brent J.

description:
BEST BURGER EVER. 

That is all you have to know. You might think it's sad or funny but I know my burgers. I get burgers at any nice restaurant that offers them. This is THE juiciest and tastiest hamburger I have ever tasted. 

On the menu it doesn't even say burger; it just read sirloin. 

I ordered mine medium with gruyere cheese. It was a whopping $13, but worth every dollar. 

The only negative thing I have to say was that I was not a fan of their house ginger ale.

*Credit to Phil L for telling me about this place. You were right.
author: Carlos A.

description: Came here on a Friday night around 7:30.  Looked busy, but they sat us right away at an available table. I had the burger which was cooked perfectly medium rare, as I had requested.  My boyfriend had the prime rib, which he said was very good.  I ordered the prosecco, and when it came time to ask for another glass, it took a while to arrive.  The waitress brought it over and explained that this second glass was on the house because they were out of the original one I had been drinking and had to find a replacement and it took longer than it should have.  I didn't mind at all, and that kind of attention to detail and customer service was greatly appreciated.  Great atmosphere, quite dark, but a good date night spot for sure.
author: Becca R.

description: My first 5 star review. So damn good on all levels. Food, ambiance, experience. I started with the steamed clams then baby kale salad then tomato bisque. All perfect. Oh, and the malbec was very lovely as well. My friend had the steak and seemed to enjoy also. Parking on Polk sucks, that's my only disclaimer. Enjoy!
author: Olivia O.

description:
A little price-y for what it is. Still had a good meal here none-the-less.

My friends and I started with some hummus, whcih was O.K. We were catching up and it was early on a Friday (630) night. Not busy at all, but the waiter didn't seem to like us taking our time. I got the veggie risotto and asked to add shrimp. It was good but the portions were small. My friends dined on the salads with rare tuna on top and clam linguini, each said the same thing of their meals... small.

Got a nice bottle of wine, and then some, which was O.K. but still a little over-priced. I understand it's a small, boutique-y type of a place, but still, no need for $30-40 markups on wines I can find at BevMo for $10-15.

Peanut butter dessert was delicious. It was a nice place and I don't regret it but I wouldn't recommend with so many other places in the city to dine... and I wouldn't go back.
author: christine c.

description: I took a friend out for a nice casual dinner. This place was super nice, the waitress rocked. I had the mixed grill which is lamb chops and sausage. So tender it almost fell off the bone. I would recommend for a nice date night  :)
author: Jessie V.

description: If you are in need of a place to grab a late meal before the drinking commences, Street would be a contender. It's near several bars and it is a bar itself. The burger was juicy and good to start coating your tummy. The fries with aioli is also a good choice to prevent possible sickness from drinking. I don't recommend getting the dumplings. A good place to start the night.
author: Eve C.

description:
"I really wanted to like this place..."

...and hey, I really did!  hehe. dumb cliche Yelp phrases. This restaurant opened in 2001, and has survived more than 5 years in San Francisco's intensely competitive restaurant market, qualifying it by my assessment, as one of the City's more well-established, long-standing trendy bistros.  They serve an upscale, contemporized version of traditional American, French and Italian cuisines.  Most of their dishes are prepared from locally-grown produce and staple ingredients.

My companion and I most recently tried the risotto with white prawns and the grilled Hawaiian ahi with chipotle-lime aioli, both excellent.  I've also had the burger which, as reiterated here by a number of Yelpers, is one of the City's better gourmet burgers.

Great ambiance and service, the only flaw in the experience was that the hostess spaced out and gave us somebody else's check before we had even been served our salads, but precious little in this life is perfect....
author: Rick H.

description:
Keeping it short:

Food = outstanding. We tried the heirloom tomato app, hummus app, mac and cheese app, risotto main course, pasta bolognese, brownie dessert, and peanut butter ice cream dessert. All were worth ordering again. 

Service = bartender was super friendly and made us some great cocktails. The dark and stormy was darker and stormier than I have ever seen it made before. The waitress was a bit brusque, not rude, just doing her job. But she was nice enough to let us hold a table for four while we waited for friends who were sitting in traffic. 

Ambiance = dimly lit and cozy. Good luck getting a table on a super busy night, or finding parking for that matter... but so goes the city. 

We'll definitely be back the next time we're in SF for some classic comfort food.
author: Crystal J.

description:
I've been to Street many times before, but not in a long while.  This time, I was angling for a beer and a burger.  This paved the way for a good comparison against Magnolia, where I also recently had (and reviewed) a burger and beer experience.  While I thought Magnolia's interior didn't match its new upscale-leaning menu, I think Street does a lot with their space to make you feel like you're getting good value for your money.  Edge: Street.  

Interestingly, both burgers (when you include the accoutrements) cost the same amount.  However, while the Street burger was merely good, Magnolia's Prather Ranch burger was divine.  Street struggled as so many places do with their definition of "medium-rare", but it wasn't way off.  Still, the Street fries almost made up for this miss.  Hot, crunchy, yummy.  Edge: Magnolia by the slimmest of hairs.

Street: good value, great space, pretty fine burger.
author: Laurence W.

description:
Street is a nice relaxing place for dinner. I always get the same thing -- seared Ahi with green beans and mashed potatoes, along with the cucumber martini.

Unfortunately, the tables are about a foot apart which makes it an awkward date restaurant. I've never not introduced myself to the people sitting next to me because the proximity feels uncomfortable. That said, the Ahi is delicious!
author: Jason M.

description: This is a great place to have a quality meal with friends without breaking the bank. I had the steak salad, cooked perfectly and good portion. I am a hard critic of steak salads and this one was one of the best I have had in a while! Cute environment inside with good art on the walls. As an MFA, this is also something I pay attention to. My beau had the shrimp and clam linguini which had great flavor, but if you are looking for a big bowl of pasta I would try the pasta with meat sauce instead. Flavor trumped portion with his dish but we all left full and happy! They overcharged a couple of bucks for our bottle of wine and the salami appetizer but were quick to fix this on the bill. Wait staff was great and the chef even took the time to talk to us as we left to make sure we enjoyed our food. Would definitely come back! This is a great date spot.
author: Sarah N.

description: OH MAN, this place has the BEST BURGER I've ever had in my LIFE!! There is only one burger on the menu. You have the option to add other items to your burger such as bacon, ranch, cheese, onion, etc. I recommend cheese and onion. The onion is super sweet!!!! The burger meat was very tasty and flavorful, the bun was nicely toasted and buttered up. I absolutely loved it!! I also enjoyed that this wasn't a fast food place, but rather a nice sit down restaurant with great service! Can't wait to go back!
author: Lynn T.

description:
I hate giving bad reviews for spots that I've only been to once....but after try their Hummus plate, Calamari,  Ahi, and New York Strip, I came to the conclusion that this place has below  food for the price. Not impressed at all. 

The service was okay, and the place itself is nice and intimate. But the food was just so average. The hummus was blah. The calamari was actually pretty good. The steak was no better than something you'd get at Chili's...Good, but nothing to rave about. The ahi was, again, blah. 

I've heard great things about Street's deserts, but my GF and I were over it by the time we finished our dinners, so I wasn't able to try any out. 

Not sure what I'd change about their food. It wasn't bad, by any means...it's just that now and days, in the City, a restaurant has to find ways to separate themselves, or at least implement something unique to give it that "wow" factor, especially with all the other options out there. 

Street's food is extremely average, and there are just way, way too many other spots I'd go to again before heading back there.
author: Farbod D.

description: Good addition to Polk Street restaurants.  Open late and we didn't have to wait.  Burger was decent.
author: Erika C.

description:
Great food and fast efficient service. Calamari starter is a winner, along with the Ahi main which is served with mash and green beans. My only change would be to serve this with a  wasabi mayonnaise. The crab cakes are also fantastic.
The restaurant is small and gets crowded and noisy but it just adds to the fun.
Highly recommend.
author: Chella T.

description:
I have had two very great experiences at this restaurant. Both with the same waitress, the service has always been first class. The restaurant prices are a bit high but the food is so good I think its still worth it. 

Beware though, this place can be very crowded on a Saturday night!
author: Sueann W.

description: A nice little joint. Overall the food was good. Ordered some calamari, very crispy and lightly battered. The clams were well flavored, could have drank the broth by itself. I believe I had the ceaser salad with steak and boy it was yummy (5 stars). The salad dressing was light and refreshing and the steak was well cooked, medium rare. Tried a few pasta dishes and it was just okay for me.
author: Nhung T.

description:
Street is awesome and a staple on Polk, even though it's easy to walk past due to a nondescript exterior. 

The food is great, but what I like most is the atmosphere (or "ahm-biahnce" for people who wear pocket squares to bars). It's dark, intimate and energetic -- a great spot to bring friends or have a date. 

Starting the night with Street and then heading to one of the many awesome bars on Polk (e.g. the infamous Bullitt bar) will make for an epic night (but potentially less epic morning!).
author: Peter C.

description:
Went here a while back for a small bday get together. Nice quaint, stylish, little space. I have a small niche in my stomach that craves for well crafted, gussied up, comfort food. Polk happens to have two such joints in Street and Spoon (down the road). Although it seems throughout the years as the menus change frequently they've gotten a bit fancier as time has moved on. 

Went for the NY Strip and fries and it definitely hit the spot. The steak was a perfect medium rare and came with a rich topping of gorgonzola butter and a side of fries. I got the panna cotta to round out the meal . I was thinking to myself  the chefs must  have my number here because how could a menu so small happen to have two of my all time favorite items? Hmmm...

The service was attentive and friendly even though it's a fairly bustling environment. My only complaint is even with a reservation it can sometimes be a wait. Definitely doubles as a good neighborhood or destination restaurant.
author: Kim N.

description:
Great service!  Our waiter was very attentive and friendly.  

I love how they include desserts right there on the menu.  Makes it easier to plan ahead - how much room to leave for what.  Brilliant!  :D
author: Kristen S.

description: I've been coming to Street since it first opened--in 2000? It's one of my favorite spots in SF for comfort food. I like that the calamari--light and not overly fried--comes with a tangy sauce instead of a typical marinara. The ahi is my go-to dish--it's always prepared perfectly. The bread pudding is hands down the best thing in the world, caramely and delicious. The service is always excellent too!
author: A E.

description:
Great location, service and ambiance. Food was solid but a wee bit on the small size for portions (meatloaf and mashed potatoes). Definitely going to check out the Sunday fried chicken dinner, I hear it's fantastic.

This place is worth checking out if you're in the neighborhood.
author: Robert A.

description:
I wasn't sure what to expect given the reviews, but I found my Street experience to be good.  The food was tasty and the service was good; everybody was really friendly, and I found the space to be warm and welcoming.  The wine list is pretty good, and there is a pretty wide choice of entrees for such a small place.

Best of all, I was surprised how easy it was to walk in and get a table at 7:30 on a Friday night.
author: Wendy L.

description: Great service, tasty food. I went there for my birthday and was trying to make a reservation. The hostess was very nice, even though they do not take reservation she still offers to try reserve a table for my friends and I. I will definitely revisit soon!
author: Jenn M.

description:
5 stars for service 4 for food
the hostess took fabulous care of our large party. She would come to the bar next door to update us on the status of our table. The crab cakes were great but request another side as they came with French fries. The spicy pasta dish was wonderful but don't ask for extra spice if you aren't prepared!
author: Keira B.

description: Found this awesome neighborhood restaurant while driving through the Russian Hill area. We ordered the calamari appetizer, crab cakes and the buttermilk fried chicken. All three dishes were excellent. We also tried several drinks off the cocktail menu and every one of them was good. Definitely a great find. Will be back soon.
author: Inde A.

description:
Street has pretty average food, that is slightly over priced.  

I came here with my friend kv, Bc she heard the burgers are amazing. Okay, were each getting burgers. We ordered truffle Mac and cheese instead of fries, because why not...

Both were solid, but I've had far better burgers for way less. Overall it seems like street is trying to do a lot of different foods that are okay, as opposed to specializing, 

It's worth trying but I doubt I'd go back. Not for a 14 dollar cheeseburger without fries. Honestly, it's a hamburger. 

And they also failed my "what's good here" test. If the waitress says "everything", that's probably not true. It's like a girl who says she's amazing in bed. Too much self promotion is a bad sign.
author: Devin K.

description: This place is extremely LOUD. Absolutely ruined our experience. The owner needs to fix the acoustics because it kills the experience. I couldn't wait to get out of the restaurant. We will no go back.
author: Peter O.

description:
I knocked them down one star because they don't take reservations and we waited well over the 45 min wait time that the hostess told us it would be. But once you've waited that long what's the point in going somewhere else??

We had a full mean here from apps to desert while out with friends and enjoyed every course. The calamari was excellent, served with a spicy chili sauce instead of the traditional marinara. My husband and I both had a pasta dish that tasted like home made pasta (not sure if it was). 

And the waitress was excellent. I can't wait to go back.
author: Nihad P.

description: Street..... You are our new late night goto! My steak and blue cheese salad and manhattan were mind blowing! See you soon
author: Ray C.

description:
The Kennebec fries was what got my friends & I to try this place (aside from the restaurant name itself). 

The cocktails were awful and the food was just okay. It was nothing to be in awe about. The desserts were good - the toffee crunch.

Food: Mediocre

Service: Average - the manager was a bit rude

Price: Over-priced for just "ok" so/so food
author: Candice H.

description: Aftering checking Yelp reveiws, my wife and I visited Street over the weekend and we're thrilled we did.  We arrived early and decided to have a drink at the bar.  We were greeted by a fantastic bartender named Amy, Saint Amy in fact.  She was extremely helpful in selecting beer and wine, and made appetizer suggestions.  All the suggestions were perfect and we decided to sit at the bar for dinner.  Again, Amy was very helpful with dinner suggestions. We ordered the wontons to start, and enjoyed the tuna and sausage sampler for entrees.  We followed that up with bread pudding for dessert-all delicious.  The restarant is relativley small but they do take reservations.  If you have any trouble getting a table, I would strongly suggest grabbing a spot at the bar and enjoying a clear view of the kitchen where John prepares masterful yet simple meals, and the company of Saint Amy.
author: Steve F.

description: I've found my new favorite restaurant and new favorite food... pork, veal, beef & porcini bolognese, made with fresh egg papardelle! Start drooling now folks. It's out of this world and a great portion size too! The crab cakes are also to die for. I will for sure become a regular here!
author: Anne-Marie H.

description:
Not a bad spot to grab a casual dinner.  I think I got lucky because there was no wait for a table for 2.  I was a little disappointed by the menu offerings for the night (the online menu looked better).  That said, my caesar salad was solid (a bit overly cheesed but still tasted good - had a nice lemony edge to it) and I really liked my warm bittersweet chocolate cake with vanilla ice cream.

I took the server's suggestion and ordered chicken-ricotta ravioli over the prime rib but I think I should've just gone with the steak.  The ravioli was tasty but didn't quite hit the spot. My dining companion ordered the strip steak and that tasted pretty good though.

This could def be 4 stars on another night - I think I just had bad luck syncing with the night's menu.  I'd come back though.
author: Priscilla T.

description: Street is my favorite go-to for comfort food in a comfortable environment.  I always feel like a part of the family.  Monica is a fantastic bartender, and the food is precisely what it appears to be: comfortable, not fancy, just great real food.
author: Randy W.

description: Good place with a nice atmosphere. Wanted to try the fried chicken but it was not on the menu. I decided to try the burger and it was good....Not the best in SF as some have said. The best thing here I would say is the Peanut Butter Ice cream. It's homemade and tastes like a peanut butter cookie.
author: Shawn R.

description: This place is right around the corner, and I really want to love it, but I just don't. There's nothing wrong with it, but it's just average. The food is okay (disclaimer: I'm a vegetarian, so the menu is limiting), and the service is spotty (I've gone three time - 2 were below average and one was average). But it does have a chill vibe and is open later than some in the area.
author: Christina S.

description:
A recent visit to Street reminded me again why this venue rests so high in my book.

I need a weekly burger, and there's no place in San Francisco I enjoy more to satisfy my craving than Street. 

It's the whole experience here that makes me swing through their doors often. It's always a pleasure seeing Amy behind the bar, and she reflects the entire mood of the place. Comforting, warm and makes you feel like you're at home.

While there are numerous burgers in SF, and I've had many of them, the burger here topped with melted gruyere, and a few slabs of thick crispy bacon settles me down.

Paired with a bowl of their golden fries that have weight and crisp, you can kiss goodbye any work week stresses here with a top off of one of their cold brews on tap.

Street is the epitome of a neighborhood joint, and the staff, owners and food come together in a perfect melody. Once a week, I know I always have at least one thing to look forward to.
author: Mike K.

description:
I was at William Cross last Friday and wanted to order food in the neighborhood so I called Street. I looked at their menu on Yelp and on-line and ordered the Wild Prawn Risotto (for $17.25). 
From Street's website:
risotto wild white prawns, red chard, basil, reggiano and truffle oil 17.25 

With tax and the $10 drink I ordered while I waited for my order plus a generous 25% tip, I was out $38. The bartender was really nice so I didn't mind the tip. I got home, opened the box to find a total of zero shrimp! I called the restaurant - a girl answered and I explained the situation - she asked if I ordered online and I said "No, I called the restaurant and ordered the wild prawn risotto". She said that the risotto didn't have any prawns in it but that I could come in the next day and talk to the manager to get a refund.

I wasn't able to go to Street the next day so I went tonight. I asked for the manager and was directed to John, the owner. I explained the situation  to him and I have to say that I was less than satisfied. This is what he told me:
1. Their menu changes everyday - I honestly haven't seen any evidence of this.
2. The girl on the phone who took my order for Wild Prawn Risotto must have only heard Risotto so she didn't bother to let me know that the risotto just had a couple of cherry tomatoes in it.
3. They can serve risotto with prawns but that would be WAY MORE expensive - closer to $27! I'd like Yelpers to look at my photo and decide if that looks like a $27 dish, especially with tiny 60-count shrimp, not wild prawn...
4. When I pointed out that their website had the prawn risotto for $17.25, John told me that the website hadn't been updated in 9 years and that they were a neighborhood restaurant that doesn't bother with the website - take the website down then, John!!
5. John asked if I'd like my dish made again, with "prawns" and comped the dish.
6. John didn't admit any responsibility for Street and hoped that I'd come back.

Street gets one star for making my dish again (albeit without wild prawn and with tiny shrimp) and one star for the dish being tasty - I'm being really generous here!
author: Viv A.

description:
I've been wanting to try this place for a while, specifically for their fried chicken.  I didn't know it is only served on Sunday.  After failed visit due to menu or crowds, we finally made it in yesterday.  It really was fate because right when I said to hubby, we'll eat at Street if we can find a space...guess what?  Yup, a space right in front - on a weeknight around 7:30pm?  

The place was not busy.  Few people at the bar and few table for 2s and 4s.  The interior is a lot smaller than we expected but it's nice - holds 30 or so total?  Quite dark inside w/ dark red walls and lots of abstract looking artwork.  Lighting is what we call "ambiance" lighting but to us older folks, reading the menu becomes a squinting challenge.  

Simple one page menu but it took us a while to debate our options.  The drinks menu was 1 page but front/back with wine selection by the glass, draft and bottled beer and a list of cocktails.  Hubby wants a cold beer (Anchor Steam - $5) so I opted to try their Sangria ($6).  The sangria was served in a pint glass with ice and a paper umbrella - it was on the sweet side but quench the thirst.

We shared the spinach salad ($8.75) and that was a good thing because it was a generous portion, I could have had that for an entree on a hot day.  It was very good, just the right amount of dressing w/o over drenching.  The bacon pieces were a nice treat and compliment to the spinach.  The red beets were sweet and refreshing.  Loved every bite of the salad.  Off to a good start...

Hubby had the rack of lamb ($19.75), I think it's really his default if it's on the menu.  It was the special of the evening.  The plate came with 3 pieces w/ mashed potato and green beans.  The chops were cooked as requested - medium rare.  The sight of the redish pink sure puts a smile on our faces.  It looked so good that I made hubby cut a small piece for me before he got a bite and before I dug into mine.  It was good even though it's on the lean side - there was no fat, not even near the bone but it was still very tender.  The sauce, however, was way too sweet -  it tasted like the sweet chili sauce you get from Asian markets.  Did not like the sauce at all.  The mashed potato was thick and buttery.  

I had the pasta w/ crab and homemade spicy sausage ($19.75) - it was also the special.  I'm so glad our waitress, Rachell, recommended it since I was debating among that, the crab and shrimp cakes or the risotto.  The fettuccine was damn good, al-dente!  The texture of the pasta was very good so I had to ask the waitress if it was made there and sure enough it was.  The cream sauce was light and flavorful.  The spicy sausage had a nice kick to it and it really went well w/ the more subtle flavor of the crab.  They must have sprinkled some cheese on top and lightly baked it because the little bit of crispiness was divine!  They should add this to their regular menu!

Simple dessert menu with 6 choices?  The coconut panna cotta sounded interesting but the peanut butter ice cream w/ some kind of meringe and stuff sure sounded tasty.  Bread pudding ($5.75) wasn't really considered but our waitress raves about it - people who don't like bread pudding likes it...she'll buy it for us if we didn't like it.  How can you say no to that?  Well, I didn't like it - I thought it was too dense and dry although the dryness can easily be masked w/ the creamy caramel sauce or the whipped cream, which my hubby loved (the sauce and the cream).  

It was a wonderful dinner, just didn't end on a high note.  Until next time...
author: Gloria H.

description:
Nom Nom Nom. Love the cocktails and the food here. Since they don't take reservations, we planned ahead and came early on Saturday night at about 6:30 and there was no wait for a table of 4. 

We started with the calamari to share, which was good. I ordered the lemon basil martini which was alright. The real cocktail winner in my book is the apripolitan, with apricot flavored vodka and even a dried apricot inside the drink to eat afterwards. It's sweet but not overly sweet, love it. 

For my entree, I went with what I have had here before, the grilled ahi tuna. This is so good and is served  with an aoili on top, over mashed potatoes  and green beans. My friend had the crab cakes, which I've also had before and are delightfully tasty -of course I had a bite of my friends dish :) Both boys had the steak, which from the bite I tasted was very good. I also stole a few fries. I think overall you can't really go wrong with anything you order here.

The ambiance is nice. We had the high table right in the front, so it was fairly private and made for easy conversation. The lighting is a little dark and funky red colored but I think it adds to the ambiance. I usually stray from American food but Street is the exception. The food is fantastic and I am reminded of this everytime I come. I would definitely recommend it for a date night or an intimate, but fun, dinner for groups of less than 4.
author: Carolyn K.

description:
The food at Street is so yummy!!!!  It's clear the chef uses the freshest of meat, fruit, veggies. Everything tasted so good. Starting with the cocktails, all housemade and unique. Something for every palate. Followed by pork belly sliders. The bomb. Good thing there were only two, otherwise I would have eaten a dozen. The accompanying arugula and watermelon salad offset the richness of the pork belly. Had the pasta. House made. Bolognese. So tasty. Followed by the peanut butter ice cream. Take all of your yummiest foods - many of them the things we ate as kids - turn them up a notch. Add a hefty dose of deliciousness and that is Street. Really. Stop here. Eat often. GREAT place. And reasonably priced. Why go anywhere else for a tasty meal? Try this place!!!

I hadn't been to Street in many years... dropped by recently on a Saturday night. Called first, so the table was available after a search for parking and a very short wait. 

Super yummy!
author: sl c.

description: I don't give 5 stars often but the niche that this restaurant fills is just perfect. The atmosphere is laidback (characterized by the dim lighting, quiter but not too quite diners, and comfort food laden menu). This can be your favorite local place to go when you don't feel like being wrapped up in a 'scene', your next date location, or the restaurant where you and your 3 friends catch up. Multipurpose restaurants are the best!... And hard to come by.
author: Melanie A.

description: Outstanding. The Brussel sprouts appetizer was one of my favorite appetizers of all time. The lemon cheesecake was light and flavorful - amazing really.
author: Chris R.

description:
The risotto. Meh.

It was a big ol' pile of undercooked rice that was really poorly presented. I posted a photo because it was so darn ugly... Looked like someone got ill on my plate.  It arrived and I think I said "seriously?" The fact that it was undercooked and somewhat flavorless, well I was really disappointed at $17 a plate.

Yes, the burger is worth it, as are the drinks.  Perfect, in fact.

The meyer lemon cheesecake, was also very disappointing. The chunks of lemon were odd... So odd that I found myself pulling them out of my mouth to investigate.  And the consistency of the cheesecake was way off; thick, but not in a good way. 

I would go back for the burger and the drinks.  The rest, again, meh.
author: Hayley W.

description:
I've come here a few times, and each time has been enjoyable.

Highlights:
*The Hawaiian Seared Ahi -- absolutely delicious over mashed potatoes and a side of colorful string beans (very buttery, yum!)
*Their cocktails -- extremely delicious. I tried one recently (not sure what it's called but it's near the top of their cocktail menu). Came with gin, blood orange, and champagne. One of the best cocktails I've tried in a while!
*Their staff -- I have had a pleasant experience with the staff each time I have been here.

The only complaint I have is I think their prices can be a bit high. I believe the tuna is 21 bucks which is fair, I guess, but my salad last night was 9 bucks for 90% spinach, a few beets, and some cheese. Maybe 5 tiny pieces of bacon. They definitely skimped on the salad, and that was disappointing. I'm still giving this place 4 stars because I've had an excellent time eating here each time I've been. Even if I did overpay for a salad, I was with great company, and had a great cocktail, what's to complain about? :)
author: Ashley D.

description: Recently met a friend here late at night. Food was great and ambiance was just right for the night. I would've given a 5 but my Espresso Martini was a big miss. Don't order that.
author: Albert Paris W.

description:
I had an overall great experience here April 20th.
 The place is small and family owned, the service was excellent and the food was seriously something to return for. I think the prices are just right for what you get. I had steak and holy smoke was it good! It was cooked perfectly and just the right amount of food.
I'm drooling just thinking about it. Thanks G and G for a great B-day dinner!
author: Roanna Z.

description:
One word sums up my review of this place: SALTY

I've read some of the previous reviews, and maybe, so has the chef.  While everyone else thought the food was too bland, my experience here was quite different.  Everything tasted like it was soaked in a bath of salt water for a few hours.  My mash potatoes.... a big salt mount.

My party and I ordered (and I've took a bite of each dish):
Grilled Filet (which is actually a beef dish, not fish) 
Grilled Tuna
Risotto
Angus New York Strip Steak

All those dishes were salty, and nothing else.

The only reason they got a 3 star instead of a 2 is because of their infused vodka and dessert.

My party tried the fig and cucumber flavored vodka.  The cucumber vodka was very refreshing.  The fig was the favorite.

For dessert, we ordered the Buttermilk Panna Cotta and the Toffee Cake with Ice Cream.  Both were outstanding.  This pretty much saved their rating from me.

I don't think I'll be going back again.
author: Maggie L.

description: Oh.. I haven't been here in so long and I miss it. I hope the recent city crackdown on infusions hasn't made its way here because the fig infused vodka is amazing. New American food made right with fried chicken Sundays that close out the weekend. You feel at home here and the prices are not too much. The tables are a wee bit close together and the sound level is deafening on a weekend night but great for first dates because the din of neighboring conversation will blanket any of those uncomfortable silences.
author: Jennifer O.

description:
This review is for their Sunday Special: Fried Chicken.

Hands down THE BEST fried chicken my husband and I have EVER tasted and he's the king of fried chicken!!  This fried chicken review echos BOTH of our sentiments as to ALL the places we've taste tested (but I'm quoting him for the most part):

We've had fried chicken from various places.  Chicken n' Waffles was okay; then you've got your run of the mill fast food joints like KFC, Meh, not bad; Popeyes, YUCK; Church's, Double Yuck.  

We've also had fried chicken attempted at a home and although the effort was commendable, Hubby thought the chicken turned out too dry (even the dark meat) and over-seasoned.  DH prefers white meat and he stated that it was drier than the dark meat, and thus he was relegated to dark meat for whatever moistness was left.  So getting fried chicken cooked perfectly is very difficult.

Street took all the mistakes from all these various places and rectified them into succulent pieces of finger lickin' fried chicken deliciousness.  The meat is tender, juicy and moist and the outside is seasoned perfectly and crisped to perfection!!
author: Karen B.

description:
How does this place get so many stars? 

Went here for dinner last night. 

My date and I got there around 6:30, the bar counter is full. A couple was seated at the table, and then there was us. A few minutes later a family walks in. 

OK, we get our drinks and order taken in a timely manner. 

Appetizer: Calamari - too much flour used for the batter (this, by the way, came out instantly).  

We then waited.....waited....waited..... waited freakin 1 HOUR for our food! The waitress knew we were getting impatient, she came over and told us it will be out in just a few more minutes and that was 15 mins before it actually came out. I don't know what took so darn long, but the food was just warm! You would think that the food would come pipping HOT! 

We ordered:

Crab, sausage, and artichoke fettuccine - Pretty good, I must admit. The pasta is homemade. They did not skimp on anything! =)

Steak - it was good- cooked well (my date eats it like that), it wasn't burnt, still juicy and tasty! 

As people began to trickle in I saw that many were ordering the same, so I still do not understand why it took us so long to get our food!! 

Food is pretty good here, staff is friendly, but it just takes them too long to get food to you, if you are thinking about coming here, be sure to snack before hand.
author: Diana L.

description:
I LOVE this place!!  My sweet friends took me there for my birthday and the hamburger was absolutely heavenly.  I like my meat rare, but this medium rare take on my burger was divine.  Juicy, velvet-like texture made the crisp crust of the bun seem alive.  Add in a wonderful dark and candlelit atmosphere, and my age didn't seem so bad anymore.

"4" for the food, "4" for the service, and a "4" for the interior!
author: Miika M.

description:
I love Polk St, I like the restaurants and bars and the crowed so I needed to find a new place to try.  And after doing some looking decided to give this a try.  They said they don't take reservations so I was a bit put off, I hate waiting but we figured if the wait was too long then we would go somewhere else.  I got there early and headed to the bar for a drink.  I ordered one of the special martinis, and let me tell you, it began to hit me half way into it.  I'm a drinker and have a good tolerance but this was strong and good and I was hungry.

My friend arrived and we ordered the hummas, and then she got the risotto and I got the crab cakes.  Everything was great, a bit spicy but very flavorful, fresh and great ingredients.  The portions were great too, we both walked away satisfied but not overly full.  It was a great way to start the night that lead us to a few neighborhood bars. 

I would definately come back, the crowed was great, the food was good, the service was fast and friendly.  It's a great place for a casual dinner with friends or a date, and the drinks are great.
author: Inga W.

description:
One of my favorite restaurants in the city.  I've had multiple meals here and they all have impressed me to the point that I commented to the chef which I have never done before.  Start with the Caesar salad which is delicious.  The french fries are amazing too.

The service is great and while there are no reservations, I have never had to wait long.
author: Blake B.

description:
Street's food is fantastic, don't get me wrong, but it's the dessert that is blow your mind, out of this world, beyond words PHENOMENAL!

I love the bar in the back for a billion reasons, top 2 being: 1) Amy 2)  I can always sit my ass down and not feel bad for ordering just dessert.

Amy is charmingly charismatic and will not only allow you to sample different libations, but will also mix you up the most creative new drinks based off typical favorites. 

Bookmark Street- just do yourself a huge favor and save room for dessert!
author: Gabrielle J.

description:
Had a little birthday dinnner rendezvous here. Was rather tasty and the waiter was very friendly. 

I had the special which was a hangar steak over a salad. It was dang good! 

Also have a lot of delicious drinks. And desserts. All good stuff.
author: Lara M.

description:
By the time I turn 50, I am going to be a sad fat bastard from eating at too many good places. That or a happy skinny bitch once I find the right plastic sugeon. Either way, I'm keeping Street on my radar because it's fabulous.

Mary L. was in town and rather than going to typical known places I wanted to try something new. We searched for parking high and low and finally found a spot just across the street and walked in for a late dinner. I figured it would have been packed and the wait probably long but the hostess saw us and sat us down immediately. Thank goodness it was just the two of us, one more person and who knows what the wait would have been. 

The restaurant is dimly lit and the decor comfortably smooth. Almost sexy, the music is a tad on the loud side but you drown it out when you start chatting with a friend you haven't seen for months. The waitress popped in fast to drop off menus and the first thing that caught my eye was the Fig Martini. It was Friday, payday friday so why not splurge. I caroused through the menu and decided to play it safe with fish.

Grilled  Ahi served with a garlic aioli, mashed potatoes and steamed green beans 
*The aioli was gorgeous, not too heavy. The Ahi was a litle too medium for my liking but was seasoned perfectly. Not salty

The Risotto came out on a rounded platter with twisted shrimp, the presentation was definitely worth a mention and the smell was tantalizing.

Drink wise, the Fig martini was strong and did it's job. Mary ordered a Cherry Coke-alcohol included! I liked her's better it was a nice touch up to a childhood favorite. 

Skinny bitch or Fat bastard I'm still coming back to Street to have a  meal in a restaurant that is darkly seductive with food of desire.
author: Morgan M.

description:
Even though I live really close, and even though the food is really good, I could only bring myself to eat here once because of its uncomfortable dining room.

It's REALLY loud and crouded (because it has good food), and waaaay too dark.  I've literally been in better lit dive bars!  It's not just the lighting either - I remember the walls being black too, or damn near black.

Still, I give this place three stars because the food was really so good, even though I could only bring myself to eat there once because of the uncomfortable setting.
author: Dmytro A.

description:
The food was good, not great. But the biggest disappointment was that the NY Strip Steak was NO LONGER ON THE MENU. I saw the steak in the other reviews and was salivating for it, only to find out I couldn't have it. 

Instead had "Salad - Steak" with gorgonzola, and found the steak to be rather scarce on the plate (3 thin slices). For $22 I expected a little more meat.

Nice atmosphere (although a little on the loud side for a comfortable dinner conversation).
author: Felix B.

description:
We have been going to Street for years, but had the worst dining experience ever there recently. My 90-something mother and I sat down at the bar to order drinks, a hamburger and a salad, but "Kevin B.,' our server was abrupt and surly throughout. We had to ask repeatedly for water, which Kevin ultimately slammed down in front of us without comment. When my mom asked for an onion with her burger, he seemed similarly perturbed, and could not have been more unpleasant before ultimately bringing it on a plate. And when we asked for a pen to pay for our credit card at this rather pricey joint, he informed us that it came after the card was run through, turning his back and visibly rolling t is eyes. He did take our money, however.

It's usually a great place, so one hope the owner, Lynn, will reprimand this unpleasant man for his unprofessional and unwelcoming attitude and performance. I gave him a token tip because that's what is customarily called for, but should have stiffed him - and demanded an explanation, and an apology. 

One hopes the owners of this otherwise excellent establishment will take note. Among other things, it was discourteous, for no rational reason, to a longstanding customer of a certain age. I'm a few years younger, but was stunned, too...If I'm paying some money for a meal, I expect a minimum level of courtesy and professionalism, all of which was absent in "Kevin's'' demeanor. Sounds like he needs a basic course in customer relations - or another job somewhere, perhaps a fast food establishment is better suited to his "talents."
author: Sylvia W.

description:
Not bad. 3.5 stars. I wish it didn't look so much like a bar than an actual dine in restaurant. It was really dark inside when I went for dinner at 7. The Giants were playing, so I'm using that as an excuse as to why the restaurant was nearly empty when we dined there. 

Not surprising, I ordered the burger since I read so many reviews on it. The reviews were pretty accurate, and although not positive I would name it the best burger in the city, it would've been the best burger on Polk Street. I also complemented with a glass of wine and the total ended up being around $35 w/ tip. Not too bad!

I had unknowingly left my credit card there. Left a message the next day. Although no one called me back after I left a message, I called again later that evening and the bartender indeed told me it was there, so I picked it up before closing time the next night. I guess thanks for keeping it safe and not charging me!
author: Jeanne C.

description: Went here for a Friday night diner with friends, and had a great time and overall dining experience.  Street gets automatic points for having sangria on the menu.  Had hummus for an appetizer, and the prime rib salad for the main course.  Both were amazing.  I kind of wish their menu was a little more expansive, and I find a meal there a little out of my price range for frequent visits. But the food is definitely worth the price and the atmosphere is also great!
author: Bridget B.

description:
How has this place been around for ten years, and we only recently came across it? So glad we did, since it's the perfect spot for a casual date. Share a few appetizers - the portions are generous and you'll want to sample as much as possible. 

The martinis are excellent - try the Fig Martini - though what you cannot miss is the home made peanut butter ice cream on top of the chocolate cake. To die for. Will definitely be making this a regular spot!
author: Cynthia S.

description: We got here so early, we were the first customers before the after work, Friday night crowd trickled in. Our drinks - a pepper vodka and olive martini (Zach) and a dark and stormy for me were excellent. We had the pick of places to sit and flawless service throughout the meal. Delicious homemade gnocchi with spicy sausage and the prime rib sprinkled with rock salt made my toes tingle and was impressed with the goat cheese pastry for appetizer. Modern decor, well thought out space with minimal noise vibrations. I'm bummed that I didn't think to stay for dessert!
author: Alita M.

description:
Delicious delicious delicious burger. Get the burger. Do it.

Okay so seriously this place has an awesome burger. (5 stars): Usually when I get halfway through a meal and I feel full I pack up the other half to eat later. When this happened at Street... I couldn't stop eating. Yes, I ate double what I needed to feel full. Whoops.

Fried Calamari (4 stars): Tasty! And pretty large portion. Sweet/spicy thai chile sauce was a good compliment.

Lemon & Basil Martini (5 stars): Refreshing cocktail! I hate really sweet drinks, and this was just what I was looking for, tart and herbaceous. YUM

Service (4 stars): No complaints! Attentive and professional.

Atmosphere (5 stars): Small, cozy, nice music and lighting. Great for a small group dinner or date, or just getting drinks at the bar!
author: Melissa H.

description:
Sad to say we were a bit bored by Street. The atmosphere was dark and fun, the waiters & esses, were lively and on top of their game.

The food left much to be desired.

The good:
gaspacho & lemon cheese cake

The boring:
Sashimi grade ahi tuna- of course it tasted good, it was sashimi grade, but that's all it was- seared tuna on top of over salted mashed potatoes and some boiled green beans. I could have made this $96 dollar meal for 2 at home.
author: ellen m.

description: john, the owner and chef, knows what he is doing.  perhaps the best dumplings in a city famous for chinatown.  as for the street burger, let's just while hiking in patagonia, this was the burger that my wife was craving, so upon our return home, we headed straight down to the street to satisfy that craving.  too bad we didn't get home on friday in time for the prime rib!  just love this spot.  always delivers.
author: Dinesh N.

description:
Solid selection of cocktails, with ones that match all types of cocktail palates -- dry ones, bitter ones, and spicy ones. The Boy had the Dark and Stormy and I the Fig Martini -- his had quite a ginger kick (hello homemade ginger ale!) and mine tasted like dried figs (a good or bad thing, depending on your feelings about dried figs). Our friends got the Apripolitan and Mussolini -- the former an apricot twist on the cosmo, and the latter a blend of Campari and Citron (right up my alley; I would have finished it if he discovered that he didn't like Campari :p).

The food was fine -- generous portions and a menu that covered all the bases: there's a hamburger, a few pasta dishes, a pork dish, a chicken dish, some salads. I don't know if I'm jaded, but I just wasn't excited by the offerings. I wound up getting crabcakes which were smothered in a heavy mayo sauce and were kind of limp and under-flavored. The highlight of my dish were the accompanying fries, which were crisp and large and delicious with the Boy's gnocchi sauce. 

I liked the ambiance here -- the walls have lovely paintings of everyday scenes and the waitstaff is friendly but unobtrusive. The presentation is quite nice, with artsy zigzags of sauce and large, hearty plates. 

All in all, this is a good place to go with a group of friends or family. I wouldn't come here expecting culinary magic, but it's got great drinks and a comfortable atmosphere, which is often what one wants on a dinner outing.
author: Annie M.

description:
Came here for dinner.  Ordered the calamari as an appetizer.  it was cooked well and the dipping sauce was tasty.  Slightly tangy and a litle spicy.  
For dinner I had the Fried Chicken, and I was pleasantly surprised.  I thought the cornbread was moist and flavorful, and the chicken was well seasoned and not greasy.  
My friend had the steak, i liked that as well, but i think i would order it more rare to avoid overcooking.

I also had some bevs, a good selection at the bar, so you can't really go wrong.

it's not the most economical place, but i think it is tasty enough to go back for a return visit.
author: Lu E.

description:
I don't get it.  I thought it would be better, but it was pretty mediocre--like food you'd find in the rural midwest, or in the early 90s.  We've all had fritters, crab cakes, calamari, and potstickers -- but if you're going to pay $8/appetizer or $20/entree it better be unique if you're just ordering crabcakes or risotto.
