I ordered the risotto. Very bland, and the rice wasn't cooked all the way-- for $18.  I suppose I got tricked being in Russian Hill and a nice looking restaurant.
author: Kris O.

description: I had to come since I read great reviews on their fried chicken that is available only on Sundays. It's important to get there early to beat the crowd and to make sure they don't run out of the yummy fried chicken. :-) The interior is kind of dark with some art work on the walls and  new country music plays in the background.  I wish they were playing the "Chicken Fried" song by Zac Brown Band because that would be so fitting. The restaurant space is a bit narrow, tight and long. The vibe I get is a hip modern contemporary feel. Friendly servers. When I was served the fried chicken (4 pieces) it was still hot and the meat was very tender and had good flavor. It also came with coleslaw, corn off the cob, mash potatoes with gravy and their moist cornbread. I totally cleaned up my plate and ate everything. Surprisingly I was pretty filled up. Then i saw the dessert menu and the Peanut Butter Ice Cream caught my eye. Now that's something I don't see too often, so I had to order that. That peanut butter ice cream has caramel sauce, whipped cream, peanuts, and a big meringue cookie. The peanut butter flavor was light, but when I ate the ice cream with the peanut, then the full flavor of the peanut butter came out. The Meringue cookie was also pretty light and not too sticky. So everything was pretty delicious.  However,  on a side note, unless you are a bread pudding fan, then I guess you would enjoy the bread pudding. I took a bite of my neighbor's dessert, the bread pudding, but it wasn't too my liking. It was a bit soggy because it soaked up some of the sauce on its plate.
author: Priscilla L.

description: Really small place. I ordered the Sweet Corn Risotto and it was yummy. I also ordered the Cherry Soda drink and that wasn't so good. I wouldn't order that again. The clam appetizer was just okay.
author: Christy P.

description:
I'm so excited to have found this place - how long has it been open???  I've lived on Polk for over three years and just went here about a month ago.  And actually went twice in one week because it was so delicious.  

I geeked out and ordered the same meal both times because it was so great - the big salad.  And trust me, I'm not a "I'll take a side salad as my meal please" kind of girl.  This salad practically had an entire steak sitting on top.  Amazing.

Both visits warranted cocktails.  And although I don't remember exactly what I got - they were fantastic.

Second time around I got the bread pudding for dessert.  It was, as you may have guessed, awesome as well.  I don't have enough great things to say about the place.  I'll definitely become a regular.
author: Julie E.

description:
First time eating here, and oh-my-gosh.

I've been craving a steak for about a month now. So, I picked my boyfriend up and headed to Nob Hill upon the recommendation of a friend. I was mildly skeptical about Street based on the mixed bag of previous reviews.

As we pulled up, there was a parking spot (the famed and feared 'last parking spot in the city') right in front of the door. It was big enough to park 5 Mini Coopers. Thankfully, we were only in one.

The atmosphere was tastefully dark, the artwork was a bit out of place. I think all of the canvasses were depicting Rocking Chairs on a porch. Anyway, we got a table right away and the waitress took our coats for us, a very rare nicety.

The menu was complete for a "American (New)" category, which is hard to come by. I had a cranberry and vodka, super watered down. 

Dinner was perfect. I had a NY Strip, he had a some sort of pasta with sausage. Both were amazing. My steak was large, juicy, tender, and perfectly cooked. The gorgonzola butter is to die for. Literally, if I ate enough, my arteries would clog. At least I'd die happy. Dessert was also amazing (Chocolate cake with vanilla ice cream, a classic done right).

After Yom Kippur (we Jews are supposed to fast for 25 hours), I know where I'm having my first meal.
author: Benjamin B.

description:
The first impression of this place was that it was dark, so dark in fact that one of the 5 of us at our table couldn't read the menu!


Regardless we were able to order,   I had the prime rib, some one got else go the NY strip steak.  The prime rib was decent, it felt though that it had been cut from the rib then fried to be reheated... didn't love the mashed potatoes (and I love mash potatoes).  The NY strip didn't blow my mind either.

We go some dessert that was a sniker doodle type thing, which was too sweet for my liking.  

We didn't hate the food, ate everything but definitely didn't were not blown away by anything and not rushing to go back.
author: ORLA L.

description: The pork and watermelon appetizer was pretty good.  Decently priced food.  I will need to go back when I am not on a diet.
author: Fatty A.

description:
Like Annie S's review, my review unfortunately won't be too complimentary. I came here last night with two friends hoping to do the dine about town special. The first problem (and it was trivial) was that you couldn't make reservations, since the restaurant is first come first serve. No biggie. We arrived at 6:30 and there were tables.

The women who sat us wasn't too friendly or warm, but we got the prime window table with a nice open view of the street. The DAT menu is supposed to encourage you to try a bit of everything so you save money. The most expensive appetizer is $9. The most expensive entree is $25. And the dessert's around $5.75. So even if I chose the most expensive of each, it would be $40 - not much of a savings at $34.95. And then get this: the Angus steak, the dish I came for, was NOT on the DAT menu. I know it says "subject to change" but their DAT website lists their menu as follows:

(Sample Menu (Three-Course Prix Fixe)
Menu items subject to change, contact restaurant directly for their most current Dine About Town menu.

    First Course
    crispy pork belly, warm lentil salad, grain mustard vinaigrette
    or
    souffleed goat cheese custard, mixed lettuces, tapenade crouton

    Second Course
    angus new york strip steak, ancho cress, mountain gorgonzola butter, kennebec fries
    or
    risotto, wild white prawns, red chard, saffron, basil, grana padano, truffle oil

    Third Course
    buttermilk panna cotta, raspberry coulis, toasted almond biscotti
    or
    bread pudding, dates, pecans, bourbon-caramel sauce 

Sigh. So we decided to go with a few drinks, two split appetizers, one soup for me, three entrees and a dessert. The food quality was actually quite good. The linguini with steak was delicious - and should have been an entree. The pork & shrimp wontons with a soy ginger splash was ridiculously overpriced and could have been the $1 (total) wontons at any Chinese restaurant. Charging $7 for that was obscene. The tomato wasn't too creamy - but this was a good thing. Hearty and tasty, the soup was a bit spicy too - something unexpected by enjoyable.

My friends both had the ahi and they liked it. I had the ground sirloin burger with avocado, grilled onions, and gruyere. DAAAAANG. Now THAT was a burger. Lightly grilled bun which turned perfect golden brown, creamy avocado sliced into a nice wedge. Wow. 

The dessert was a peanut butter ice cream that was also outstanding. 

In the end, I paid $50 for a cocktail, my share of appetizers, soup, burger, fries, and ice cream plus tax and tip. Seems like an awful lot, though, doesn't it?
author: Aaron F.

description: had dinner with a colleague. The place is nice but food and drink are surely not better then OK. Maybe it was depending on the dishes we took, however as a restaurant, if you have it on the menu it should be great.
author: C S.

description: I'm not a burger person, but they have a really good hamburger here.  The rest of the menu looks really good, but I was in a thrifty mood so I stuck with the cheapest thing.  The place is nice so save up for a date night and splurge.
author: Corey V.

description: Why Street why?! I really wanted to like you. Don't order a glass of house Cab. It's $13 a glass and tastes like jug vinegar. The calamari was just alright tho our waitress raved about it. The homemade pasta was better but not good enough to bring me back. Harumph.
author: JoAnn P.

description:
Came here the other night with a few of my friends. Heard great things about this place. They only serve the skinless fried chicken on Sundays. Damn it!!! Came all the way over here to try the Chicken and they don't serve it. Is the chicken that special???? Since they don't take reservations, we waited for a little bit. I noticed Nick's crispy tacos was next door. I had to try one of their fish tacos. 

We had two orders of calamari. I like it when they overfill the bowl with calamari falling over the plate. They don't do that here, hence the reason for two orders. I remember when US restaurant and Little Joe's had this order right. Oh well. 

I had a bowl of lobster soup. It's not the best but it's also not the worst. Woodhouse makes a mean chowder. 

Ceasar Salad. It's just your run of the mill salad. 

Tried the steak and it was awesome. Had a taste of the halibut and it was also very good. The gnocchi was a little too doughy for my taste. Overall, it's a great place to dine.
author: jason g.

description: What a gem on Polk St.  My gf and I came and was seated easily around 8:30, but I think we were lucky, because we saw two bigger groups come afterwards and they couldn't be seated.  This place is quite tiny, so make ressies if you can! We shared one entree and two appetizers and it was just perfect.  Their Taglietti Bolognese was AMAZING.  I don't eat out for pasta normally, but it really was amazing... I think I had to keep eating it even though I was stuffed because it was that good.  writing this makes me want to go back actually.  Of course they have mac n cheese was awesome as well, and a side of brussels spouts.  Got nothing to complain about it.  I hope to return to try their pasta with the Dungeness crab!! slurp.  To top it off and make this place five stars is their amazing drink menu.  They have some FUN variety of martinis here. Come here for a yummy meal before you bar  hop away!
author: Stephanie C.

description:
We loved it.  Had three apps and an entree and every one was good and had a distinct personality.  Wine list was moderately strong, but, very reasonably priced.  The space is small and pretty loud.  We had a 7 month old with us and he did fine, but, a jumpy kid would be very unhappy.  A crowd of more than 4 would probably best be served somewhere bigger.  

Great food, really good staff and a low key put together crowd.  Great night.
author: Mark M.

description: I like the paintings and dark red lighting.  Friday night was noisy and crowded, the 3 of us nearly tablemates with some others next to us.  Spicy hummus was yummy.  Kale salad was too light.  Red zinfandel was not as smooth as the $38 price led me to expect.
author: Ethan K.

description:
Fried chicken, fried chicken, fried chicken. 

Tender, juicy, ball-shaped white meat pieces with random bone and cartilage, wonder what part of the bird that is? 

All the fixings too, done right - mashed potato volcano with a brown gravy crater lake, wicked tasty corn off the cob, and a little square of fall apart moist cornbread.  Lobster chowder was definitely above average, and the spinach salad was about 50% thick slab bacon by weight.  Warm toffee cake and ice cream dessert was dense and moist, and had some serious unrefined sugar or molasses going on.

No one element stood out, and I can't put my finger on it, but this is deep down satisfying food that brings a smile and adds up to way more than the sum of its parts, it made me remember that America does have a special cuisine and it's the stuff I ate as a child but didn't think anything about at the time.  Service was attentive and thoughtful, the music was some bayou country stuff, I grew up on this food but it was never this good.
author: Gil S.

description: I read about Street on other Yelp reviews and based on the comments I decided to try it. Everything good that I'd read about it was indeed true - the bartender Monica is an excellent and friendly server, the food is delish, and the atmosphere comfortable and neighboorhood-ish. I sat at the bar to dine (solo) and ended up chatting with a woman next to me who was a local...so nice! The only thing that wasn't ideal was the uncomfortable bar stools (and the fact that there's not alot of leg/knee room if you're trying to sit close enough to the bar to eat). But other than that minor thing, I would highly recommend Street as a perfect place for great food, great service and great ambience.
author: J. G.

description:
Their motto is "Strong Food, Real Drinks". I'm impressed.

The vibe is local San Francisco joint. They do it right: friendly, familial service, sizable bar, modest menu that shines for itself, great wine list.

The cocktails looked damned impressive, though I didn't get a chance to try any. Our server went so far as to bring us a few "tastes" of wines they had by the glass before we picked a bottle, and we ended up with a new discovery.

Our dishes: house-made sausage with gnocchi, linguine alla vongole, and seared ahi with green beans and mashed potatoes. I had a chance to try all three, and they were all really great. The tuna was, perhaps, a bit over-seared, but otherwise, execution was spot-on.

Overall, it's a great spot that serves totally solid food. This has the possibility to become a favorite local hangout.
author: Jim P.

description:
Silly me, I didn't know that, "Freshly Ground Sirloin" meant "We make the most amazing burgers so come on in & have one!"

Wow, this was a damn good burger!  Thick & Juicy, just the way...wait, that starting to sound dirty... let's just say it was DELICIOUS!

Toppings are a la carte so I ordered gruyere cheese and chose to steal the avocado off my date's plate. (didn't even notice - hehe).  It is served with house steak fries that were perfectly salted. Yum!

After looking at the dessert menu, I decided that I have to come back just for dessert.  I already picked out the braeburn apple cake and the bread pudding.  Can't wait!
author: Lauren C.

description: After a perfect sunday afternoon of watching basketball & drinking a couple of beers my date decided he wanted a burger from here. Hearing him talk it up so much, I started craving one too. Thank god there was no wait! The space is dimly lit and there are only about 10 tables. We shared the pork belly appetizer - fatty and delicious. I ordered the burger medium rare & it was perfectly medium rare...for some reason this is hard to get right. I managed to eat the whole thing, it was THAT good. I can usually only eat half a burger in one sitting. Overall, a great dinner & even better company.
author: Sara P.

description:
I am giving 5 stars since I was rather tipsy-so sober maybe 4? 
The food was great- the gnocchi was perfectly cooked and the steak melted in your mouth

I would for sure go back! Maybe next time I will be able to remember it better... ?
author: Janae L.

description: I love this place.  A great little neighborhood spot with excellent food, fun drinks and friendly service.  The fries are to die for, the bolognese is divine and the prime rib is out-of-this world.  My only criticism is that it is often loud and over-crowded.  We once got seated at the window table behind the door and could hardly make it in and out of our seats because the table was so awkwardly placed, but it was a small price to pay for the quality of food that you get.  Definitely one of the best date restaurants in the city, if you ask me.
author: Jessica H.

description:
Was heading over to Tonic to meet some friends, & had my mind set on hitting up Nick's Crispy Tacos...but didn't realize that even though it's TACO TUESDAY...they shut down food service at 8:30p! So...finding ourselves hungry, we decided to just pop into this little cozy lookin' bistro just 2 doors down. 

Service was ok, the waitress forgot one of my friends drink orders and we had to flag down another waitress to bring them over, and the waitress actually asked my friend if she could have one of her twizzlers that my friend brought in!! uh. ok

Seating is very close together, small tables, we had the tall bar table by the side window, great for people watching & good conversations. 

My friend ordered the steak and it was peppery and cooked right to her order.  Steak wasn't that big for $24 though. 

I ordered the mixed greens salad, a great delicious toss of mixed greens,sherry vinagerette, apple slices & candied pecans! yummm & a side order of a bowl of french fries.

The fries were perfect.  Crunchy on the outside, and soft and hot on the inside.  not overdone and definitely not soggy. YUM. $5 a bowl. 

All in all, a good little bistro to grab some food in, but next time i will definitely want to try their burger!! 

They were getting 3 stars, but i added an extra star for the perfectly cooked french fries!!
author: Lulu C.

description: Yum-my!  The Mac and Cheese is a must have with the applewood bacon.  The burger was fresh and tasty!  Glad we found this place. It's cool!
author: Judy H.

description:
Service service service!!! 

I swear to God if I have nothing more to "yelp" to people who own and run restaurants is that people will come back if the food is ok and the service is really polished but they will not come back if the food is great and the service is terrible and during our dinner last night, we experienced some of the worst service we have ever had eating out in San Francisco and it was a quarter full!

  We are both in the industry me as a chef and my wife as a general manager. We decided on a early dinner around 6:30 p.m. The place had about four tables and we were promptly seated. That is where it goes downhill unfortunately. 

  Our server was in her late twenties, thin with long brown hair pulled into a pony tail. As soon as she approached the table we felt the chill that appeared to be from someone who did not want to be there at all that night. No engagement, no real concern about whether or not we wanted another drink or if we even enjoyed our meals. I asked her to "course out" our meals since we were having three appetizers and two entrees. I assumed she knew what we were asking but low and behold, the apps just started flying to our table. 

  I sat with an empty cocktaili glass for over ten minutes and actually flagged down another server to order me a drink because our server seemed pre-occupied by whatever was outside, her friend at the bar and with her busser which just seemed odd. 
  
  What is a true bummer is the food was pretty good except for the soup which I would invite their cooks to my kitchen to give them a course on how to skim fat off the top of their soups because 30% of was chicken fat and not very appealing. The hummus was good if not ordinary, the wontons were very "Chow-ish" and tasty and the fried chicken and sausage and gnocchi were very well done. 

  If we do go back and that's an big "if" we will not have this server again. In fact, my wife gave half of the servers tip to the other server who helped us get through our meal and thanked her for her help.

There was no manager on the floor to discuss this with, no contact email to communicate this to and frankly phone conversations are ineffective so here we are at lovely YELP. I hope the powers that be at STREET read reviews with honest concern and make steps in improving bad service techniques. 

Viola...end of story.
author: Kevin C.

description:
*update12/30/2007* Street was bumped up to five stars.  Why? Tonight I was craving fried chicken and when my dining companion canceled I decided to forgo Farmerbrown and Front Porch and fly solo at Street. Usually I'm all about the burger at Street but since I was already in the fried chicken mood and it was Sunday (chicken night at Street) I knew that that was the way to go. 

And I'm so glad that I did! The chicken was uber-yummy and had all kinds of sides-mashed potatoes with gravy, corn, cole slaw and a slice of cornbread. But the star of the evening was the chicken. Nicely breaded and seasoned perfectly - I thought for sure I'd only eat two of the four pieces but ended up finishing the entire plate.  

And if that's not enough, I had dessert. Home made peanut butter ice cream, with caramel sauce, chocolate, peanuts, home made whipped creme and meringue. This dessert was like heaven on a plate.  Again, I licked the plate clean when I should have stopped after a couple of bites.  

But now I'm left with a dilemma - do I go to Street for one of the best burgers in the city or for some tasty fried chicken? Me thinks more research is needed before I come to a conclusion.



*update 2/11/2007*  I finally had a meal at Street that didn't involve a burger...last night I had a fantastic pork T-Bone served over polenta.  The meal was well worth the hour wait.

*original review*
Tonight I had a cheeseburger at Street-how do I love thee?  Let me count the ways...
Perfectly seasoned meat (yes)
Soft, chewy bun that soaks up the meat juice (yum!)
Ordered medium rare-comes to the table medium rare!
Fries are hot and crispy and salty (I ate every last one of them)
Served with half a pickle and some other pink pickled thingy that was indescribable but yummy.

The Street burger is definitely in my top 3...right behind Slow Club and fighting Balboa Cafe for second place.
author: phil h.

description:
Street is the perfect local, not too fancy, great food, cool atmosphere, great location restaurant. If you're going out in Russian Hill and want a not too expensive great meal before hand ... its a 5 star. 

Oh - and by the way - probably one of the best burgers and fries in the city. And yes - I know those are fight'n words but I stick by my claim. 

They have nightly specials including fried chicken (I think on Sundays) and prime rib for great prices. 

They don't take resos but leave your name and number and grab a cocktail at sketchy (in a good way) Crestas next door. Street has a good bar also but it can be a tight squeeze in the narrow restaurant.
author: Peter C.

description:
Street's owners set out to create the neutron bomb of comfort food menus. The idea was to find the best street foods from all over the world and create a simple, delicious, carbohydrate and  sugar heavy menu of comfort foods that, being international, would avoid the dullness and predictability of a diner, chain restaurant or burger joint*. It turned out people want their comfort food to be mostly familiar so the model changed to focus more on American cuisine, but John and Lynne, the talented and hardworking owners of Street, have achieved their goal. Street offers a warm and filling dinning experience in a friendly but sophisticated and attentive atmosphere.  Their sign promises Strong Food, Real Drinks and they mean it. 

Tables are small, closely packed and often noisy. That makes Street a great place to establish a feeling of intimacy without having to talk too much or work hard. Hello first date, informal work group gathering or neighborhood place to hang with your significant other. Not so much a good place for working dinners, communications heavy third dates or for anyone claustrophobic, or overly noise or privacy sensitive.

Drinks include a range of vodka infusions (fig, apricot, and cranberry are three of my favorites), wonderful mojitos, and a full but reasonably priced wine list. The bartenders are often hot and always know how to rock 'n roll. Name the poison, you won't be disappointed in the dose.

Street french fries have won best in the city, and with good reason. Cooked using  a double fry process (I asked) they are remarkably crisp and flavorful. My wife and I often split a bowl as an appetizer. The fried chicken (Sunday only.. except when they have some on Tuesday, and spring for the extra piece of cornbread) is wonderful, as is the hamburger and the  homemade peanut butter ice cream (they tend to run out so think about ordering at the start of the meal).  If you are in the mood for a light dinner, try splitting an order of the spicy humus and one of spinach salad or mixed greens.

Expect the bill for two to be around $85 with drinks, desert and tip. To avoid the worst of the crowds try to come before 7:00 or after 9:00. No reservations except on Valentines's day but waits of more than 20 minutes are rare, and the full menu is also served at the bar.

I believe that on the good-to-bad scale, nuclear weapons tend to be near the bad side.  But  if real neutron bombs were as comfortable as Street I just might change my mind.




---
*my understanding based on a slightly drunk conversation. I think I'm right, but if  I'm wrong, its still a good story.
author: Bill S.

description:
And I was just eating in the dark...dun, dun, dun, dun, dun...dun, dun, dun, dun, daaa, dun dun dun.

Seriously, this restaurant is so dark, I thought maybe I was wearing my sunglasses at night.  

Other than experiencing what it might be like for a blind person to eat, the burger was pretty good.  Kinda pricey, but tasty.  

I think I need to come back, bring my tripod flashlight and try something else.  The menu options looked appealing.  Can't really judge a restaurant on lighting and burgers alone.
author: Christina S.

description:
Strong food is right. Unyielding would be more accurate. Or, in the eloquent words of my dinner companion, "That shit was hitten!"

I am tempted to say that Street's paella is even more delicious then my dad's. If you had ever tried my dad's paella, you would understand what a monstrous compliment this is. Thank god my dad barely knows how to work a computer because it would break his heart to hear me say it - or read that I had written it, you know what I mean, geez.

The steak comes garnished with a fist size chunk of gorgonzola butter. Given, anything drenched in cheese butter is going to taste delicious, but the meat itself was very good. As for the truffle fries it came with.... Adding truffle oil to anything makes it a winner, this was no different. I'm not even going to get into the magnificence that was the paella in hopes that the mystery of it all will entice you to go experience it for yourself. 

I'm very surprised people complain about the prices; in comparison to the other restaurants in the vicinity it's very reasonable. The only cheap restaurant within a 5 block radius of Street is Andy's - not recommended, UNLESS you are looking for a good excuse to stay home from work the next day... pretttty hard to work with food poisoning.

Go - go now.
author: Taylor E.

description:
Street seems to have a sophistication about it when you look at it from the outside. When you enter this somewhat dimly lit restaurant you see artwork on the wall that seems to work well with their exposed brick walls. Our server was extremely nice and seemed to be there only when needed which is nice. In fact, I didn't notice any staff around at all until I was ready for service of some kind. I like that. 

The appetizers where great. A spinach ravioli and calamari which was done exceptionally well. We chose the Ahi Tuna and the Risotto with Prawns. Both were very nicely prepared though the tuna was slightly more than "seared". This is fine by me though as I'm not afraid of my fish actually being cooked once in awhile. My dining partner also had some great red wine that we both enjoyed very much. 

Overall, a great experience but I do feel that you can get this level of food for a more reasonable price. But, because of a cool atmosphere and good service I'm inclined to stick with 4 stars and I would return to try the strong drinks everyone seems to rave about.
author: Gabriel R.

description:
Ate here for my birthday with a friend because we heard it was good. Got there and got a table. Our waitress was really nice and enthusiastic. I wasn't feeling the atmosphere though. I felt like the look of the inside could have been done a lot better. But once it got dark it seemed to fit.

I forgot what it was called but I ordered this fettuccine pasta with a snow crab and sausage sauce. We had to wait awhile. We even saw people that came in after us get their meals first. When we did finally get our meals, the presentation was lovely. Plump noodles with plenty of crab and sausage. The sauce was full of flavor, and a little spicy. It was also the perfect dinner proportion. This pasta was REALLY good, but I would have like it a lot more if the sauce was white instead of red.

For dessert we ordered the bread pudding. OMG it was to die for! A square of warm pecan bread pudding surrounded by a load of warm caramel sauce. Doesn't that sound like heaven? Because that's exactly what it tastes like.

The only reason why I gave Street 4 stars was because of the sauce, but it was still really delicious and I had a good experience there. I'd definitely go back! Especially for that bread pudding.
author: Michelle M.

description:
After reviewing Phil H's review on Street, I know I need to come here since I LOVE CHEESE BURGERS.  

Fortunately, I came with a group of 4 so I got to sample different dishes.  I made a mistake of ordering my burger well done, and they charcoiled it to black.  Sigh. 

However, the Ahi Tuna, crab cake, and the dumplings were amazing.  I started to drool over my friends plates and they took pity on me and shared.  Now, that's what good friends are for.  :)

PS.  The lighting is on the REALLY dark side.  I know they are trying to create ambiance and etc, but please turn up the light a little so we can read the menu, or have candles on the tables.  Just a suggestion.
author: Gin H.

description:
You would almost miss this resturant because it is narrowly tucked in between a bar and another shop. Once it gets dark the lighting is nice, it gets full quickly and can get a bit loud. This seems like a good place to get a bite to eat and then go on to something else. The spicy hummus is very good, crab cakes not so good, pork chops (my friend said) were very good.  I would go again but was not one of my favorites of all time.
UPDATE:
i have to give a recent update...went back to street and had the burger-delicious! i think this is the best thing on the menu. definitely would recommend this entree.
also i love that you can bring your own bottle of wine here!! definite plus...might have to bring it up to 4 stars from three
author: Jenifer B.

description: This is go-to in our neighborhood. The fried chicken and burgers are great. The restaurant is a bit loud but it's fun and dependable. Street is definitely worth checking out, if you haven't already.
author: Cheyenne C.

description:
After working as a line cook here for more then a year while I was in school, my family and I still love coming back and seeing Chef-Owner John Lampkin slaving away at the end of the hot line.
Everyone raves about the Sunday Night Chicken night, but John has a ton of more dishes in his repertoire that garner a mid-week visit.  His terrines and pates when ever on the menu are a must.  The pork dumpling's are to die for, and the house made sausages and fried calamari are awesome.
And the burger?  Oh  my  god, has to be the best in the City, and that says volumes!  "Strong Food, Real Drinks" - Says it all!
author: Charri F.

description: A perfect day after birthday dinner location, I absolutely fell in love with Polk St as Christmas gets closer, nights get darker and restaurants get cozier. Street is an adorable venue for dates, catching up with friends but NOT for large groups. It's like fitting clowns in midget's car. I mean small people...
author: Stephanie J.

description:
Sitting at the bar at restaurants is great because you have so much more interaction with the staff. It adds an element of fun to your meal. So when I showed up here with my good buddy Manny we decided to take a seat at the bar. We ended up becoming great friends with our bartender/server Amy. Seriously, she rocked from the beginning to the fuzzy end. She dropped good knowledge on the cocktails she made. She also gave us samples of her favorite tequilas (Casadores brand), Armagnac VSOP (a brandy), and some of the house infused cucumber vodka (quite refreshing). We took a shot of the house infused habanero vodka with her which was a great eye opener.

As for the meal itself I'm pleasantly surprised to say it was the best steak I've had in a while. We both had the started with the Asparagus Soup and had the Angus New York Strip Steak with a pat of Mountain Gorgonzola Butter and Kennebec Fries. The steak came out perfectly seared with a medium rare cook. It had all the qualities of a great steak: tender, juicy, and flavorful. The gorgonzola butter was a nice accent to the steak that just put it over the top. Talk about a foodgasm! They certainly live up to their tag line, "Strong Food, Real Drinks."

MUST HAVE: The steak and anything Amy says is good. She's a top notch bartender.
author: Al L.

description:
Delicious burger!  Awesome fries.  I'm sure their other stuff is equally as good, but I've only had their burger as of yet.

It can get pretty crowded in here, so try and make it a little early, but the wait staff is really accommodating, and friendly.

I got the cucumber martini...it had a carrot and a slice of cucumber in it...and was just vodka...so, I wouldn't get that again (my fault for ordering it, because I believe all of that was implied in the description...and, well, I just don't like martinis all that much hehe).

Great place though!
author: Kristin E.

description:
Sometimes having nothing to say at all is a good thing.

Food is good. Service is average. Ambiance is calm and inviting. Menu was normal. Crowd is low key. Not busy, but just the right amount of people to be sat right away, but slower service.

Overall, I had a good experience. Unfortunately it was nothing memorable.

Next time I will try having a few more cocktails to liven the place up a bit, maybe give it a little more spark.   

Cheers!
author: Dee C.

description:
I came here for a late dinner with the beau. We shared the calamari appetizer and an entree of the gnocci pasta. I had a glass of white (not sure which) that was ... mediocre. 

The calamari was very floury, and had not much flavor to it. A bit disappointed, but looked forward to the gnocci.

Possibly the worst gnocci I have ever had. The dumplings were either way overcooked or just made very badly. It sort of melted in my mouth... not good. Service was really awkward. I can't pinpoint why, but I felt pretty uncomfortable at times. 

I've heard a lot of good things about Street's burgers, so maybe we just ordered the wrong things. Regardless, I'm not sure we'd go here again for the food.
author: Cynthia T.

description:
The food here is certainly strong and the drinks are more than real. Order cocktails and share everything so you can experience more than one dish.

Good simple food + good cocktails + a good price = Street.
author: Mark M.

description:
I came for my birthday with my two bestfriends. It was a fairly busy night but we were seated quickly. 

It was loud in the restaurant which was kind of a downside. 

Our food was given in a quick manner but our service was attentive but not anything special.

However the clientele was very friendly. Everyone sang me happy birthday! and they tried to steal my gifts...well only jokingly. 

My steak was cooked medium even though I ordered it medium rare. My friend got the burger it was really really good. The fries were nice but a bit salty.

For dessert...bread pudding. oh man. it wasn't the best ever but bread pudding in general is the best ever.

i don't think i'd go back but it wasn't a bad experience
author: prachi v.

description:
sunday night we cruised on by for some fried chicken dinner. the chicken was good, though i regret not opting for the burger in hindsight but i had a burger that day for lunch.

at first i was shocked at the prices, a bit steep in my opinion.  but you don't just pay for food when you go out to eat, you pay for everything -ambiance, location, the i-ate-there bragging factor, etc.

i wasn't wowed or disappointed by any of the all encompassing factors that make up a night out to eat, a-ok.
author: Ameer N.

description:
I went out to a dinner and a movie last night.  I decided to take my girlfriend to Street last night since all I see is good reviews for it on yelp.  I was not disappointed.  I forgot to get the cross streets for the place and phoned in after our movie and ended up putting my name down for a table before we got there.  When we got there, a small table in the middle of the restaurant was waiting for us.  The hostess nicely pulled out the table so that my gf could get to the seat.  After reading all the reviews, I knew I had to get the burger.  When I was looking at the menu, I started to think about it but I eventually just ordered a burger.  My gf got the steak.  We also ordered drinks and appetizers

I went safe and got a beer while the gf got the "Cherry Soda".  The beer was pretty generous, enough for my Asian tolerance.  The Cherry Soda, however, was probably the most disappointing of the whole Street experience.  It didn't taste like Cherry or er... Soda.  It had no flavor and I ended up drinking it for her while she just ordered a Shirley Temple.

The appetizers were pretty good.  All I got was the cup of clam chowder and it was REAL good, great clam flavor.  My gf got a salad with pecans, cheese and apple slices; very nice.  Then the real food came.  The burger was nice, BIG and JUICY.  I asked for mayo and then ended up getting some ketchup as well.  I didn't get fries because the steak came with fries so I just stole those.  The steak was cooked sorta medium rare but I like it even better like that, and my gf didn't mind.  It tasted very good as well.  The fries were okay... nothing to purposely go to Street for but it did the job.

I would go back for the burger for sure and maybe even the steak some other time.  Thanks Yelp!
author: Chris C.

description: Perhaps I did not order the right thing on the menu, but I was very unimpressed by the food here.  The crab cakes were just odd, and the fries were dry and bland.  3 stars because my drink was pretty good, and the bartender was friendly.
author: Katherine D.

description:
Packed on a Tuesday night, we sat at the bar for dinner. And its a good thing we did since Kelli the bartender was so incredibly sweet and took really good care of us. 
The vibe is lively and the art on the walls is exciting. We started with sharing the dumpling, which were better than any Chinese restaurant dumplings I have had...but I am no expert. 
I had a lovely glass of Cabernet and had the Angus steak which was excellent and satisfied my red meat craving. My partner had the gnocchi and sausage and ate all my fries which he reported were excellent. 
We shared the chocolate cake topped with the peanut butter ice cream and luckily the boy was there to eat most of it and saved me from too much decadence in one night. 
I will come back here. It was great.
author: Nilu r.

description:
I would not go back. Its such a low rating, because it gthink this place is way overrated. 

The food is decent, not good, not great, just O.K. But, definitely not where i would pay 25$ for an entree, even in russian hill.

I'd rather go to Pesce, or Polkers or somethinng.
author: amit s.

description:
If a guy took me here on a date, I'd think he was cool, had good taste and knew how to feed a lady. 

Love the ambiance - casual yet hip and classy
Love the service - cool, calm and knowledgable
Love the food - fresh, creative and pretty solid, love the steak and the risotto was a 4
Love the drinks and wine selection - had a great zin recently, prices are decent
Love that you can walk in on a Friday night - got a table for 4 at around 9 pm

I won't say this place is hands down the best place on the "Street" but it's a solid spot for a satisfying dinner and a few drinks.
author: Deann M.

description:
THE BEST burger in the city!!!!  The cab dropped us off across the street and I had barely noticed the sign.  It is quite sleek inside, very hip.  I love exposed brick, and some interesting art pieces.
I was told to order the burger, and so I did with grilled onions and white cheddar cheese, accompanied with Seghesio Zin, and a bowl of fries.   As I pressed the buns to cut my burger in half, you could see the juices flowin' and the smell of sweet sauteed onions...the first bite...mmm.....mmmm....mmmm  It was huge!!!  I couldn't stop eating the fries as well, and so I had to take my other half-burger home and it was still delicious today.  
Aiden was our server, who was incredibly sweet and took very good care of us.  We got there just in time before last call, but not once did anyone rush us or made us feel like they were shutting down.
Everything was perfect!!!!!!
author: Gemma P.

description:
STREET is the love of my life... well, not really, but love seems to play a role in this cozy restaurant. Table for two, dimmed lights, romantic... (sorta) filled with people, so you know "busy" is good even on a Thursday. I'm usually here for the burgers, $9.50 for just the burger, but if you want to add bacon, cheese and onions it's additional. 
$1.50 for the pork, $1.00 for the cow, $1.00 for the smelly root veggie (roasted onions) about a $14 burger, delicious sirlion, so you have quality beef!! 

Plus my red wine of $9. I love it here... just because it's so close to home.
author: Judi K.

description: Proper burger, tasty watermelon mojitos... this will work. How did I miss them before?
author: Jodie B.

description: A favorite spot for an above average casual meal.  The menu is small and I wish it changed more frequently, but there are several items that are done very well.  Especially good are the kale caesar, gazpacho, pasta Bolognese, and linquine with clams.  I'm afraid to get the fried chicken because several people seem addicted to it.  Shout out to our favorite bartender Monica.  We always try to eat dinner at the bar because she's the best!
author: Teresa N.

description:
The other day, after lauding the tater tot crabcakes at Circa, I became obsessed with the idea of having crabcake for dinner.  "Crrraaaabbbbccaaaakkkkeeee," my empty stomach groaned, so as soon as D got home, I grabbed him and hauled him down the street to, well, Street.

Any place that has crabcakes as an entree is bound to become a favorite with me, especially when they serve it with creamy cole slaw, thick Kennebec fries, and drizzled with spiced mayonnaise-y goodness.  If you're not currently obsessed with crabcakes like me, don't worry - in my experience you really can't go wrong here, especially with the calamari appetizer, or, another favorite, sangria (their version, with a healthy dose of cinnamon, is more than serviceable).  Finger-licking good is pretty much de rigeur at Street.

The staff is nice and unobtrusive and the atmosphere comfortable, though the coolness factor varies according to current art installation.  As someone else mentioned here, it can be rather drafty sitting next to the cement wall, so be prepared to bring a sweater just in case.
author: Tanya N.

description:
mmmm....eh (shrugging shoulders and pursing lips)...

There were aspects of this dining experience that I really enjoyed: the mixed green salad with apples, blue cheese and pecans was thoroughly enjoyable. The Apripolitan cocktail, while it didn't knock my socks off, was unique and tasty. And the decor was really cute with green wood tables, red and green walls and fantastic art adornments. The teeny little purple hanging lamps above the bar were fun as well.

Things that I DIDN'T enjoy included: the meat loaf. Is it suppose to have the texture of cardboard? When cutting my first bite, the edges were so tough that I had to literally saw through it with my knife. Call me crazy but meatloaf should be moist, almost "fluffy" if you will. 

Along with the rock they tried to pass off as meatloaf, the restaurant itself is pretty small and made me feel the tiniest bit claustrophobic. We were lucky enough to get a table that wasn't resting on its neighbor but even still, I felt as though I were pressed against the wall.

As I was walking out I gazed at a table dining on the sausage and potato gnocchi dish. My cheeks suddenly burned with envy that I hadn't ordered that particular entree. Oh, the outrage I felt! Sigh... I'm not sure if I'll make it back to Street but if I do I sure as hell will be trying that.
author: Julia N.

description: One of the few restaurants open 10PM and after. Had the tomato risotto and ahi tuna for dinner -- both were delicious, but the tomato risotto was especially fresh. Chocolate cake for dessert rounded out a great meal.
author: Zelda Z.

description:
The girls and I went to town on the martini menu- as a former bartender/ cocktail waitress I was thrilled and enchanted by the creative flavors and extremely festive garnishes. One of my drinks had large multi colored sugar crystals on the rim! It was confetti in drink form, which made me very happy.

Our food was great, service was OK. I'll definitely be back.

One tip- this place is teeny, and the tables are frickin packed together. Don't bring large men here at peak times. They will not be comfy. And please people, DON'T bring your kid in a stroller. There is no stroller parking!
author: Katie H.

description:
I loved the drinks....the fig martini was great....was not overwhelmingly fruity or articifical tasting but subtle, stiff and totally enjoyable. The food, however, was just bearly alright and uninspiring. It was kind of bland and did not have much depth to its flavor. Really, the price was reasonable enough that I wasn't upset that I was eh about the food, but then I'd rather pay an extra $3-5 elsewhere and get something special and inspriing.

Verdict: I'd go back here for drinks and maybe a couple of appetiers to nibble on at the bar; I would not go back for dinner.
author: Nana N.

description:
Went to Street last night at the recommendation of you Yelpers and it was amazing.  My husband ordered a fig martini which was perfect vodka infused with real figs.  We both wanted to order the burger, but didn't (next time!).  Instead I had the gnocchi with housemade sausage and my husband had the braised pork shoulder.  We shared the roast pumpkin salad to start.  The first bit of gnocchi  was a bit disconcerting - the gnocchi was super delicate and the sauce was sweet, but the sausage was very bold and spicy and they didn't really match.  Both separately were delicious though.  The pork shoulder was tender and very tasty and the pumpkin salad was really delicious.  We've passed this place a dozen times and never been in - I'm so glad we found it!

UPDATE
Went back for the burger and it was delicious!  Ordered it with cheddar and avocado.  Fries were perfectly crispy, thin, and well seasoned.
author: Jen T.

description:
Ah, Street, it was good to see you again last night. The first time I met you, I was really, really drunk, and your delicious martini concoctions only made it worse (or better, depending how you look at it). It was nice how you got me drunk without trying to make any kind of moves on me. I've always appreciated that, Street.

Last night when I saw you I was much more subdued, but you were charming and gracious as always. I was sipping wine rather than guzzling cocktails, and the Pinot Noir was lovely. The asparagus with truffle oil was divine, and I would roll around naked in the goat cheese souffle. I didn't try a dessert, but the Kennebunk fries I stole off my friend's plate were a treat. 

I can't wait to drop by and see you again!
author: Angie R.

description:
I feel pretty dumb because I sat here for five minutes trying to remember what the name of this restaurant was, and I only went there a week ago today. Early Alzheimers? YAY


A friend took me here for a birthday dinner(man Ive really cashed in this year dinner wise) .I had never heard of it before, but my friend she's a chef and always takes me to the best in the bay.I trusted her.

Our meal was excellent . I had some sort of steak dish which is a special occasion type deal nowadays that was cooked to my medium rare perfection,juicey juices flowing ,succulent ....inviting...tender.Where am I going with this?Bottom line it was rad.

We also shared pot stickers =rad
and a beet salad=rad

The house drinks are really delicious as well ,except whatever one we had the glass was lined with these frightening confectionary sprinkles that made me feel like I was at a 7 year olds birthday party.


Single men of San Francisco, you want to score take a lady here, but there are no reservations so get there early bc it gets packed.

Single men of San Francisco, if you want to do me call (415) 438-siiiiiike
author: Lauren V.

description: The dinner went well. The food was fantastic. The service was very good as well. The restaurant was small and cozy, with ambiance.
author: Lisa B.

description:
I always walked by Street on Polk but never thought about actually eating there until my bestie suggested it for a girls night out.

First things first. They have Sofia Minis (champagne in a can), which is one of my newest obsessions. Our waiter was perfect. Always arrived at the right times and was never overbearing. We shared the mixed green salad. I don't like salads, but if it comes with nuts and cheese I'm all in. For dinner I ordered the steak and fries. Super thick juicy steak (with a thick helping of gorganzola butter on top...hello Heaven) and fat french fries were amazing! I only wish I had room for the desserts. Homemade peanut butter ice cream! ....next time for sure.
author: Whitney F.

description:
Talk about urban chic! This restaurant really should be in the East Village in NYC. I love the vibe of the place. Drinks are phenomenal! Mango margaritas, barbie martinis...yes, we went as a big group of girls. The sirloin burger is mouthwatering, the prime rib is perfection. Their entrees are priced around $15-$20. 

The only thing that's keeping this place from scoring 5 stars is the service. It's a small restaurant so don't expect to get seated immediately. It wouldn't be such a problem if their bar area was slightly more spacious. In fact, their bar area is extremely narrow and is coincidentally also the walkway from the kitchen to the tables, so if you don't have a seat at the bar, you end up shifting around the waiters and waitresses until you're seated somewhere. 

But, the plus side is this is a great restaurant right in the middle of the Polk st. bars so you can grab dinner and then rage at the bars like you're back in college.
author: Alisa A.

description: Went for the fried chicken Sunday special and I enjoyed it, though I wish they had an option of buttermilk biscuit vs. cornbread.  It had good flavor and was crispy yet not too heavily-breaded or greasy.  Also had some fancy $9 cocktail drink which was good.  Great mashed potatoes and gravy, good corn.  Cole slaw wasn't that good, though, unless it's just that I don't care for this item in general.   Nice clean bathroom and good soap dispenser.
author: Marc S.

description:
Fig Martini omg!!! One of very few restaurants that actually made me happier by seating us at the bar first.

The space has lots of red in it which I love. It is small which I also love. And finally the thing I love the most is it had great food and great drinks. The bartender was extremely friendly and talked me into the Fig martini (try it, try it, try it). To make things even better the bartender recommended Bar Johnny as an after din spot (great choice).

The food was delicious. I had a great spinach salad and my company had a burger which was said to be one of the best. Bread was also good and the check came to under thirty bucks (excluding our bar drinks which we paid for before sitting down to dinner).
author: Theresa T.

description:
One word, three letters: RAD. This place is rad.

(Yes, I'm trying to bring that word back).

Whenever somebody asks me for dinner recommendations, Street is usually at the top of my list. The place is straight-up dependable: delicious and flavorful food (I recommend the NY strip steak), an awesome vibe and super reasonable prices. Those things in combination with great service make for an overall experience worthy of 5-stars on yelp.

Rad.
author: Christian N.

description:
I am not a fan of Valentines but it so happened that I came here with a lovely lady on the particular Thursday so designated. Twas our third evening out together and I was pretty certain she was an equal non-fan of the whole Valentine euphoria gripping the town.....so I was a tiny bit nervous about the potential for being surrounded by mushy, gushy, lovey doveys the whole night.

Her cab was a tad late so I went in to secure our table. An intimate space, it had a little buzz from the conversations occurring at the surrounding tables...but nothing overpowering, just enough to convey a nice level of energy.

Of course the moment my company for the evening joins me the waitress swings by and greets us with a "Happy Valentines!" To be expected for sure, but I think i stopped breathing momentarily as i heard the words and the expression on the face across from me outwardly reflected my thoughts. 

That moment aside, the rest of the dinner was great. 

She had the New York and I had the Filet. Both pieces of meat were cooked nicely. Her plate was slightly flawed by a stack of overly salty fries. My filet was complimented by some fresh asparagus and a little twice baked potato. 

The atmosphere was nice and comfortable, definitely cozy but I didn't feel crushed by the crowd. The goal of this place is to use fresh, locally grown ingredients to create hearty flavorful comfort food. I wouldn't say the food was stunning but I wasn't disappointed either (aside from the salty fries). Add a bottle of wine and some good company and this place definitely makes for an enjoyable dinner spot.
author: Scott D.

description: What a fantastic little place! We wander up Polk and found this jewel! Start to finish was amazing. Hummus appetizer was great! Kale salad was next, highly recommend! Then the New York strip for the main coarse, perfect! Please make this a stop! Yum, oh and Cheese cake! Yes! The service was top notch!!
author: David W.

description:
Nice cozy atmosphere.....Not too loud..... 
Nice California cuisine.  The mixed green salad and hummus plate was good.  So was the cheesecake.  The descriptions of the drinks were intriguing.  Watch out though..... The margaritas can ignite some interesting conversation!
author: Alli F.

description:
Dear Pope,

While I'm not catholic, I would like to request that you consider the bartender at Street for sainthood.  I'm not entirely sure what the process for going about this is, but I'm sure that you'll agree with me that she deserves it.  This Friday, she shook mango puree with habanero infused vodka over ice, and poured it into a martini glass.  A treat so sublime could only come from divine inspiration.  So you see, you must agree to consider her candidacy.

Furthermore, the food and service at Street is also quite fabulous, so if the Vatican keeps a listing of holy places, please be sure to pencil them in.

Deep Regards,

Amy
author: Amy A.

description:
Three words: Sunday Fried Chicken.  

Now, I'm not normally one to belly up to a greasy plateful of fried goodness, but that's exactly what I've done on a few Sundays at Street.  And I should start by saying that it is actually NOT greasy, but has just the right amount of crunch and juiciness.  Comes with mashed taters and coleslaw.  Definitely order a cocktail because what's fried chicken without a cold alcoholic beverage to wash it down?  Be sure to mark your calendars, though, since the fried chicken meal is only on the menu on Sundays.  

Otherwise, Street is a solid, consistent restaurant.  I've never made reservations, and although the place is always buzzing, the staff has been very accomadating and we've never had to wait very long at all.  I've had a couple fish dishes here that are delicious.  Great variety in the menu from potstickers to lobster risotto (YUM).  The cucumber martini is delish and very refreshing, too!  

The small space is great for an intimate, yet casual date.  Love it!
author: Kathleen B.

description:
I'm having a really hard time with this review. You see, I really enjoyed my meal. I had the prime rib, which was juicy and cooked to perfection. The side of mashed potatoes was likewise delicious, and all in all I had a good experience here. The bottle of Seghesio zinfandel didn't hurt, the atmosphere was warm and mellow, and the service was spot on.

However, my husband and our friend weren't as impressed. They both ordered the sausage with gnocchi, which sounds great, right? It could have been, but the gnocchi was just off. It wasn't the right texture. Granted, gnocchi is hard to do right, but at a restaurant like this, it should have been much better. 

So I am giving this place 3.5 stars, rounded up to 4. If it were my meal that was just okay (instead of my husband's), I would have probably rounded down. The desserts could have also tipped the scale, but while they were pretty good, they were not amazing. Same goes for the pate appetizer. What is making me round up was the overall dollar per unit of meal-pleasure. For a bottle of wine, an appetizer, three entrees, two desserts, and a bottle of wine, we came in at about $110. That's a good reason to round up right there. 

Gosh this is a boring review. At least I realize that I sound like an accountant.
author: Sahra H.

description:
Strong drinks and good food.  Or is it strong food and real drinks?  Not really sure but I am in love.  

As a person that hasn't eaten fried chicken since childhood, I was intrigued by the promise of skin-free, fried poultry.  I'm from the southeast and my 'issues' with fried chicken having skin and bones to negotiate, made me a freakshow amongst my friends and family. Pretty much, if it reminds me of a once living creature, I can't eat it.  As such, I've steered clear of fried chicken for I don't know, oh at least 15 years or so.

The fried chicken at Street is impressive.  I don't know how they get the breading to stick to skinless chicken but they do.  It makes for perfectly fried and perfectly moist chicken. I even ate it off the bone.  That's right.  This chicken caused me to have a gastronomical breakthrough.  I wasn't snapping bones and sucking marrow but I feel a little pleased with myself that I took the leap.  It was the chicken, not me.

Drinks were great.  I had the apripolitan and my friend had the fig martini.  Both were well-proportioned, not too sweet and perfect for sipping throughout dinner.    

Also loved the cornbread.  It was moist and still had chunks of corn kernels mixed into the bready goodness.  We finished off dinner with the apple cake and caramel sauce.  It was delicious and the caramel was homemade buttery yumminess. 

You can't go wrong at Street and I look forward to returning for a sampling of the rest of their menu.  I do love burgers (boneless, skinless and not at all reminiscent of its previous form).  

Oh...and go before 7pm or after 9pm to get a table without having too much of a wait.  Seating is first come basis only.  Drinks start at 5:30pm, dinner at 6:00pm.
author: Corey F.

description: Meh...  Truffle mac & cheese was missing the truffle.  Brussel sprouts weren't bad but below average.  Overcooked shrimp in the linguini.  Burger was good.  Service was good.  Definitely some better options within the immediate area.
author: Garrett N.

description:
I like Street and I like Amy, the bartender who greeted us, helped us get the tables together for our group, and provided us w/great service all night.  

When we came in, around 11ish(?), there was another group there, but they soon left and we were the only ones there. That was fine by me since we had the place to ourselves. I got to finally try the infused vodkas this time and while I liked the sour cherry, I think no more vodkas for me (also had the pineapple which was good, but didn't like the cranberry).  Oh, and I finally learned what elderflower tasted like (kinda lycheeish).   

I had a great time, but maybe too much alcohol, but I'd definitely come back.
author: ML N.

description:
I somehow managed to live a few blocks from Street for a whole year before venturing inside. Maybe it was the dark interior and loud music which put me off (in my old age, I'm getting picky), but boy was I mistaken.

I've been there a few times now, and have always had a good experience. The crab and shrimp cakes are awesome, as is the burger. The house cocktails are good too, and the deserts are to die for.

All in all, a big yum-o.
author: Elizabeth J.

description:
The best burger and fries I've had in San Francisco.  

On second thought, perhaps the best ever.
author: katie m.

description:
Our experience at Street was mixed. At first, I was alone at the bar waiting for my friends to arrive - I was surrounded by the delightful smell of fried chicken and received food recommendations from a very friendly and nice bartender (Sara, I think was her name).  I watched her pour what seemed to be strong drinks with the many different kinds of infused vodka's. I didn't try one though, I was enjoying the Viognier.

Once my friend arrived, we tried the potato and leek soup - it was wonderful, and no cream! I love soups without cream (for health reasons primarily). So far, the experience was top notch. The music was great, there were fun people - oh but the bar stools, my friend and I thought we were going to fall of the barstools!

Once we moved to a table and my third friend arrived, we noticed the chairs were a bit more comfortable but not worthy of a compliment. Our waitress recommended a wonderful red wine; that's about the only thing she did correctly. Our bunless burgers arrived without the cheese we had ordered; the plates promptly returned with half melted cheese on the burgers - the cheese was sweating. It was not appealing, but the beautifully fanned avocado was so I dove in. The burger was good, arrived medium rare as requested. It took the waitress a few reminders to bring onions for my friend, but she continued to eat her burger anyway so that was lame.

My friend who didn't have the bunless burger ordered the dumplings (YUM!) and a caeser salad which I didn't try. I chose to do that by the look on her face. She wasn't pleased.

All in all, I think I would go back and give the spot another try.  I liked the vibe, and an eager to try the infused vodka's. Perhaps I'll bring my man this time around and get his perspective. Perhaps I'll remember my helmet so if I do infact fall off the barstool, my head will be protected.
author: Iliana T.

description:
I am so impressed with this restaurant.  What appears to be more or less of a hole in the wall from the street, is actually very nicely decorated on the indoors.  We were seated right away without a reservation, even though the restaurant seemed crowded.  

I ordered the apple-gorgonzola-pecan salad for a starter, which was amazing, and then the yellow tail tuna for my main course.  I thought it was extremely well put together , perfectly cooked, and tasty.  The main course was a little less than $20, which seemed like a great price for how nice the meal was.  

My date ordered pork loin. Both of our main courses came with perfect mashed potatoes.  

Desert was also fabulous, some sort of apple cake with ice cream.  

Wonderful date spot.  Great wine.  I will definitely be going back again.
author: Lauren M.

description:
NOTE - 4 stars in my book is equivalent to 5 stars. I save one star for consistency, and i've been to Street only once.

So we just happened to be walking by this place last night looking for a bite after a nice show. Since we were too famished to keep looking, we walked in.

There are few pleasures in life that match the feeling of walking into a restaurant by chance, getting a table instantly with attentive service, and being served food that is prepared perfectly, is delectable, and feels like you would not be eating anything else at that moment. And to top it all, spend less that $50 for two. Granted we only had a glass of wine each and split 3 appetizers and a dessert, but i'd take quality over quantity any day. I savored each and every bite, watching the flavors and textures take on colors and sounds like the scene in Ratatouille when Remy explains the joy of enjoying food to his garbage-scarfing brother outside his gourmet restaurant.

Enough said.. try it for yourself. Just for reference, we had the soup (3.5 stars), country pate (5+++ stars), and the pork/shrimp wontons (5 stars) as our appetizers, and the panna cotta (5 stars) as our dessert.
author: Miki N.

description:
I came here after reading great things about their burgers. The only thing the burger has going for it is that the beef is very good. But it tastes like a burger I make in my kitchen with very good beef. Once you add cheese and a side of fries, you're talking $15+. 

Also, it's impossibly dark unless you're at the bar.
author: Max B.

description:
Kristen and I went here tonight for a good night of girl gossip, infused vodkas and amazing food.

We scored on all levels! 

I had the infused cucumber and apricot vodkas...SO GOOD, and to think I was worried I couldnt find good infused vodkas outside of the The Village Cafe in San Jose! 

The food was so good, the lobster corn chower was orgasim worthy, and the sirloin burger was exactly what I wanted, simple, perfectly cooked and topped with gruyere cheese.

Add this place to the laundry list of reason why I am so in love with my neighborhood.
author: Alicia K.

description:
I found Street through Yelp, one of the many restaurants I've tried thus far because of Yelp.  After reading all the rave reviews, I knew I had to make a trip to try the steak and the burger for my bf.

Since reviewers mentioned it could be busy, we called maybe 20 minutes before arriving to put our name on the list.  By the time we got there, there was a table nicely waiting for us.  The hostess was very nice and pulled out the table so I could get in, since all the tables were in a tight spot.

Checked out their drinks menu and decided to get the Cherry Soda, definitely very disappointing, since it didn't taste like what the name indicated.  The beer my bf ordered was nice and generous.

For appetizers, I got a garden salad, which came with fresh greens, gorgonzola cheese, apples, and candied walnuts.  Everything was very well put together, just enough salad to get me started and just the right combinations of flavors for a tangy yet sweet taste.  The clam chowder we got was also very tasty, tasted like clams.

I ordered my steak Medium and it came a little more Medium Rare but that turned out okay since I always anticipate Medium to be cooked more than it should.  The steak was awesome, juicy, and meaty, just the way I like my steak.  The adjacent tables to us all had people enjoying the yummy steaks, so Street must've been doing something right.

We were too stuffed to have dessert, that and I'm just not a huge dessert person, so it's never a must have for me.

Overall, service was good, food was AWESOME and prices were VERY reasonable.  Definitely one of those places we'll be going back to.
author: Winnie L.

description: Can't recommend the delicious innovative cocktails by bartender Amy enough!!! The food is always delicious too. Comfortable atmosphere and outstanding service. Street is a great staple in the 'hood.
author: Anne A.

description: Our favorite local restaurant -- could eat there every night of the week.  And I'd have a hard time not having the burger every time.  Surprising it's not in the discussion more often for best burger in SF.  And to top it off, the owners are just awesome people.
author: Jeremy D.

description:
This place is amazing. The ambiance was perfect, food tasted excellent, and the staff were very friendly and accommodating! 

The heirloom tomato appetizer was my favorite,..

I highly recommend it!
author: Leia V.

description:
Do you like ginger? If so, I have three words for you: house-made ginger ale.

I needed to choose a nicer restaurant on Polk street, as a family friend wanted to take us out to dinner Sunday night. I had heard good things about Street so we ventured there. The four of us walked in around 7pm and seated ourselves at a table right near the front of the restaurant. Nice and dark inside-- just how I like it when I'm tired from a long weekend.

Our waitress couldn't have been nicer. You could tell she just wanted to share in the excitement of the tasty food. As promised, I ordered the house-made ginger ale. We all ordered entrees (I got the pappardelle and the man-friend got the steak) and then our friend ordered two appetizers for everyone to share. 

The fritters were light and fluffy, perfectly done, with little morsels of sweet corn scattered inside. The ranch dressing they were served with wasn't life-changing, but it was a nice cool dressing for the hot fritters. I will probably go back to Street just for those fritters.

The hummus plate was lovely. Chunky, fresh hummus on a platter with a few pita slices, olives, and cherry tomatoes. 

My pappardelle was great. I never order pasta at restaurants-- something about wanting to eat well-cooked meat when I can, because let's be honest, I'm no cook-- but I asked the waitress to recommend something light and tasty. This was the perfect rec! There was a good amount of pasta and fresh tomatoes. Not too heavy, definitely filling, and very fresh-tasting. 

We were all beat so we didn't make room for dessert. Also good to note: Street does not have an espresso machine, so if you're craving an after-dinner pick-me-up, you'll have to settle for coffee. 

A great, local place for an easy, tasty meal. Not the cheapest joint in town, but I would say worth it. (Especially when someone else is paying.) I hear the drinks are outstanding, so take note that I'll be back. And that ginger ale... you have to try their ginger ale.
author: Lauren M.

description:
It was a dark and stormy night.  The two young girls had hailed a beater cab for the rollercoaster ride across town in search of sustenance.  They streaked through the raindrops into the deserted doorway and, exhausted from their travels, slumped onto bar stools, wet and weary.

"Heya ladies, here is our drink menu," the rough, wisened, but smiling bartender said.  

"Can we also see a food menu?" the blond one inquired.

"I think our kitchen is closed for the night," she said with regret.

And thus, their hopes, dreams, and desires of eating at Street were completely dashed and they were forced to go down the street to a pretentious snobby rich person bar and eat less tasty burgers.  

But, they did return to share a bottle of wine and that was worth 4 stars.  

Thanks to the kitchen manager who apologized for not cooking for us when he found out that we were from out of town.  That was a nice gesture.  Next time!
author: Lauren L.

description:
I have been going to street for many years and it has always been consistent.  They have the best hamburger in the city (at least when they do not mess with their Buns! - they changed them once and also had different Cheddar - but seems like they have stitched back).  The other entrees I have tried are also good, but once you have that burger I just cannot want to try any other dish.  

The hostess is great and is always very friendly.  They have a fantastic mojito
author: Dan G.

description:
Update July 2007:

How disappointing! The past two visits have been lackluster. My favorite ahi tuna is no longer my favorite, and, has in fact, been overcooked. Plus the mashed potatoes seemed like they were instant. I have to sadly downgrade a star.

Original:
This used to be one of my favorite restaurants in town... and I've discovered it still is. I love the food here. The ahi tuna is tremendous, perfectly seared every time. The mashed potatoes a divine comfort food and the icing on the cake, the apple braeburn pie with ice cream. One down-side, there is only one Pinot offered by the glass.
author: a p.

description: Came here for dinner with a few friends on a Saturday night. The food was good (I only ordered a salad) but I will go back for the cucumber martini which was AMAZING!
author: Brittan C.

description: They were out of the fried chicken when we showed up at 9:30 so that sucked. Our waitress was awesome though. The food was okay.
author: Christopher R.

description:
Best burger in town -- although they call it ground sirloin... fancy schmancy. Everything else on the menu is super yummy. Love the bread pudding too.

I wish the bar was easier to sit at though. The counter doesn't come out far enough so you really have to lean forward on your stool and sit sideways.
author: Jill S.

description:
It was dinner with the Girls night and I needed to find a new place to go or rather a new neighborhood to explore. (I've been a little underwhelmed with North Beach, SOMA, and the Mission lately). So when someone suggested I check out Russian Hill it was off to a great start already.

On to what you really want to know about Street. 

Atmosphere:
Cozy little space perfect for "small" groups (there were only 3 of us) dimly lit with a cute little bar towards the back of the restaurant. The decor itself is pretty nondescript kinda modern artwork Scandinavian style tables. 

Service:
Kick ass bartender. The wine list was a little short but the cocktails looked really unique. Waitress was extremely accommodating as I dropped my fork not once but twice and smiled the whole time even when we had paid our bill and continued to gab for another 20 mins without buying any more drinks or food. Surprisingly there wasn't a wait when we arrived at 8pm on a Sat night and got a table right in the window up front.

Food:
The best part of the whole review. For an appetizer I ordered the goat cheese souffle split between the 3 of us was a tantalizing start to the meal.  Followed by the yellow fin tuna grilled just enough on the outside the flavor was delish. There was a side of creamy mashed potatoes and green beans that were equally yummy. The finale was of course the lemon cheesecake which if you are a cheesecake lover like myself was pretty damn good. I only wish I had it all to myself but girls dinner out wouldn't be complete without "splitting" a desert.

I foresee myself dragging all of my friends back to this restaurant again very soon!
author: julie r.

description:
This is a cool looking place.  Really small and narrow but they find a way to fit the tables in.  A few of us got to Street early so we grabbed some drinks at the bar.  The host, bartender and waitress were so great and nice.  We were all finally seated and ordered our foot.  I went with the crab and shrimp cakes and it was good.  Unfortunately I felt really sick afterwards so I'm a little skeptic to give it high praise.  My roommate said her burger may have been the best burger she has ever had.  Maybe I'll try that next time.

I was going to give this place 3 stars, but the waitress and host gives it a +1.  She was slightly slow and clueless really really nice!  We were celebrating a friend's bday and she came out with the cheese cake but my friend was in the bathroom!  She had to hide the cake, wait until my friend came back and then re-lit the candle.  After writing that just now, it doesn't sound so special, but the effort was very cool.  Also, while we were leaving the host waved good-bye to us from the back room and when we exited she came out to thank us for coming in.

Very nice people.  I'll come back just for that....and to try this burger...
author: Tom Y.

description:
The highlight of the meal (other than the babe across from me) was the heirloom organic tomatoes.  Yummmm.  But therein lies the problem.  The rest of the meal went downhill.  I had a kamikaze on the rocks which seemed to have no lime juice...essentially a straight shot of vodka and triple sec.  Too strong for my delicate throat.  For dinner, I had the grilled chicken breast (I know, I know, it's chicken) with "chilled" garlic noodles and peanut-lime sauce.  Basically it was a chinese chicken salad.  Partner had the Ahi which was ok, but as a huge fish fan, I was unimpressed.  Dessert consisted of a shared bread pudding - equally uninspiring.  Try Mazze's on Lakeshore in Oakland for a superior bread pudding.  

The restaurant is cute and the tables and lighting make for a nice setting...but it was really noisy.  Plus, my dp had an unpleasant encounter with the staff at the end...not her fault at all.  By all accounts, the employee acted like a complete ass.

A generous two stars.
author: Gregg O.

description: We came here for a friend's birthday and had a great seat looking out the window on Polk.  I had the caesar salad and macaroni and cheese.  The salad was fresh and god.  The macaroni and cheese (with Bacon!!) was such a great comfort deliciousness on a cold night.  My sister had the pasta with crab and sausage and it was delicious.  I like that the restaurant is chill and was a great place to enjoy a friend's birthday and actually be able to hear people.
author: Arica V.

description:
I ate at Street a couple weeks ago with some girlfriends and thought the food (calamari, heirloom tomato salad, and a pasta dish) was pretty good, but a little overpriced. 

A week later, I noticed my credit card had been overcharged by almost twice the amount it should have been. I contacted Street and very nicely explained the situation. I work in marketing & customer service in the food & wine industry myself and know how exhausting it is to deal with complaints.

While Street did finally credit my card (a week and a half after originally calling), it took me about four calls and faxing in my original receipt. They were apologetic on the phone, but I felt like it took WAY too long to credit my card and there was nothing else offered to win my business back--no free drink, appetizer, etc. At other restaurants, I've gotten free champagne or a free bottle of wine when the wait was too long!

As I live right around the corner, this could have been one of my go-to spots. However, the mistake and lack of effort to win my business back means that I will not be returning there. Perhaps it would have been more effective to be rude and demanding on the phone instead of nice and understanding?
author: Amanda B.

description:
The dinner that almost didn't happen but I am so glad it did:

Our evening began with a 45-minute vulture circle of the carrion, that carrion being a parking spot anywhere near the vicinity of where we were dining.  The magical little destination, Street, looked busier and busier with every passing-by of their window as we grew weary and hungry.   We were pretty sure we would not be able to get in, or if we did, it would be a looonng wait. It WAS Saturday night and we were on minute 44 of the hunt.  It was not a good sitch in the car with three Starvin Marvins dying for a drink.

"OK, that's it, I've had it, we're going somewhere else!" grunts my dining partner (and chauffeur).
