He's getting to that point where your stomach is indeed eating itself, and if you don't get somethin' up in there, all around will suffer dire consequences i.e. a fierce round of BK Tenders in the car pre-dine.  Our visiting guest agrees.  He, too, is losing stomach lining by the moment and cannot bear it any longer. 

"How about one more time around the block while I bust my Zen vibes and get us a spot in front?" I quip, though it didn't really seem funny to either of the guys.  I really, really, REALLY wanted to eat here and I wasn't afraid to whine.

I muster up my very best inner Om for some good karma to come my way in a large installment, when all of a sudden, we come upon THE spot, the one right in front of Street! It practically glowed.

Aside from the fact that I appeared heka-on-top-of-heka psychic and cool, everyone was glad to just have made it after almost sacrificing the best cut of asphalt up to indecision.

Street was packed.  Super packed.  I noticed an exquisite spot in a nook by the front door that faced the street and fervently wished for it to be ours.  The peeps already sitting there were almost done, I could tell.   I mentioned to the hostess that we would love to have the window table (which I'm sure she hears about a hundred times a night), and she sweetly told me there were 2 other parties ahead of us but that she would try.  

I was happy with the parking luck, and didn't want to push it, but somehow the karma continued as three seats in a row were open at the end of the bar.  If there were placecards with our names on them, I decided it would be creepy and we would have to leave, however, the only thing waiting for us at the bar was a really friendly bartender who suggested the Apricotini. 
It was perhaps one of the most delicious infused vodkas I have ever enjoyed, and it came out of a real-deal giant jar of apricot goodness.  She was totally slammed but made us feel welcome, chatted with us a little, and did her job very, very well.  Big props to her for not putting on the "weary tendress" mask, which you see in any busy bar.  Her night was hellish by all outward appearances,  but she had a great attitude and was enjoying her evening.

Right after we had a few sips of our drink, sweet hostess lady comes over, again, I think there was a halo of sorts, telling us to come with her.

And guess where she takes us?  The window seat, the spot we wanted and even obnoxiously requested.  Fate had worked for us, as the folks there before us were "loungers" -the service industry's most dreaded patron, he who practically camps tableside.  The ones with the "Type Stay" personality (heh heh I just made that up).  And we were the beneficiaries...yessss!

The food, wonderful.  Our hummus app was delicious, but for the price, very disappointing portion-wise.  A half-star deduction for that.  

Main?  I had the gnocchi dish, which the chef happily prepared for me sans saucisses.  Our server brought them out on a separate plate before the meal and my BF enjoyed them as an app- very nice.  The gnocchi were like perfect pillows of carbaholic pleasure, potato-ey but fluffy.  I could have eaten another bowl of it, but who wants to be the only one at the table having seconds?  I decided to have another Apricotini instead.

Street was great, but quite noisy.  We were in the only seat in the house offering a noise buffer to the extreme talky-talky in there.  It's like everyone just won the lotto, graduated, had a baby, and became a grandma all at once and they are all squealing about it.  And they can't stop.  I have never heard more bird-like laughs and Chatty Cathys in one room in my life, so trying to have a date here would not work out unless it was the last one before a break up.  A great place to exit ceremoniously from; the crying or wailing would probably not be heard by anyone.

Ride your tricycle or Segway.  Parking's a biotch unless you have gratuitous cosmic blessings coming to you.
author: Lea N.

description:
Went to Street last week with my girlfriend and had a great dinner.  The staff was friendly, the atmosphere was chic and the food was great.  I went with the gnocchi and sausage and was surprised by the portion size.  Usually when I order gnocchi with sausage there are a few sliced pieces of sausage mixed into the sauce but at Street I was pleasantly surprised to receive two whole Italian sausages.  My girlfriend had the steak which she enjoyed.  Nothing spectacular but a pretty decent steak for the price.

All in all a great experience and not too expensive.  I will definitely be back.
author: Michael R.

description:
Good comfort food- the weekly Fried Chicken is delicious as it has a really flaky buttermilk crust.  I liked the soup I had there as well.  I got a cocktail but didn't like it that much.  My friends' food was good but not great.

I felt the tables were a bit tight and was a little bit uncomfortable.  If I lived in RH, I'd come here often (especially given the reasonable prices) but I didn't love it enough to make a crosstown trek.
author: Jeff A.

description: Fried chicken on Sunday was great.  They don't claim to have the best fried chicken or its their specialty like others and the others suck.  and the dumpling had a very oriental style and taste, which was fabulous.
author: Kevin L.

description: My boyfriend and I went here for dinner on a Tuesday night.  The place was only half full, but it took a good 45 minutes to get our dinner (fried chicken).  When we asked the waitress nicely if our order had been lost, she seemed very annoyed.  Each plate had 3 perfectly formed triangles (unusual for fried chicken), and it was the driest most bland fried chicken I have ever tasted.  We were both very hungry and yet only ate half.  We left with a $66 tab (including $10 tip), and both said that it was the worse fried chicken either of us had ever tasted.  Total rip off for what we were served.
author: Scott B.

description:
Delicious first visit. I had the risotto and it was very good.  Mushrooms would have been a GREAT addition, but I didnt want to sound like a know-it-all so I just ate it without.

My friend had the fried chicken which was supposedly the special. Some people called ahead to 'reserve' some and others were left without when they ran out. It did look and smell good but I did not try any.

Definitely tasty and service was good.
author: Ashley S.

description:
I wavered here between 3 stars and 4.  I think in my mind, there's a big gap between those two ratings.  Like in surveys, on a scale of 1 to 5, 1 being you abso-freaking-lutely agree and 5 being hell-no-no-way disagree, 3 would just be essentially "I really have no opinion because it never occurred to me that this survey question even mattered at all to my life."  So if the place didn't annoy me or blow me away, I often settle at 3 stars.  So did Street deserve me coming out of my deliciously comfortable ambivalence?  Hmmm ... (ambivalently attempting to ponder ...)

Had hummus for appetizer which was really yummy.  Literally - those were the words the waiter used to describe it.  He was like "Oh yes, that's really yummy."  And we were like - did you just say really yummy?  But that's just the feel of street.  It had a nice casualness.  No reservations, small place.  Lots of windows opening onto the street.  So yes - it's 4 stars worth when it comes to feel ... however when it comes to food ...

For an entree, I thought I was going to get their famed hamburger.  I hadn't even really heard of it yet, but I saw the waiters bring out like 6 of them in the 20 minutes that we were waiting for a table.  Figured it was the thing to order.  But no, I decided on the duck - just to see how creative street could be.  It was kinda chewy, seasoned ok - basically typical californian cuisine.  So yeah, not very creative.  This is what drug me back to ambivalence, I guess.

Sigh ... I love california, but I always want my food to have a little more attitude.  What essentially equates in my mind to healthy-ish comfort-ish food just doesn't blow my mind.  But maybe that's just me a now in my life.
author: Audrey T.

description:
I always liked Street in the past 5 times I have eaten there, until last night.  Our dinner for three was fine, we had dessert and ordered one drink each.  We paid, but apparently weren't finishing our drinks and conversation quick enough when the hostess/manager interrupted and asked if we wouldn't mind to move our conversation to the bar to make room for a large party.  This was 5 minutes after we paid, during which the hostess never ceased staring us down.  The real kicker is that the place wasn't crowded and there were others leaving soon.  Also, their "large party" was four people.  

I hope they read this and understand they have lost a repeat customer.
author: Casey K.

description: The food and dessert were amazing! I had the steak salad and it was perfect! I have yet to try the fried chicken. It was not on the menu when I ate here but will keep checking back for it. The peanut butter ice cream was delicious as well! Ambience was a little dark. I will definitely be returning here! Service was great as well!
author: Jenine D.

description:
"Hey, I've always wanted to try this place! They have fried chicken!!" is something I have said more than once, during one of my many strolls down Polk. Luckily my girlfriends said they also wanted to try it, and so began our awesome dining experience. 

There was a bit of a delay when we arrived for our reservation, so we ordered some drinks and hung out for a bit near the bar area. One of the (I'm guessing) managers or owners sent us a bowl of their amazing kennebec fries with parmesan cheese sprinkled all over. Delicious, and I might even dare to say some of the best fries I've ever had. Plus it was so nice of the staff to realize that we were going to be waiting for a little bit longer than expected! 

For my main entree, I of course had the fried chicken. It was great, and I loved that the sides were corn, mashed potatoes and cole slaw - simple and unpretentious. I just don't get it when places try to make fried chicken all fancy and something that it's really not. 

The desserts were equally fantastic. We tried the bread pudding, homemade peanut butter ice cream and warm chocolate cake. All of them were to-die-for, and only $5.25 each. Since I am a sucker for sweet and salty combinations, I think I may have to come back here for a huge bowl of fries and all of their desserts. 

Oh and it's also worth noting that this seems like the perfect date restaurant. It's slightly upscale, definitely down to earth and very romantic.
author: lindsay w.

description: This place was awful. My friend recently moved to the neighborhood and after helping her unpack we went walking down polk for a quick bite. She is a vegetarian and while they had some options she chose the Veggie risotto, the zucchini tasted old, like it had been in the refrigerator too long. I had a soup and salad, the chick pea soup tasted like it was from a can and the Caesar had no flavor, no garlic, no anchovy no Parmesan. Will Not Be Going Back!
author: Ginevra A.

description:
Chatter Boxes Galore!  Not that I'm not one myself, but the tables are WAY too close to each other, I found myself unwillingly eavesdropping.  My friend and I were literally shouting at each other..."HOW WAS YOUR DAY?"," IT WAS GREAT, AND YOURS?"  Not so fun...

The restaurant has great ambiance though, very small but warmly decorative.  Artsy but not overdone.  Service was superb, a nice hidden gem on Polk St fo sho!
author: Wendy H.

description:
Tucked next to Peet's, I walked by this place so many times without even realizing a restaurant was there. I've been here a few times and have always had a great meal until this week... Street is known for their burgers and steak. The gorgonzola butter that comes with the steak is so good you'll want to dip everything in it - no joke. I was dipping my fries, steak, calamari, everything into this butter. I almost asked if I could get a little to go! I didn't get the butter this last time and maybe that's why the meal wasn't as tasty as I remembered...or maybe it was just the lousy company. 

Wine list is mediocre - would recommend bringing your own bottle. They don't take reservations and aren't open on Mondays so get there early to score a table before it's too busy.
author: Josephine H.

description:
Have you ever had a dish that literally made you jump in your seat? Where your first instinct is to scoop another heaping spoonful and surround it with your mouth to let all the flavors make it happy? 

The risotto!!! Yea, it does that to me. It does so well in capturing the wonderful flavors of the sea that it makes very seafood lover want to sing. The shrimp and chard were perfect additions and the melty cheese was just the right consistency of smooth, not too rich and not too creamy. I couldn't fight the urge to keep dunking my spoon in for more. It was perfection while it lasted. Poor Kygia B...

The Spinach Salad, Calamari, and the Strip Steak we ordered were all definitely worth getting. The soufleed goat cheese custard was nice, but no one really cared for it, and the crab cakes were decent, but the gnocchi didn't do much for me. 

Service was on point. They had our table ready in the 30min that they quoted. Our server was super friendly and we joked back and forth that small girls really CAN eat. 

I definitely will go back for more risotto. And next time I'll order my own. Thanks Kygia B. for surrendering half of your dinner.
author: Deanna T.

description:
This is my favorite restaurant in SF!  Really friendly, reasonably priced, and the food is amazing!  Best burger I've had in SF (get it with the heirloom tomatoes if they are in season).  

My biggest problem with going to Street is that I can never decide what to order b/c everything is soooooo good!!  I recommend sharing and you may even want to get an extra entree to make the decision process easier.  Srsly!  I don't think there is anything on the menu that isn't amazing.  

One minor downside is that they don't take reservations, but the bar staff is really friendly and if you have a big group, they will usually make an exception.
author: Chris J.

description: That IS a tasty burger!  THE best burger I have had.  Can't help myself from ordering it as takeout on average once per week... Do yourself a favor, give it a shot.  Only drawback is that they don't open until the evening, would love to be able to order this for Sunday football afternoons.
author: Mitchell F.

description:
Street is another one that falls by the wayside because I am lazy and rely on opentable.  (At this point, why is any restaurant in SF not on there!)  =)

I must say it really exceeded expectations, and that is saying something because most people have glowing things to say about it.  

Though we waited forever for a table, it was worth it.  The Sausage and Gnocchi I had was really something special.  The crab cakes were also pretty great, and the bite of burger I got to sample was on point.  

Once finally seated, the service was great.  The place has a great lively atmosphere.  I will definitely come back and highly recommended if you haven't been.
author: Andrew M.

description:
Met the owner . Wow. He totally reminded me of my really cool awesome Dad.  

5 stars not only for the really nice, cool owner, but the friendly, down to earth staff and the awesome Yellowfin Tuna and the MEYER LEMON CHEESECAKE.  You must try this if nothing else.
author: Victoria M.

description:
Went there for Dine-About-Town and was kind of disappointed.   Usually, Dine-About-Town includes an appetizer, entree, and dessert for $35.  It doesn't make much sense because most appetizers were about $7-$9, entres were under $20, and dessert is $6.  As you can see you're not saving much.  

We chose the place to try out the chicken, but they ran out of the fried chicken.  The calamari was bland, french fries were good, and hummus was good.  The portions are not that big.  

The only great thing were the desserts.  Lemon cheesecake was delish, bread pudding was soft and creamy, and the chocolate cake was to die for.

The service was very good!
author: Annie S.

description:
I am in love with this restaurant! 

I have eaten here on several occassions and it is consistently delicious! I have taken my friends and family there and they love it too! 

The prime rib rocks!

The service is great and the restaurant has a cool neighborhood vibe. I absolutely recommend this place.
author: Alex M.

description: Great place on Polk. Fun ambiance and good food.
author: Lacy T.

description: We have been trying to get to this place forever and after four tries, SuCCeSS!! Non-existent street parking is difficult if not impossible by the time Street opens (6pm) and driving around three times, we saw four spots open up, and instantly taken in the duration of a heartbeat! I ordered the Ahi medium rare with mashed potatoes (very flavorful and tasty) while sis ordered a hamburger with fries (great and crunchy though mixed with water from the small salad on same plate). We were the first ones into the restaurant but within minutes, the bar and dining area (one and the same) were half-filled. A dark place with paintings displayed on one side of the walls, a very cozy place and possibly romantic if not with your big sister (as in my case). Lousy street parking but otherwise, I will return...  I liked the food and mood of the place! Very dark - bring a flashlight!
author: Tony L.

description:
Street is really unimpressive for a lot of reasons. The main reason though is the menu. 
+ Weak house cocktail list that almost entirely consists of flavored liquors with a splash of something. You really can't get away with that in SF. The wine list is okay and the beer list is semi-respectable, but could be found anywhere. 
+ The food is just unimpressive. I've heard raves about the fried chicken... it was terrible. The seasoning in the batter was way off (too spicy and there was a funky aftertaste that had nothing to do with the buttermilk) and it was overcooked. The side dish pairings with the fried chicken were also way too carb heavy... mashed potatoes w/gravy, corn, coleslaw and for an extra $1.50, a piece of cornbread. They should lose the corn and coleslaw and add some greens. (No one in the South where buttermilk fried chicken was invented would ever serve cole slaw with it). We've had other dishes here in the past that were equally unimpressive, but since the fried chicken is somewhat of a specialty, I thought it was worth a full description.

There are some other problems with Street as well...
+ Seems to be understaffed for dinner service so it takes forever to place your order and once you do, your food comes out 3 minutes after your drinks. 
+ The service attitude is cold bordering on pretentious by both the waitstaff and the bartenders, which is odd considering the name and general theme of the restaurant. 
+ Not a good value. Given the quality of the food/menu and the service, Street is about 25% too high.
author: Emily C.

description: Awesome food, cute trendy place (if you don't mind eating in the dark). We waited 30 min or so before we got seated but drinks at the bar were super exciting.
author: Debbie C.

description:
God help you if you are a vegetarian who does not like risotto....there are basically no other entree choices for you. However, if you like meat or fish, you will have plenty of options here. 

I really debated whether or not to give this place 3 or 4 stars and finally decided that I had to go with three stars. Mainly because:
1. The aforementioned lack of veggie options -- yes there are a few veggie appetizers but some humus and a Caesar salad are not what I generally want for dinner
2. the food is frequently on the salty side
3. They don't take reservations. Now to be fairs, this really isn't a problem during the week or even late, but if you want to eat hear at 8 on a Saturday, you will probably be waiting for a while.

That said, they DO serve late (a plus in my book) and they have a lot of yummy appetizers... those two things alone ALMOST push Street to four stars.
author: Rebecca H.

description: What a great find! We got there early so getting a table was no problem at all. The staff was friendly and accommodating and for me that is just as important as the food. We had the fired calamari, the burger, and steak and everything was delicious!
author: A D.

description: I want to love this place.  It has the vibe.  The amazing staff.  The happy buzz.  But 3 times of trying the cocktails and not enjoying them is having given it a chance too many.
author: Ash A.

description:
They have Kennebec fries.  When I'm at the market, I have potato choices of Yukon, Russet, Fingerling, Red Pontiac etc.  You don't get that many choices with french fries.  So, high five to Street for giving me Kennebec fries.  

It's a little cramped in here.  If you can get the four seater bar table in the front of the restaurant, you won!  This is also a sit at bar alone and still be comfortable restaurant.
author: Wakako U.

description:
I came here for dinner with two of my dearest friends from high school and we had the best time! For a Thursday night, I thought this place was perfect! It was a casual setting with a great vibe and excellent food and service!

We started off with the spinach, goat cheese and beet salad and flash fried calamari. The calamari was delicious. Deep fried with the perfect amount of batter and the thai dipping sauce was a great compliment. 

I had the Hawaiian ahi tuna for my entree. The fish was seared just right and the sauce drizzled on top gave it the extra kick that it needed. It was acompanied with a side of fresh green beans and buttery mashed potatoes. I had a bite of my friend's NY steak and it was moist and juicy. I was very envious. My other friend had the crab cakes with kennebec fries.. mmmmmm... they were delicious too.

Between the three of us, we share the breading pudding and chocolate cake for dessert. I have to be honest, as a bread pudding lover, Street is not the best place too order this dessert. I was actually quite disappointed. A fellow yelper actually recommended me to come here just for this dessert, so I had HIGH expectations for it... It was definitely TOO mushy for me! But bread pudding is so subjective. I like my bread pudding mushy AND crispy on the outside, but my friend who loves his mushy was loving every bite. On the other hand the chocolate cake was yummy. It was very dense and rich in chocolate flavor. The vanilla ice cream really made it taste even better.

Overall, despite the disappointing bread pudding, I loved everything else.
author: Denise L.

description: For some reason I thought this place was going to be divey. But it turned out to be rather fancy. I don't like how the place is really dark. I could hardly make out my food. But it tasted good. We shared the Risotto dish and the other pasta dish. Both were tasty but neither blew my mind. I would come back for some comfort food. I think I'm supposed to come back to try their excellent burger. Just wasn't in the mood for a burger that night.
author: Kathleen T.

description: This place is okay. Came here & had truffle mac n cheese with bacon and the fried chicken. The truffle mac n cheese was really good with a lot of flavor but not as thick and cheesy as I like. The fried chicken came with cole slaw, mashed potatoes & gravy, corn kernels, and corn bread (which I didn't order but was charged for. Pointed it out to the waitress after our meal since she didn't check on us even once while eating and she took it off the bill). The fried chicken was good but nothing I would ever go out of my way for. Nothing else on the plate was worth writing about. My boyfriend commented that you could get all those things at KFC and it's what KFC would taste like if they made all their food fresh ha. Overall, everything was just okay. Prices kinda high to be this underwhelmed.
author: Lele L.

description:
The four stars is mainly for the atmosphere because the food is average at best.  We specifically came here tonight as we've both been craving fried chicken.  I was disappointed.  The cornbread was it's saving grace, but of course, it was on my sweetie's plate and not mine (I declined to order it thinking I'd save a few calories.  What was I thinking.).  Our server tonight also could have used a little more personality...or she just didn't like us from the get go.  

On previous visits we've had the crabcakes and the sicilian sausage and they were just, eh.  But we keep coming back.  It's just so darn dark and inviting in there.  Best bet is to sit at the bar.  Also, I noticed it's a nice place for dining alone.
author: Lisa C.

description:
Absolutely delicious. 

My boyfriend's parents were in town from Seattle and I was frantically making reservations for a Friday evening dinner at 6:30pm at the last minute. Unfortunately all of my choice restaurants were booked up, but I found a table for Yabbie's down on Polk. 

I had been wanting to try Street for a long time now. I figured that we would walk down and see if there was a table available at Street (since they do not take reservations) and cancel our reservation at Yabbie's. If not, then we'd fall back on our original plan and take our reservation. 

Luckily, we had just beat the dinner rush and were seated right away at the high table by the window in Street. BF walked down and cancelled our reservation at Yabbie's (they were so nice that we'll definitely try it sometime). It was VERY dimly lit, but boyfriend's mom loved that we were in a quiet(er) part of the the restaurant and by the window so we could people watch . The food was fantastic, BF's mom and I both had crab cakes, BF's dad had sausage and BF had Prime Rib. Service was OK, but the food made up for it. 

I was SO happy that Street did not disappoint! 

I definitely recommend the calamari and possibly a flashlight. We were literally using the street lamp outside our window to see our menus.
author: Tien H.

description:
STREET is one of my new favorite spots to go to for dinner.  This was my first time.  I wasn't expecting much but when I left, I couldn't stop talking about it.  I went with two other friends who were really impressed as well.  We got there a little early and was happy to see that they have a bar.  

Appetizers: We ordered the calamari which was lightly deep fried and tasted really fresh.  The size of the appetizer was good for three persons.  We really loved this one.

Main Courses: I ordered John's sicilian sausage which was very tender and tasty.  The gnocchi and cheese complimented the sausage very well.  I could have this again.  The portion is perfect.

My friends ordered the grilled hawaiian ahi and freshly ground sirloin (medium).  We tried each other's food.  The ahi was so flavorful that I could still taste it after a few minutes.  It was fresh, tender and seasoned well.  The freshly ground sirloin was delicious.   It just melted in your mouth.  Will get this the next time I go.

Dessert: We split the Warm bittersweet chocolate cake with vanilla ice cream.  Woo hoo!  Such a good cake especially you eat together with the vanilla ice cream.  I could eat this anytime being a chocolate fan. 

Our waiter was funny and great.  Always on top of filling our waters, getting our drinks and asking if everything was okay!  The ambiance was nice.  Many people talking and enjoying themselves!

Will definitely come back!!!  = )
author: R R.

description:
Here's how I ended up finally eating here.  I heard about this place from a couple friends, and heard it was also the same people who started Utah in SOMA.  Then I met this guy, he asked me out on a date, and next thing I knew he pulled up to Street.  I was more excited about trying the food than going on a date with him.

Long story short, the date was fine, but the food was incredible!  Our waiter rocked, and never made us feel rushed even though space is a commodity in this restaurant.  I am not a risotto person, but it was so yum that I would try anything they make.  Love it and can't wait to have another first date here.
author: Lulu B.

description:
One of the best burgers in town.  Every neighborhood needs a place like this.

This place balances the line between trendy and accessible.  They do comfort food correctly.  The wine list is approachable, and their burger (ground sirloin, soooo tasty) is world class.
author: Andrew C.

description:
I'm going just agree with most people, so I'll make it quick.  

1.  Burger is great.  Tops I've had in the city

2.  Fried Chix on Sunday night = tasty (a must have)

3.  Staff is inviting and friendly.

4.  A must visit.
author: Tom C.

description:
Saturday night was my second visit to Street. My best friend and I like to meet there because its about halfway between my place in Nob Hill and hers in the Marina. Its also a little more upscale without being snobby. The food is also pretty tasty and the wine list is decent. 

But the real disappointment...and the reason for giving it three stars instead of four, is because the waitress was awful. The place was busy, but not packed. And she had four tables in her care, including ours. Apparently that meant that she could take her time taking our order and even longer to get our bill to us. Sigh.
author: Jenn G.

description:
Cute place with very friendly people working there, esp. at the bar.  We had the pate platter, burger and risotto and our entrees were totally salty!  We even said light on the salt cuz my friend had been there before and warned me that the food is on the salty side.  I'm scared to think what it would have been like if we didn't say "light on the salt"!?  There were a few bites that weren't as salty and the food was good & flavorful...if only the whole dish were like that.

But, I do like this neighborhood place, it's got a good vibe.  I will try it one more time and hopefully they can fix the salt problem!
author: vanessa c.

description:
There were four of us at Street.  My brother, my father, and my grandfather.  A multigenerational feast, to be sure.  Our previous excursion as a group had been Range in the Mission.  Range and Street are similar--both in the "New American" category.  But Range is slightly better.

However, Street did not necessarily disappoint.

Strong drink: Good wine selection and a solid cocktail.  Street obviously uses Alexia Moore as one of their wine distributors, which I appreciate (Bonny Doon, Husch, etc.).  I use "cocktail" in the singular because I only ever order one:  a Knob Creek manhattan.  Our server patiently listened to my specifications and returned with a perfectly mixed manhattan--down to the brandied cherries.  

Good but not stellar food: I had seared ahi, served with mashed and blue lake string beans.   Flavor was good, but the fish was cut too thin for searing and/or the heat was too low.  Consequence: the ahi wasn't really seared.  It was cooked medium rare.  Ahi should be lightly seared on the outside, rare on the inside.  

My brother is a veg, so he had to get some lame dish that wasn't on the menu.  Note: not a single entree was veg-friendly.  

My dad ordered the NY strip--excellent, cooked just right.  My grandfather ordered the crab cakes, which were great with a pleasant amount of heat.

Try the bread pudding for dessert.  Grandpa liked the peanut butter ice cream (made in-house), but I think the whole PB and/or J trend in new American joints is overdone.  Brother's chocolate cake was great, too.  I had Remy VSOP for dessert.

Bottom line:  Street is solid but not necessarily remarkable new American.  Service is great.  Drinks are fantastic.  But if you're in the mood for really exciting haute comfort food, try Range.
author: Joe R.

description:
Came here with a friend after walking around your San Fran hills for what seemed like years, and the hosts were not at all dismayed to see your humble narrator walking in looking like a big sweaty bear. We were seated (downwind) promptly and served drinks quickly as well. I ordered the risotto and my friend ordered the shortribs.
Risotto was one of the best I have ever had (if a little soggier than I like), and quite reasonably priced too. My friends ribs were delicious (I had to pry them away from him! Its like he was attached to them or something.....sorry, I had to do it). 
All in all
Food: YUM
Price: CHEAPO! (Relatively)
Dcor: Its there! (Meaning not all that memorable, but considering the prices its forgivable)
author: Ross G.

description:
Street is a GREAT neighborhood restaurant.  Friendly staff, good food, fun patrons.  We always go on Sunday's as they offer Fried Chicken on Sunday's only.  The chicken is served with mashed potatoes, gravy fresh corn and cole slaw with the option of sour cream corn bread.  It's terrific and reminds you of that great home cooked meal you had as a child.  Other dishes we've tried have all been good, risotto, steak etc.  Desserts are also well done.  Liz's personal favorite is the Apple Cake.  Awesomely good.

Street is not fancy but always good and a happy place to visit.  Highly recommended when in the Polk St. area.
author: Ron T.

description:
Good thing I had my friend choose a restaurant for dinner...he chose wisely!  Also, the fact that it's less than a 10 minute walk from his place was great.  

Making no reservations and getting there at 7:30pm, we were seated right away!  (Which is a definite plus) Although the place is a little on the darker side and that there's a strange neon light over the door way...the rest of the place was pretty cute.

I really wanted to try the fried chicken, but instead opted for the risotto which was delicious! Yumm!  It was just the right amount of food..plenty of shrimp, chard and cheese with a drizzling of Truffle Oil...drool!  Friend ordered the gnocchi and calabrese sausage, the gnocchi wasn't as firm as I normally like it, but the dish was a great combination!

If you happen to be in the area you should really try Street, the food and staff were great!
author: Christine C.

description:
Every time I go here, it's on a Sunday, so I have the fried chicken.  Its delicious!  

But what's this?  Paying extra for cornbread now?  hmmm, minus 1 star.  

Otherwise great Sunday night comfort food!  I'll force myself to try something other than the fantastic chicken next time.
author: Nick S.

description:
Went in on a Friday evening after the kitchen had closed, though the bar stayed open all the way to 2am.

The place was mostly empty, which was what we were looking for at the time - something quieter and with more seats than the surrounding bars. 
The drinks were good, strong, and well mixed, and the bartender (Amy) was friendly. I can't go to five stars without at least _trying_ the food, but the drinks were good enough to earn it four.
author: Daniel G.

description:
The decor is nice... a little tiny but you don't quite get that cramped feeling.  Unfortunately it is in a popular area so parking can be a little tough.  Stay the course and you'll find something.  Also, after a nice dinner you can hit up any of the numerous wine bars that happen to be nearby.

I've been here three times now and each time has not disappointed.  The fried chicken on Sundays is good.  Their NY strip steak is savory (especially with the generous helping of butter on top).  AND, their dessert is off the hook (I have only tried their sticky toffee bread with vanilla ice cream and the panna cotta).  

I didn't give 5 stars only because their wine selection isn't as good as it could be.  The cote du rhone was their better glass of red.
author: Kenneth K.

description:
Street is really homey, friendly, yummy comfort food, conveniently located right next to the fabulous Buc. Plus the servers/bartenders are all super friendly. They have really delish cocktails as well.

This is the type of restaurant where you can bring anyone - parents, friends, boyfriends/girlfriends, etc. Universally appealing ambiance.
author: Ava S.

description:
My overall experience at this restaurant was great. Our server was extremely friendly and organized. The food we ordered was pretty amazing. 

-Hummus: served with yummy veggies and pita bread
-Grilled artichoke: i couldn't stop dipping them into the special sauce 
-Won tons: very tasty and seasoned well
-Seafood risotto: Yummo. i haven't had risotto this good in a while
-Prime Rib: Pretty good, but hard to mess up a decent cut of prime rib
-Wine: they offer half bottles of wine, which i thought was pretty amazing especially if you don't want to order the whole bottle.

My only complaint is the tables are so close to each other, you might as well be sitting and chatting with your neighbor. I would recommend dining with friends, but scratch the idea of romantic date.
author: Anne K.

description: This is hands down one of the best sirloin burgers I've ever had. It's soooo juicy. Be sure to add the applewood smoked bacon and the gruyere cheese, oh and Dijon mustard....simply delicious!!!! My mouth is watering just writing this! Don't forget the kennebec fries either. Mmmmmmm.....
author: Genie M.

description:
Took 8 minutes to receive menus, 15 minutes to get an order in, and 30 minutes for our food to come out.  While waiting, a child broke a glass cup and it took 5 min for anyone to come out and clean it up.  There were only 2 tables with customers and yet the service was abysmal.

Crab and rock shrimp cakes: Salty and lacked the natural flavors of crab and shrimp.
Burger-over priced and not on a true focaccia bread as stated on the menu, but a regular bun.  The burger was good, but not worth the service and the price.
author: Kamui K.

description:
Nice location right on polk STREET :)
Friendly neighborhood joint with good burgers/meat/salad/soup/drinks. Not too pricey on bottles of wine either. It is too dark in there, however, and I started yawning profusely because of this. Also, they need to turn down the music for more ease of conversation!
author: Kyla L.

description:
Good food and service. I'd go back.

Went to Street for the first time last Friday. Even though I usually don't to really cheap eats, I'd come back to this moderately priced bistro for sure.

First, friendly and attentive staff. Always a plus.

Second, delicious food. I ordered the beef spare ribs. They were absolutely delectable. Tender, melt in your mouth and tasty. My friend had the ahi tuna, it was fantastic as well. Our appetizer and sides were also solid and flavorful.

Dinner (with appetizer and drink) for two was about $66. A little more than I like to spend on a meal, but I'd return for sure.
author: M O.

description:
Yummmmmy,  What a great neighborhood restaurant. Very intimate space, perfect for a table of two. The food has a nice southern twist, very satisfying. 

Love the textural artwork that surrounds the space.
author: Trina H.

description:
I've been walking past this place for years.  Literally.  I once had a roommate that used to go real heavy on the vino when the rest us were at work then stumble down here for "the best burger in sf" which was really a euphemism for "the bartender doesn't mind if I am the only person at the bar drinking gin martinis on Tuesday afternoon."  Anyways, roomate swore by it.

Finally on Friday night I stopped in for a late dinner and a drink.  The cocktails were great.  The hostess was really cool and happy and the place was way nicer/stylier than I expected.  

I got the burger with bacon and white cheddar cheese.  It was extravagent.  So rich I could hardly eat it, but was still loving it.  It was also huge and the fries were great.  Started with an heirloom tomato salad that I also loved.  

3 stars b/c the burger was overcooked and I didn't like my girlfriends dish.  It was kind of a salad and I was expecting a roast chicken dish.

I'd go back for burgers and drinks on a sunday for sure.
author: Eamonn T.

description:
We ended up at Street after our original dinner plans were foiled.  It was pretty packed in here on a Thursday night at 8:15, but the hostess was awesome and got us seated by the window with only about a 30 minute wait.  The food, the service and the cocktails were all excellent.  We had shrimp/crab cakes, which were delicious, and a couple of big, juicy burgers with fresh fries.  For dessert, we had the homemade peanut butter ice cream and my wife is still thinking about it. 

I like the dark, friendly vibe in here-- very glad we ended up at Street!
author: Matt L.

description: Great burger. Solid bun, not too big. Good ground sirloin beef, always cooked with care to order. Very tasty kennebec fries. Bartenders make great drinks. Overall, a very good neighborhood restaurant. I wish they had a TV or two. I'd watch games at the bar 3x a week.
author: Juan S.

description: So I went back to have dinner with friends.  Mind you, she picked the place not me.  But like I said, I was willing to give it another go.  I enjoyed it more this time (yummy pea soup and steak salad).  'Nough said.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
No reservations, but they will let you put your name in and get a drink at the Buck and they'll come get you when your table is ready. 

Street is one of my faves in SF... everything is yummy... but if you go, listen carefully... you MUST get the bread pudding.  I know, I know, I am not really into bread pudding either, but the bread pudding at Street is different... trust me... you'll thank me later.  Its like, "mmm-outloud" delicious.
author: Mary S.

description:
Effing burgers man...I freaking love them at Street!  I've had the burger about 20 times out of 21 times I've eaten there and I've loved every bite.  Get it with Avocado and you won't be sorry.  One of the cooks looks like he's had a few burgers in his day and that's a good sign! 

The slogan says it all, real food, strong drinks.  Their cocktail list is creative which makes it easier to hang out at the small bar while waiting for your table since they don't take reservations.  

The prices are incredibly reasonable so this is always the place we take out of town guests for dinner.  But if you are going with a group, they won't take more than 2 credit cards per table so be prepared and bring some cash money.
author: elyse e.

description:
Really like this spot because it's close to my place, has great food and it serves booze in addition to wine and beer.  What up with the restaurants in SF that don't serve booze?  And they're open late!

No reservations.
author: Scott W.

description:
Tried this place out based on the great Yelp reviews and it didn't disappoint. Went here for dinner on Saturday with 3 others and we were seated immediately. It's pretty small but I didn't feel packed in like at so many other tiny restaurants in SF.

All the food was great. The portion sizes are perfect. The atmosphere was romantic and casual. Definitely a perfect place to go for a date.
author: Bruce D.

description:
I really want to give this place 5 stars, but I walked away hungry.  I don't need gigantic Cheesecake Factory-sized portions, but when somebody tells me that a dinner salad is exactly that and plenty of food, I expect some serious greens!  It was medium sized, with all kinds of goodies like apples and pecans and gorgonzola, but I wished it were a bit bigger.

My friend had the chicken with some yummy mashed potatoes and she really liked it.  My cucumber vodka martini was strong - so strong I asked what to do about it and the waitress awesomely suggested lime juice to make it a good gimlet.  And it WAS!  My friend's pink lemonade martini had confetti-like sugar granules around the rim, which made it a real party in a glass.  I'll be back.
author: Marina Maven C.

description:
I used to LOVE this place.  It was my favorite neighborhood standby - always consistently good food, service and ambiance.  Sadly my last two visits fell far short of my expectations.  IMost recently,  was jonesing for  a burger this past Friday eve so I suggested to my date that we hit Street - known for a great burger and amazing fries.  Unfortuanately, my burger was just so-so and the fries were not at all what I've had in the past. My date had the Ahi, which has been superb in the past, and it too was mediocre at best.

The quality of my meal this past weekend was a HUGE disappointment.  What a buzz kill...what happened?   Did the owner/chef pass off the baton?  I'm offering 3 stars instead of 2 only because my past meals have been so much better.  Let's hope it's a passing phase....
author: kim c.

description: This place is so cute. It's got great decor and wonderful service. I went with a group of girlfriends and we are all VERY different eaters and we not only all found something me liked each plate was amazing! I had the Ahi and hummus which was fantastic.
author: Crystal M.

description: While I like the food here (great burgers!), this is really a review of the bar and Amy, the genius behind my modified cucumber martini. Street is the bar I visit on a Tuesday when I want to drink alone without drinking alone. The small bar always seems to be full of friendly locals and they have just the drinks I need: house made infused vodkas and a great wine list. Add a bartender who knows how to make a single gal feel well looked-after and I will come back again and again. And again.
author: Sara J.

description:
I actually joined yelp in order to review this restaurant because of two bad experiences here. The first bad experience took place on a Friday night. Myself and some friends went to try Street. We were told that there would be a 45 minute wait. We went over to a bar, drank, and returned 45 minutes later. When we asked on the status of our table the hostess, without an apology or any acknowledgment that we had already waited 45 minutes, said that it would be another 45 minutes - one hour. WHAT?!?

Needless to say we left, but because of its high rating on yelp and its proximity to my apartment, I tried again a few weeks later. I took my parents there for a treat (I know, stupid given my first experience). We went during the week at 7 so there was no wait. When we ordered, my dad asked for the fried chicken as did my boyfriend. All out. THEY ARE KNOWN FOR THEIR FRIED CHICKEN. My mom ordered the fish. All out. At 7 o'clock, before the majority of the people eating there had ordered, they were out of two of the eight items on their entree menu. In tough times, you should be able to count on being satisfied when you choose to go out to a nice meal. We weren't. Twice.
author: Jodi S.

description: Wonderful, wonderful hamburger. Excellent fries. Friendly service. Only negative? REALLY LOUD.
author: Patsy K.

description:
Love what John does here. I will say it would be nice to mix up the menu a bit more. When's the pork belly coming back???

Staff is great, food is pretty good. Great 'hood place to eat.
author: Bubba M.

description:
Never a bad meal in four years here. My only complaint: they often run out of chicken and burgers if you don't get there by 9:00 or so. The owner says it's because he wants to make sure everything is fresh, no leftover food. OK, I'll buy that to an extent. But something tells me the day-old "anything" here would be an above average culinary experience.

Any appetizer works as a meal intself. The Calamari is crispy but not greasy, rather flavorfully light. Soups are savory and not delieverd scalding hot. You MUST have the burger, with the grilled onions that simply squish themselves between the burger, ketchup and bun. The fries are astounding, not greasy-tasting. The bread pudding is like biting into a buttered pancake with maple syrup, but all the work of buttering and syruping and slicing has already been done for you!

The bar service is some of the friendliest in the City, usually by a female... young and cute, just like most of the customers. I think they have an "ugly" detector at the door, but somehow I still manage to make it in.
author: Nitram N.

description:
Cute, Cute, Cute. It was exactly what we were looking for...dark, loud, artistic, and plenty of wine to choose from. ...

We went with a half bottle of Sancerre ($19)
I had the Caesar salad...dressing didn't really have enough pizazz for me, but the shredded cheese on top was so soft and velvety..I added some lemon and pepper for some punch. ($9)
He had the special..sea bass with corn and mushrooms. Not a lot on the huge plate that took over most of the small two seater table, but was tasty nonetheless. ($19)
We skipped dessert (darnit). I had already eaten two desserts that day, but next time I will def. go for some bread pudding...Also, the couple next to us was having the burger...yum..i was jealous.

Overall...We will go back when we are looking for a quick bite with a fun atmosphere.
author: Amy W.

description:
Went tonight to Street for the second time. It's quite a romantic interior and perfect for a date. Plenty of tables and a great bar. Reminds me a bit of a new york restaurant - tables close together and a lively hum.

I love the rustic decor with lots of candlelight reflecting. There's a lovely counter height table in the front window but they absolutely wouldn't let us sit there because we weren't a group of four. As it happens, the table remained empty until we left. 

On the walls they've displayed the mixed-media artwork of Shirley Mariani. It doesn't seem to have changed since I was there several months ago and they don't post prices with her paintings. If a cafe/restaurant/pub is going to go to the trouble of hanging an artist's work, I always like to see the prices and artist's name so I don't have to ask. In this case I did ask which is why I know.

For starters we had a lovely spring greens salad with granny smith apples and gorganzola. I'm such a fan of blue cheese in a salad and it was tasty. The greens were a bit dry and though I strongly dislike a salad that's swimming in vinagrette, this could have used a tablespoon more.

Both my friend and I ordered the prime rib. It was medium rare  and served on a bed of mashed potatoes with a few crisp green beans. The prime rib was perfectly done and tender. The mashed potatoes were gluey and contained too much chicken stock. I didn't care for them at all and barely touched them. Usually nothing keeps me from devouring mashed potatoes so that took some doing. They served this with a nice sour cream/horseradish sauce. The entire plate was too cool in temperature. 

The service was fine. Wine selection was decent. I wish they'd brought out my main while it was still hot. There were relatively few people in the restaurant when we ordered and my friend and I ordered the exact same thing so there's really no excuse for it to be sitting around to get cold.

I've had the risotto before and quite liked it. This is a fair restaurant. It wouldn't take much more than a few tweaks to make it a good restaurant.  Mid-range prices.
author: Alison P.

description:
Just got back from Street.  We had a large party so I will give A LOT of room for service, food, and overall experience.  First and foremost, I want to acknowledge our waitress.  She was absolutely fantastic.  She was patient, accommodating, and had excellent customer service.  The food itself was just mediocre.  I'm by now means a food snob, but I know my meats.  We had the prime rib, steak, risotto, ahi tuna, heirloom tomatoes, wontons, and crab cakes.  The food was slightly overcooked and salty!  The heirlooms were very good though.  

The floor supervisor, or owner, wasn't very nice to us.  Granted, our party was incomplete and some of us were more than an hour late.  I apologized profusely for our friends' tardiness and even said," Please, if you need this table to seat your customers, by all means, seat them."  She snapped at our table and said, "yeah, these other people had reservations."  UMMMMMMM.........  I thought Street didn't take reservations!?!?!?!?!  The cocktails weren't very good either.  

Oh well, at least our waitress was nice.  The desserts were good.  I still think if we spent over 500 dollars at your restaurant, we should've at least gotten a thank you.
author: Stan V.

description:
For some reason I always feel uber cool when dining at this place.  The interior of the restaurant is the epitomy of urban chic.   The vibe is classy (but what else would you expect from Russian Hill)? Service is spot on.

I've been here several times and tried many of the dishes and cocktails.

They have a full bar and some tasty infused vodkas.  The wine list is decent, however selection is much better if you order by the bottle 

Skip the pork belly, but try the calamari

The spinach salad with beets and goat cheese is a wonderful starter for two to share 

Being the carnivore that I am I usually always order the burger, be sure to add gruyere cheese.   Otherwise it's the Angus strip steak which is always tasty  accompanied by gorgonzola butter.  The fried chicken is a decadent yet delicious option but I believe they only have it on Sunday nights. Crab cakes are a good choice as well.

For dessert:   Peanut butter ice cream.  Trust me.

If you feel uncomfortable in tight spaces, be forewarned, the tables here are mighty close together.  The noise level is high and the lighting is dim so if you have bad eyesight, bring your owl light.
author: Brenna C.

description:
I can't believe I have lived around the block for over a year and only just ate here the other night.

Good prices, nice atmosphere, friendly staff. Great burger!
Def a nice no frills place to get a good meal!
author: Sam H.

description:
Food...who actually lives in the neighborhood and would write a review on this generic B&T destination?

That said, let's talk about bar service, now that we're reviewing "Street"....

Kudos: they make their own ginger ale mix for those of you with a discerning palate.

Downside: bar staff has "good" days and "wish you would go away" days.   Woe be those who show up on a WYWGA" days b/c my bf/so is just not paying attention to me....
author: PeterDragon D.

description:
Went here for dinner around 10:00 pm which made me worry that it would be closed like so many other restaurants. But not it was busy and more people came in after us. 

The food was good though uninspired. However it is simple american food and they do a good job of it. Also, as I always like they have a full bar with good drinks. 

So, to conclude:
Good Food
Good Drinks
Stays open late 

I will be back!
author: Madeline T.

description: I really like this place. The prices are decent and the food is good (I had the risotto - totally bomb). The fries are also delicious with the housemade ranch -- be sure to try this or split an order for the table. I definitely will come back. The only issue I had was the layout. The restaurant is a little  on the small side so you end up feeling like you're in the middle of traffic if you don't get one of the edge tables. If you sit at the table right next to the door, you'll be constantly scooting your seat in to avoid diners coming & going.
author: linda t.

description:
My original plan was to go out and grab some beers with a friend, but  I had just flown back into SF, and was starving... so instead decided to come here for food and drinks.  Considering that I live less than 5 blocks away, I was pleasantly surprised with the results -- why haven't I tried this place before?

The ambiance is a little odd- it has a lounge feel to it, but with cramped dining tables (dim red lights, full bar, and room size that feels like a classed-up Buc).

I got the seared ahi tuna.  The dish was cooked just the right way- cool on the inside with a nice sear on the outside. It sat on a bed of mashed potatoes which were very rich and full of garlic- awesome. The tuna had a creamy lemon sauce on top... it was flavorful, but too heavy given the nature of the tuna.  Definitely could have used less sauce, and perhaps it should have been served on the side

Good beers on tap is a plus and they had a solid wine list. Will be back again- curious to try the burger
author: VL K.

description: This place is great for well-executed, simple food and strong cocktails. Really recommend their prime rib with mashed yukon gold potatos or the strip steak. The thing I love about their strip stick is they give you a little pad of gorgonzola butter that is chilled, so the pad melts slowly and you have this sort of hot / cool / pungent / earth sensation that is nice. They have a proper mixology menu and good range of drinks to choose from. The wait staff here is super friendly and attentive. We are spoiled to have this place in our hood. I highly recommend.
author: Andreas T.

description: Amazing mojito! Best burger ever, and great atmosphere. The place is very casual and the staff is very welcoming. I love going back here, and it's a great dining experience every time.
author: Ana Z.

description: The folks here are very nice.  They food is just OK and a tad expensive in my opinion.  In any case, this place does get packed in the evenings. It's not that big--so russian -hillers just wait and wait.  I got the steak salad and it was fine but just nothing special.  My dining-mate got a pasta dish. The staff was really good about telling her there was a meat base, in her original choice, so bonus points for that.   I paid $45 for my portion of the tab which did include a drink and a shared hummus starter.
author: Ka C.

description:
3.5 stars.

every inch of the interior received a red hue.  ...reminds me of another restaurant that, to this day, inflicts mental scars and haunts me w/wine-induced grins and laughter...

i spoke louder than usual.  ...not as boisterous as a bar, but the space was abuzz w/lively conversations had over cuvees and pinot noirs.  pretty good wine selection, given that street is only a $$ restaurant.

despite a friend's poor experience w/the risotto in the past, i was pleasantly surprised w/mine this particular evening.  the flavors definitely stood out, and the prawns were cooked perfectly.  

the tuna was ok.  a bit too chewy for me.

the panna cotta was disappointing.  i was willing it to leap off my plate, but, there it sat, giving lazy winks to its almond biscotti neighbor.
author: Ting A.

description:
Heard good things from some friends, and I was only slightly disappointed for two reasons...they ran out of the chicken.  What a bummer..and the hummus was blah.

The calamari was great as was the corn bread.  The corn bread was the most moist perfect taste I could imagine.  Absolutely amazing.  

Plan on going back because this first visit was more or less a tease.  Also, the waitress was really helpful on how to make sure you don't miss out on chicken and even offered a tip that you can call ahead and reserve chicken.
author: Aaron S.

description:
The S.O. and I were looking for another dining option close to a few certain art galleries to expand our repertoire. We searched Yelp and ended up choosing to try the Street. 

Be warned, they are serious about their tagline at this joint - strong food, real drinks.  Except they really mean strong sauces.  Not strong like spicy and delicious, but strong like each sauce overpowers the flavor of whatever it is smothering .  

We started with pork won-tons.  They were okay, but the flavor of the ginger sauce was just entirely too strong - you couldn't taste the pork...  The same was true of S.O.'s steak - the meat was horribly tough.  It was cooked to perfection -- medium rare and pink inside, but the cut of meat itself was all sinewy and tough. And once again the sauce (gorgonzola) completely hid the actual meat flavor.  

My meal was a disaster.  Being an East Coast transplant I should have known better than to order the crabcakes.  I learned that lesson the hard way many years ago when I first moved here -- or at least that's what one would think.  Unfortunately after reading all of the raving reviews, I really thought they would be a tasty option -- so many rave reviews.  Boy was I wrong.  The actual cake part of the crabcakes were serviceable, but once again the sauce was completely overpowering and completely wrong for the flavor of the crabmeat. Blech! Crab has a delicate, buttery flavor and isn't meant to be paired with a spicy roasted pepper and corn sauce.  I was able to scrape the sauce off and survive, but needless to say I have learned my lesson once again. No one in California knows how to make crabcakes. Period.

The service was marginal. The place wasn't packed, and we saw our waitress try to deliver our food to another table.  Even though we were trying to get her attention to let her know the food was ours, she ended up going all the way back to the kitchen before she figured it out.

I won't be going back. It's just too saucy.
author: Meredith M.

description:
This is my first review and wanted to review Street.  

My recommendation is to go on Sunday nights because their special is fried chicken.  There fried chicken is the crispiest chicken in San Francisco.  My parents enjoy the lemon drop cocktails here.  I've moved from San Francisco to the South Bay but if I still lived in SF I would go to Street once a week and enjoy their awesome food, but only if my parents paid.
author: Jeremy C.

description: Like the chic and dim litted atmosphere of the bar & restaurant.  Came here to celebrate a friend's 21st bday. Definitely a place to get dressy for. Ordered the sirloin steak with buttery mash potatoes and wtheck?! horse radish sauce!! hahaha, i hecka thought it was ranch dressing and swallowed a mouthful :( the meat was very tender, juicy and medium rare the way i like it, however the portions not exactly worth 20 bucks.  On the side i had a pomtini, which messed me up pretty good, i`m a light weight and Yes, Asian Glow under dim red lights, wonderful complimentary!!
author: Fat C.

description: Great drinks & food - though the atmosphere can be a little loud/hectic due to this tiny spot's huge appeal
author: Johnna M.

description: the best restaurant in town. Great food, but the atmosphere is so upbeat that whatever mood you are in, it will get better!
author: Sam B.

description:
The burger was wonderful! Try it with bacon, avocado, and cheese!!

But this place was more expensive than I had originally thought so be prepared! Interesting specialty cocktails...but choose wisely!
author: Christi B.

description: After being greeted by a rude hostess, we were greeted by a rude server. Then, as if their service wasn't terrible enough, the second we finished our meal we were asked to leave the table so they could seat another group. I've never been treated so poorly at a restaurant before. And it's not like we got 1 appetizer to share and didn't get drinks or entrees. We spent over $100 on their overpriced food and they still we're inconsiderate and rude.
author: Leah A.

description: Really good! I had a beer and the Crab and Rock Shrimp Cakes... Yum!!!!!! Came with fries; I would've liked to see something original about the fries, though. They were just plain fries with ketchup.  Maybe some original spice medley or a unique dipping sauce.  It would add to the dish. My boss had the burger with avocado and said that it was delicious.
author: Courtney M.

description: Haven't had their food but the drinks are great and it was empty on friday night wich is great because I hate it when people have to push and elbow you just to get through. This place infuses their own vodka and rum: apricots, peppers, pumpkin, cucumbers and etc. Our bartender Amy was awesome: outgoing and a great at mixing drinks.
author: Tatyana K.

description: Great place for cocktails, cozy and mellow.  Fried chicken was just okay, nothing special and the mashed potatoes were overly salty.  Bread pudding was great.
author: James B.

description:
Street is one of those places that I really want to like.  You can see that the couple who own it have put their hearts and souls into the place but it is just so incredibly uncomfortable that from the moment I sat down, I couldn't wait to leave.   The tables are thisclose together; small two tops with the most uncomfortably hard chairs imaginable.  We went really early on a Thursday evening and so it was still slow but I cannot imagine it being packed. .. I am misanthropic to begin with but can't stand to feel like people are sitting on my lap and that's what it'd be like if the table next to ours was occupied.  The restaurant is tiny with all hard edges - and at 6:00pm they were already playing pseudo house music that just bounced off all the hard edges - it was still bright and sunny outside and the room/ambiance screamed for some good, slow jazz.  

But the real reason I went to Street was for the burger.  I REALLY wanted a great burger and I surely was not disappointed.  Truly a great one -one of the best in the city actually.  Perfectly cooked, on good bread with great bacon and superior cheese.   We shared a bowl of fries that were also very good . . . they use the same kind of potatoes that In-n-Out uses - kennebecs - and the only drawback to kennebecs is that while they are perfect when they are hot, as they cool, they get stiff and chewy - I wish more restaurants would use winnemuccas - they stay delicious down to the last morsel.  

We also had cocktails and while the mojito is certainly large, quantity does not make up for quality. . .it was awfully weak and the mint was not muddled well enough to release the true depth of flavor.  My companion had a lemon drop that was also weak and not nearly lemony enough.  We started with the fried calamari and won tons.  The calamari themselves were delicious but were served with a Thai dipping sauce that didn't have any discernible flavor and it was watery so it did not cling to the calamari at all.  The won ton were similar in preparation to what they serve at Chow but these won tons were far better.  Toothsome with a firm but delicious filling.  The soy based sauce was so good that we ended up dipping the calamari in the won ton sauce and it was really good that way.  We didn't have dessert - I was so aching to get out of there (okay, so my ass was aching from those hard as rocks chairs)  we left and I NEVER skip dessert.  

The truth is, I will be back. That burger was just so good.  I will arrive early and perhaps sit at the empty bar where I'll have plenty of elbow room and can check out all the interesting infused vodkas they have.

Street leans toward comfort food on their menu and I just wish the decor reflected that.
author: Lainie L.

description: I'm glad to know that even though it's been almost 3 years since I've been here , Street is still run by the same amazing wife and husband team and they are still churning out a magnificent dining experience.   I came here recently with my BF and his mom, so I was definitely feeling the pressure since I had picked the restaurant for the night.  The rosemary and garlic encrusted prime rib was divine.  I'm convinced the mashed potatoes had crack in them.  And the crab cakes were meaty goodness -- best I've had in SF thus far.  Desserts (especially the lemon cheesecake) were fab.  Good to know that I can confidently keep Street as one of my solid, go to restaurants in the city.
author: LaSha G.

description:
Where oh where are the half stars? i didn't find Street to be quite a four-star experience, but it was better than three. In the end, I had to tip it downwards simply because they made me the absolute worst gin and tonic I've ever had in my long experience as a drinker of drinks. How the hell do you screw up a gin and tonic? No idea. But they managed to do it. 

Anyway, aside from the gin and tonic travesty, all else was decent. Decent is the word I would use to describe almost every aspect of the meal. The service was decent. The shrimp and pork wontons were decent. The scallop and shrimp corn dogs (yes, corn dogs) were decent. The gnocchi were a little too gooey, but other than that, decent. The pork "chop" was more like a pork cutlet and was overcooked, but it was, you guessed it, decent. The bread pudding, while a little custardy in texture for my taste, was still perfectly--drum roll--decent. 

There was nothing about this place that would recommend it. Nor nothing about it to NOT recommend it. Do you know what I mean...? I'd go back--if I was starving and happened to be walking by at that moment and there wasn't a wait for a table and I wanted to eat a hamburger. 

I hear a lot about the burger. I should've gotten one of those...
author: Sage R.

description: This place is one of my Polk Street favorites!  It has been here for a long time, and the food has been consistently delicious.  The friendly service proves this to be a neighborhood favorite, and the menu seems to hold fresh and seasonal ingredients.  Nothing I have had has been less than absolutely yummy...the burgers are phenomenal and the wine selection is legitimate and well priced.  I love the interior decor - simple and inviting.  Such a great place to go for date night or girl's night out, and the neighborhood is perfect for after dinner drinks.
author: Jessica T.

description: Kickin' corn bread. The first time I ordered it I asked for butter, and the owner himself told me I don't need it. He was right. The corn bread is insanely good. Great fried chicken too. This is one of those places where it is actually more fun to eat at the bar, even if you are with someone. We used to live up the hill and would come here all the time. Always good food, great atmosphere, and the owners are cool people.
author: LosAngelenoguy L.

description: Been here once for just the dessert.  The bread puddin was FANTASTIC!  I wasn't a fan of the water tho... it tasted like bleach.  UGHHHHH
author: Ivy S.

description:
I hold Street and their associates solely responsible for any and all questionable decisions I made last night. 
Lisa and I got our drank on like it was nobody's business. Her? Fig martini. Moi? Apricosmo. That's right. GIRLY drinks...screw you, Atkins! I'm a size 4 again. I can drink whatever the hell I want! 
We also got our scam on. And by scam I mean drunk eye-screwing and gratuitious boob shaking at all patrons who looked like they were packing...
On the real...the drinks were strong and delicious. The bartender was seriously not interested in getting me drunk but with a little perserverance, the service wasn't too bad. The hostess (manager?) and the owner (??? some hot guy in shorts overseeing everything) were incredibly gracious and made me feel like a welcome customer. Lisa and co. seemed to enjoy the food (I'm not crazy! sugary drinks=lunch AND dinner AND breakfast tomorrow) and it looked incredibly tasty. Big points scored with the lighting and the sexy interior. Only problem? One bathroom for a place this popular equals potty anxiety. It's tiny and it is outrageously popular, so you better like rubbing up against strangers (god, I do...). 
You must go for the drinks and stay for the hotties at the bar. And then take them with you to Tonic...and then to Wish...and then to DNA...and then...well...like I said: I hold Street solely responsible for all questionable decisions made last night...
author: Autumn K.

description: The food was good, don't let the three stars fool you.  Our server was attentive enough, but I don't really think that it's appropriate for the wait staff to pound on the door to the bathroom and then chastise you for taking too long when you come out of the restroom.  I was in there under 3 minutes, to be sure.  It's not my fault that there's only a single bathroom and the employees are pissy (pun intended) because they have to pee AND attend to their tables.  Also, be aware that this place can get loud.  The lighting seems to have an intimate feel that may lead you to believe that this would be a good spot for a romantic-type meal.  However, once the place is full, you will find yourself shouting across the tiny table to your devastatingly handsome dining partner.
author: Kiki G.

description: Stopped here for a quick dinner. The restaurant was busy, but we were seated fairly soon. The tables are so close together you feel like your having a conversation with the people on either side. The service was so-so, and the food was definitely lackluster at best. Not a terrible place, but would recommend many other options within a few blocks in either direction.
author: Michael C.

description: Some nights a girl's desires can only be satisfied by a big juicy bloody rare burger.  Last night I was this girl, so guided by the wisdom of fellow yelpers we headed to Street.  Loved my burger and was pleasantly surprised to find brandied cherries in my manhattan.  I need nothing else from you, Street.  You have proven yourself with these two items.    When the burger lust returns, so shall I.
author: L W.

description: LOVE the atmosphere but the food was only so-so.  I've had much better fried chicken (try 1300...to die for).  The steak was not very flavorful and the burger was, well a burger.  Nothing special.  I really want to like this place more as it has such a cool vibe.  I love exposed brick.  I'd give the food two stars and the atmosphere four, thus my three star review.
author: Jennifer C.

description: I'm really surprised by all of the good reviews here, because I did not have a very good experience at Street. The food just isn't good and tastes like a bad experiment I could have made in my own kitchen. I would chalk it up to ordering badly, but neither my boyfriend or I liked our meal. His fried chicken looked like something I could have gotten a drive through. Skip this place and check out one of the many other restaurants on Polk St.
author: Lindsey S.

description: I had the sausage with gnocci and would definitely have it again - and I'm not even a gnocci fan!  A friend of mine took me to this cute neighborhood diner style cafe... great for a casual date or meeting up w/ friends.
author: Kerri L.

description: This place always delivers! Using fresh, sustainably grown ingredients from local farms, Street offers superb meals every time I go in. My girlfriend and I love this place. The ambiance is great and it's always busy. To start, I'd recommend the Pork & Shrimp Wontons or the Calamari. Those are the only ones I've tried and are delicious. For the mains I'd say the freshly ground sirloin burger is always satisfying. The NY Strip Steak with the Gorgonzola butter is great as well. Top off the meal with any of their Port wines.
author: Victor B.

description: Street is one of my favorite restuarants in my hood. They are family owned, the staff is awesome, and the food is delicious.  While burgers are a plenty on polk street, I always crave Street's burger.  Their salads and  risottos are heavenly! Tthey are constantly changing the menu, so always some new things to try. Good wine selection from boutique wineries and tasty cocktails.
author: Susanna S.

description: Fried Chicken Sunday's - hell ya.  I was out for an early dinner last Sunday,  and good thing because by 6:30pm this place was packed.  I guess most come for their Fried Chicken w/ Mash and there's an option to order a piece of Cornbread which is definitely worth it!  This was the first visit for my friend & I so we decided to share the chx and an app - Pork Belly.  It was served w/ lentils and greens - it was just ok.  Also, they have a unique drink menu - my friend got the house infused vodka flight - you get to choose 3 from a list of about 6.  2 out of 3 - pretty good.  I tried a Apripolitan (sp?) which was delicious, and also made with one of their infused vodkas.  The bf coincidentally went here the same night and had their sirloin burger - BOMB apparently...ahhh next time.
author: Meredith K.

description: This is a really cute little place perfect for a date, but alas, since I'm not dating anyone, I went with a girlfriend of mine.  7:30 on a Friday night and there was no wait for 2.  They have really cool pieces of artwork on the walls and dim lighting.  There is a bar in the back.  I was a little disappointed that the people sitting next to us got to order first even though we were seated first.  Shared the hummus and pita appetizer which was very tasty.  Then I had the ahi with mashed potatoes and green beans.  It was quite good, but I sort of wish I had gotten the pork shoulder instead.  Anyway, most dishes are under $20 and the food is delectible!  I'd definitely go again, but I'd get a bottle of wine next time, and maybe a dessert too.
author: Vanessa Z.

description:
Street is an ideal restaurant for a first date. . .it's dimly lit (in case there were any surprises on how your date looked outside of the bar). . .the great food (which will give you something to talk about if you run out of things to say) . . .and it's extremely affordable (so you won't feel obligated or guilty if you don't think there's going to be a second date). The space itself is small, and rather than creating an intimate feel, you end up feeling a bit claustrophobic touching elbows with the patrons next to you. But hey, if there are any awkward silences, you can always jump in on their  dinner conversation. The portions at Street are considerable for the price you pay, which is rare nowadays in the City. After dinner, there are plenty of things to do on Polk- Amelie Wine Bar, The Buccaneer, Big Foot Lounge, and North Beach is right  around the corner. All in all. . .a great date spot. . .whether it's your first, or your fifty first.

Personal Street recommendations- the pate appetizer (especially if your date doesn't like the stuff, because you get it all to yourself!) and the prawns risotto.
author: Alice P.

description:
So, my lady and I found this place one Friday night and went there. The atmosphere was cool, and looked to be promising. We were wrong.

The service was great, the waitress was very nice, attentive, and friendly. The food however was very sub par for the prices they are asking. The bowl of gumbo we shared was pretty good, so the meal started off on the right foot. For mains, the lady got the seafood risotto, I got the "homemade" Calbrese sausage with gnocci.

The risotto was pretty good, but not for the price, I've had better, I've had worse. Wasn't memorable at all.

The Calbrese, was horrible. The gnocci was bad. You could find a better sausage at Top Dog in Berkeley, or at Faletti Foods, it was not even a real Cal, I was actually offended that they would serve what tasted like a Costco sausage at this place. As for the gnocci, I've had better from the frozen section of Trader Joe's.

The only reason this place doesn't get just one star, is the waitress was very nice.

To reiterate, DO NOT GO HERE. Unless they get a new chef, or lower their prices.
author: Brendan F.

description: This is a lively neighborhood restaurant in a good location on Polk. It's rather narrow but decently long with a nice bar. It can get a little loud and crowded-feeling, but not too bad. The staff is very friendly and the food comes pretty fast. The menu is a somewhat limited but everything tastes pretty good. I'm a big eater and found the portions to be a little too small -- had to grab a little extra from Real Foods across the street. I'd come back again, but only if I'm not starving.
author: Andrew T.

description:
Best burger in the city.  Bar none.
