This restaurant is family owned, and the care and attention shows through in the food.  The menu changes with the seasons, but everything is always perfectly cooked and reasonably priced.  Street is too nice to call a burger a burger, so order the grilled sirloin medium rare and thank me later.
author: Andrea F.

description: You can't go wrong with this place! In addition to the burgers and fried chicken mentioned by other Yelpers, they do a great pork chop. Also if you're looking for something on the lighter side, try their cold garlic noodle and chicken. The place is small and the parking can be difficult but the food is awesome and worth the trip to Russian Hill.
author: Neil K.

description:
Awesome...a moderately priced trendy bistro in my 'hood.  This place is delish.  The vibe is casual.
Every time I've been here, it's been easy to get a table and the service is great.  I've never eaten here on a Friday or Saturday night, so I am not sure how easy it is to get a table then.  I'll report back.
The freshly ground sirloin burger...um...YUM!  I also recommend the grilled Hawaiian ahi, the baby spinach salad, the mixed greens, and the hummus.  The portions are decent, I left feeling really full.  Next time I want dessert...I just couldn't make room.
There is a bar you can eat at if a table is not available.
author: Ashley Q.

description: I came here last night for the infamous Street burger and was definitely not disappointed! The burger was juicy, medium rare, and absolutely delish once topped off with that pepper jack cheese! Perfectly toasted bun and crispy Kennewick fries. Not sure what that means, but I know they were special. Minus one star for extremely slow service (I think they messed up our order bc people were getting served around us quite quickly) but plus one for adding the smoked applewood bacon by mistake. Caesar salad was standard. Cute little place for a date. Almost all tables are for two people and the lighting is quite dark.
author: Lauren Y.

description: I fail at clicking buttons. I meant to give this four stars before instead of 3.
author: Rochelle F.

description: Excellent little bar-restaurant. Had dinner at bar with friend.  Service prompt and friendly.  Menu is brief, but fine selections, e.g. hummus, steak salad, lamb burgers, etc.  Had the excellent wontons and (their own) sausage and gnocchi dish--delicious.  Highly recommend for informal, light meal.
author: Ned S.

description: The food at Street was pretty good but slightly overpriced especially considering the place is really crowded. You pretty much feel like you're dining with the people next to you. Also the place is extremely loud. I had the crab cakes which was overall pretty good except for I didn't like the black eyed peas as a garnish. My boyfriend had the steak which we found satisfactory. It comes with fries though instead of mashed potatoes which seem more fitting to go with the steak the way it is served. The desserts were slightly less satisfactory than the meal. The service was good except for the lag time between courses and the check was slightly long. I would definitely go back though.
author: Cathy T.

description: I've dropped in Street several times in hopes of really liking it.. unfortunately it was always ok..  Being a southern girl I'm extremely picky when it comes to fried chicken, and I must say it was good but not THAT good.. The gnnocchi was yum from what I remember. I don't really get the ambiance. To be honest I'd rather go somewhere else on Polk street like Pesce or Yabbies for dinner.
author: Sarah W.

description:
tried this place last night. this place ruled. first off, right when i walked into this place, i noticed that this place had a really good atmosphere. the place was pretty full too ... for a wednesday night, i think that's pretty good. 

ok, so we started off with an appetizer ... pork & shrimp wontons (w/ soy ginger splash). oh man, this was awesome. 

for the main course i went with the grilled hawaiian ahi (w/ chipotle-lime sauce, mashed potatoes and blue lake beans). very very very good. the ahi was seared to perfection.  it was also a pretty decent sized portion of ahi too. i highly recommend trying this dish. 

this place also has pretty reasonable prices. my main course ran me $17.75. 

I will definately go back here to try some of their other dishes.
author: James J.

description:
You know how you feel when you may have had one (re:12) too many cocktails in the afternoon and early evening and then you went home and tangled up the sheets with the new love of your life during the proper dinner hour? You pull yourself back together, hair tussled, skin glowing a sense of the world being fresh and beautiful and wander down the street to have a romantic late supper. 
Is there possibly a feeling that can match this one, I say no. 
So there we are seated at Street being romantical and I manage to be underwhelmed with every item brought to me with the exception of the wine and the apple cake. I was especially appalled by my risotto, which was certainly not actual aborio or carneroli, I think it was actually short grain rice. Maybe it was just an off night on the line. My man's steak was good.
I will say that the service was very gracious and the candlelit room very conducive to the continued romancing.
author: Melissa H.

description: Despite being in my 'hood, last night was my first visit to Street, not really sure why. The space is very stylish and sleek, but still manages to remain neighborhoody. The food is something along the lines of California cuisine, but I went with the fried chicken, which, pardon the expression, was finger lickin' good. I've heard from some reliable sources that their hamburger is one of the best in the city, so will have to try that next time around. I'd recommend Street for a dinner with friends, or even for a casual date.
author: Nish N.

description: Went here the other night for dinner and overall was a very enjoyable experience. The decor is hip and trendy, but not in a "trying too hard" sort of way. As for the food, it's definitely on the "comfort food" side of things, and was quite tasty... espeically the grilled Hawaiian ahi and the risotto, which was prepared in a delicious red sauce. Oh, and I know that rose wine is generally considered garbage in this town, but we had an excellent bottle... I believe it was called Vin Gris of Pinot Noir or something like that. Tres magnifique!
author: Chris B.

description: Street has awesome burgers!!  Trust me, try the burger when you go there.  Also, if you are lucky enough to go on a Sunday their fried chicken is perfect.  I used to go there all the time when I lived in the neighborhood.
author: Jake A.

description: First off, the Street Burger is one of the best burgers in town.  Juicy, mouthwatering sirloin.  The calamari, as others have said, is delicious. The dipping sauce is a spicy, yet tangy, jalapeno/cilantro/vinagarette type of sauce that is superbly savory on the tastebuds.  The Trumer Pilsner on tap is also a must sample.  A great way to start of the night in style.
author: Johnny B.

description: My first time eating on Polk St. was at Street!  It was a fun atmosphere, good cocktails and pretty good food.  I had the burger which was very good for a burger and my mom had the sausage/gnocchi plate.  The heirloom tomato/goat cheese appetizer was DELICIOUS and the service was really great.  The artwork on the walls was really cool as well...would definitely go back!
author: Elizabeth H.

description: Yummy food-I had the souffled goat cheese & the meatloaf-both were very good.  The desserts are amazing as well.  A little too dimly lit in there for my taste, but besides that, it had great service & a good location.
author: Crystal W.

description: Sundays Fried Chicken dinners are the main reason I love to go there. With its deliciously fried chicken just right, mashed potatoes and gravy (like how you wished mom made them) and the sour cream cornbread satisfy the pallet. Get there when they open at 6 or you may have to wait. Also every time I go on a Sunday, its funny how all but one or two people have ordered the chicken. Where else does that happen where everyone gets the same dish?
author: shawn a.

description:
even though street is close by, i havent been there in years... after going back recently, i remembered how good it is!  fun atmosphere, good food and cocktails, what else could i ask for??  sure, its not super gourmet, but you know what you are going to get.  our service was a little spotty but not bad and we weren't in a hurry.  
we shared the calamari and the pot stickers - both were great.  i had the dungeness crab and shrimp cakes for my entree which were good.  not as good as east coast crabcakes but lets not go there... 
i will definitely be putting street back into my local neighborhood go-to list now that i have been reacquainted!
author: Carolyn B.

description: The Apripolitan:  my new favorite cocktail (tied alongside the Laughing Buddha from Cantina).  Food is really good - though the chef had a huge issue with my friend and I asking to have the burger cut in half so that we could share it.  I suppose we could have cut it ourselves, but he was really persistent about not ever cutting a medium rare burger in half. If it was well done, that was another story - but not if it was medium.   I mean, HUH?!   In the end our waitress must have schmoozed him because he did in fact cut it - but we found the whole thing really odd.  The pate was de-lish - as was the warm goat cheese appetizer.   I will definitely returning!!
author: Whitney H.

description: Their Mojito gets twelve thumbs up from me.  I've never had another like it! Never!  *crashes off chair while throwing arms around in the air*
author: Catherine F.

description: Street is a nice neighborhoody restaurant. The space is small and everyone is packed in tight. The food was cooked well but the menu was very basic.
author: Carlos L.

description:
i want to give this place 3.5 stars.

they only serve their fried chicken & corn bread on sunday nights starting at around 6pm.  they usually run out of chicken and corn bread around 8pm.  sometimes, they extend their cornbread until tuesday (rarely, i was told).  they stop serving food at 10.

we came here at around 830pm, and we snagged the last two pieces of corn bread and fried chicken.  they gave us a 10$ deal (instead of the 17$) because they only has two pieces of chicken left, which was pretty sweet.
i got the crab cakes with fries.  their crab cakes were really ehhh.  i felt like i was eating canned tuna.  i don't know.  it wasn't bad, but it wasn't terrific.

but omg.  you have to get the corn bread.  it's absolutely delicious.  for 1.50$, you can have the most perfect-est corn bread in the worldddddddd.  it was perfectly moist with little chunks of corn in it and just the right amount of sweetness.  it's amaaaaazing.
author: H. L.

description: Mediocre at best - overpriced, so-so food and atmosphere. I have no idea how this place is rated as highly as it is. The cocktails were just ok, and I was not impressed with the food. The only thing that I enjoyed were the desserts - the toffee crunch and peanut butter ice cream were great (enough for 1 additional star).
author: Adrienne C.

description:
so i've been looking for a great burger at a local joint and we have a winner. the burger here is pretty damn good! good fries too.
the downer was the bar. they were out of anchor steam and it took 10 minutes to find this out. then had a fig martini which was a bit sweet. could have used a blue cheese stuffed olive. 
but because the burger was that good, they get four stars
author: Rich B.

description: I really want to like this place especially after reading all the raving reviews about this place. Came here with bf some weeks back and we had the sausage housemade gnocchi and an ahi tuna dish and it must have been an off-night. Wasn't very memorable and service was spotty. Sigh....maybe better luck next time?
author: Yan M.

description: Went to street for the first time last night on NYE.  The Service was great and the food was interesting and good.  I'd like to go back on a non event night and see what its like, as there were seatings at 8 and 10 - we sat at 8.  Its a tight fit in there but for a place thats just blocks from home, i am sure we will return.  Looks like a fun place to go with friends.
author: Patrick V.

description:
Street is a noisy, local eatery and bar that consistently has good food and is a good value.  

We often get the burgers, which are always cooked to medium-rare perfection.  The new york steak is always perfectly cooked and served in generous portions, giving steak specialty places like Izzy's a run for their money.  And the wasabe-flavored pork chops, when they used to serve them, were some of the very best I've ever had.

I was hesitant to write a review, because this is a place that is thankfully devoid of tourists.  It beats all the Union Square tourist traps-- with the possible exception of Cortez-- hands down.  

The bar also serves a variety of wines and topshelf and house drinks.  A big, fat martini and a Street burger or steak is the perfect antidote to whatever ails ya.  We are pretty close to being regulars at this point, having been there probably over a dozen times, and it's always good.  That's why we keep going back.

Just beware that there is no valet parking, and street parking in this area is notoriously tough, especially on a Friday night or the weekends.  Also, they are open for dinner only and not lunch, and I believe that they are closed on Mondays.  But they do serve dinner till fairly late, and this makes it perfect for Sunday nights!
author: Dave N.

description: I had always wanted to try this place and finally went there after some drinks at Greens the other night. Mistake! The food was whatevs and for the price totally not worth it. I feel like I could have ordered the calamari and hummus plate at  TGIF and gotten the same thing. The Pate (one of the chef's specials) was gross. The only saving grace was my fiance's pappardelle pasta. AND some weird 8 year old was running around serving food. 100 bucks later and left feeling unsatisfied.
author: Cynthia S.

description: A friend brought me here for dinner and it has been one of my favorite places to eat. The staff is friendly and atmosphere is intimate. Fried Chicken Sundays are the best times to go..
author: Trish P.

description: I've been going to Street for quite a while now, and just revisited last night. It's always been a fantastic old standby for comfort food, in a cozy, neighborhood environment. The food is consistently good...and service is always spot on. One of my favorite spots on Polk!
author: Brianne K.

description: Fun drinks and atmosphere!  Wasn't much in the way of vegetarian options, but the food was definitely tasty and creative without being over the top.  Great for a classy yet casual dinner!  I had the seared tuna with mashed potatoes (this was back when I still ate fish) and it was delicious.
author: Tamara M.

description: This place has the best burger in the bay area. I know some people will swear by the Meister or Barney's but the Street burger is the best! Convert yourself and your friends now! The perk of this place . . . the other entrees are very tasty as well (see fried chicken, crab cakes and gnocchi). If you want a surprise, order the bread pudding or the sangria. Both are tops! Not to mention the crab cakes! "How could you not have a good time eatin' crab cakes?! I love 'em! They're phenomenal!" Parking sucks and sometimes there's a wait but a drink at the bar usually cures these problems.
author: Ryan M.

description: I love this place. It's usually relatively easy to get a seat, pretty casual, yet the food is awesome. The burgers are delicious and the last time I was there I had a seafood risotto with truffle oil and we had an heirloom tomato app--divine! Good selection of wine, a great place to go in Russian Hill for a date or with the girls!
author: michaela w.

description: Wonderful  risotto, pot-stickers, steak, signature fried chicken and yummy CORNBREAD (on Sundays only) and of course, the service. The only negatives: the ahi has never impressed me and the noise level is sometimes too much (pretty common in SF). However,  aside from that, Lynn (co-owner) and husband, have done a great job keeping this restaurant a favorite spot for good quality food.
author: Agent F.

description: This place is ok.  I've been twice and the food is fine, but not amazing.  Actually - do not get the risotto, it's not that good.
author: Sarah S.

description: Try the grilled Ahi and apple cake.  The spinach and beet salad was great too.  Top-notch service.  My only complaint is that it was cold inside, even with my jacket on.
author: Miss Purr fec t.

description:
Started going here early when they first opened this place.  Been going on / off now for awhile.  Always find the food solid, although frankly I almost always go with my standard - their burger...it is GREAT.
Always found the service terrific, and I think their prices are actually quite reasonable as compared to other key-location-situated restaurants.

Only suggestion is to bring a coat or sweater, it can be chilly in here, especially if you are sitting next to the door.
author: Jonathan H.

description:
This review is only for their burgers.

Best burgers in the city, period.  I've been looking for a great burger and now I've found it.  Meat cooked how you like it and great light crispy buns. 

The best burger in the city will run you $9.50 plus ~$1 for cheese or any other additions.  As noted by others, the fries seem like they are from the same potatoes as In-N-Out but cut thicker. My fries were too salty but I'm sure that fluctuates. A side of fries is $1.50 with a burger.

My search for the best burger in the city is over, even if it costs a little more.
author: Anders H.

description: The food here is good and the atmosphere is nice but it definitely isn't stellar. I like to think of it as a good back-up place that I can go to last minute and still get decent food. The drinks are definitely strong but that doesn't always mean good. The prices are higher than they should be for the type of food they are serving.
author: Lauren M.

description: Alright while in San Fran a couple weeks ago, I turned to yelp to find a good steak near my Hotel and all the reviews led me to this place.  So when we first walked into the place it was super crowded and there really wasnt an entry to stand and wait for a hostess.  Finally a lady said it would be about 15mins and she ushered us to a standing area in the back  to where we could order a couple of beers.  After wishing they had a TV for the past 15mins we finally got seated, and as i mentioned before this place was super packed.  I got crammed into a little seat where peeps were basically standing on top of me at the bar.  Luckily for me they left shortly after i sat.  On to the food, we both got the new york steak and all i can say is it was fantastic.  I just wish it would of been hotter, it tasted almost as it sat for a bit before we got it, but i just ate it super fast to make sure it was warm.  As i said before the food was fantastic, and the waitress was great.  This place could use a TV and some more space...but its definitely crowded for a reason, and you know its good if its crowded so thats always a good sign for your first time to a place, but if i had to deal with that everytime i would probably be frustrated.  4 Stars for Great food, but could definitely benefit from an entry and maybe a TV at the bar, for while your waiting.
author: Mike M.

description:
it had been awhile since i'd be to Street...and now i'm bummed i wasted so much time.
service = great
atmosphere & vibe = cool, dark, comfortable
but, people, the burger...the burger!  it is divine.
great little neighborhood place and perfect for lingering over a few glasses of wine (red, of course, to go with the burger) and great conversation.
author: Lija H.

description: I ate there two nights ago some of my employes work there too. We had the spinach salad and the cheese souflee, very tasty and light. For entree We had Grill steack with fries. we had a nice evening I will be back.
author: Mattin N.

description:
i got parking out in front and no wait at this establishment...that's an automatic 3 stars right there!  of course, it was stuporbowl sunday,  anyway, i just ran a half-marathon that am, and the game was good, so i was ready to treat myself to a burger.  this place has good service...they were super nice....okay, maybe no need to up-sell me on the burger condiments, but it wasn't obnoxious or anything, so i forgive!...i'm surprised the place doesn't charge extra for the bun.  but i digress...

the burger...super yummy...big, juicy, and butter on the buns!  pure genius!!!.....the fries (those of you that know me, know that i am a french fry connoiseur...very crispy and salted perfectly, and just about everything you would ever want from a deep fried tuber...i actually prefer really thin fries (higher fried goodness to surface area ratio), but these were good....

my friend got the fried chicken, which was really good as well.  she was kind enough to give me the wings, which scored her a few extra points in my book...again, higher fried goodness to surface area ratio...the chicken, not my friend...

i like you street, i will come back.  hopefully you will have another parking spot waiting for me in front, and a nice empty table (not near the door...brrrrrrrr) too!  and maybe you will even have some lighting in the back so that i don't accidently grope anyone as i'm trying to feel my way to the bathroom....
author: Miss P.

description: We came here last Saturday and had a great meal. Walked in around 730, sat at the bar for a glass of wine and were seated within 15 minutes. The food was really tasty. We had a mixed salad and calamari to start. Main dishes were halibut and the gnocchi delight with sausage. Wow. And the bill was really reasonable! Everyone said great things about Street and it lived up to it's reputation for me.
author: Shannon C.

description:
If I could rate this place zero stars (meaning "will never return"), I would. It gets a failing grade.

Arrived to meet two friends who were having dinner, I was only planning to have drinks with them. The place was busy but not packed, and I sat at a 2-person table next to my friends. When I only ordered a cocktail, the waiter very aggressively grabbed the place setting and menu from in front of me. I noticed him being charming with other patrons. When the bill came at the end, he overcharged me and one of my friends and, when I pointed out the mistake, he took personal offense, saying "I had nothing to do with this." Um, actually you did! We paid our bill and sat at the table for a while longer finishing our drinks, and since we were paying customers, we felt this wasn't pushing it. But the very snooty hostess was hovering the entire time, casting passive-aggressive smiles and glares our way. Eventually she said to us, "Excuse me ladies, can I make you more comfortable at the bar?" WOW. No thanks.
author: Johanna K.

description:
For me, this place is just did not do it for me. My boyfriend wanted to try this place and he brought me along. We looked at the menu from the window and it looked decent, so I said why not. We were seated immediately to a table that was way too tightly enclosed for anyone (and I'm a skinny guy). However, the waitress did assist us in moving the table and getting us seated so that wasn't bad.

We started with the zucchini fritters and they were really good, I can't complain. My boyfriend got wine and he didn't like it.

For our entree, I got the gnocchi with calabrese sausage and my boyfriend got the grilled ahi. Mine was nothing spectacular by any means; I mean come on, if you're charging 20 bucks for a plate, it better be damn good but it wasn't. My boyfriend's ahi was overcooked (or so he said) and his mash potatoes were flavorless.

For dessert, I got the chocolate cake and my boyfriend got the peanut butter ice cream. My chocolate cake was like something that was pulled out of the refrigerator, tossed in the microwave, and a scoop of ice cream was thrown on top. I was shocked to see something like this costing 6 bucks. My boyfriend did like his ice cream though.

Overall, I would have given this place one star if the service was mediocre and if the fritters were bad, but they weren't and they were the only two highlights for me at this place. If you're willing to shell out $30+ on a mediocre meal, then knock yourself out, but I definitely don't see myself coming back here again. I would much rather go to an Olive Garden and spend less than half of what I spent here and still get better quality food.
author: Richard C.

description: The all-American, comfort food menu looked pretty amazing, but I like to keep things simple--so of course I got the burger and fries. Crispy toasted bun with a soft, plump patty in between. Perfection. Generous, American portions, too ;) The dim lighting, candles and couple-dominated clientele didn't really make me feel good about being single, though. Ha.
author: Natalie T.

description: The best burger in town, hands down. So juicy that you don't even get annoyed that tomatoes and cheese cost a dollar extra, each. Absolutely worth it. I also recommend enjoying a cocktail and the art. In that order.
author: Katie T.

description: We had to wait outside because there was no room inside, which wasn't good because it was pretty cold.  The food was pretty good.  The service was just ok.  It won't really be one of those dining experiences that will stick out in my mind.  :(
author: Rise G.

description: great little find just walking around Polk street exploring. food was yummy with just the right portions and the drinks were fabulous! wait staff was friendly and made the dining experience that much more enjoyable! i am looking forward to it becoming my new neighborhood go to spot!
author: ronda a.

description: One of my favorites Live in the hood for years - best burger in SF, fried chix on Sundays & Bread Pudding is insane.
author: jordan n.

description: Went with my girlfriend's family, and had the fantastic fried chicken.  I also got to taste everyone else's food and it was all amazingly well-executed.  The service was as friendly as it gets.  The atmosphere is also great.  I'll be a regular here.
author: Chris  F.

description: Can't say enough good things about this restaurant!  While a little loud due to all the conversations in a small space, that added to the atmosphere.  Specialty drinks, appetizers, entrees, and deserts.  Awesome!
author: Beth K.

description: This place is awesome! Never disappoints. I love the staff and the food is amazing. Best burger in town!!!!
author: Jenine L.

description: I love this place!  Why?  Cause it's in my hood, first and foremost.  Second, they make a MEAN burger, and my "mean" I mean  a Wicked buger!  Sooooo good...wouldn't recommend ordering the burger on a first date, however, if you're feeling brave, it's very easy to man handle if you cut it in half...oh and if you like avocado, I would say order some AVO on that biatch!
author: Danielle V.

description:
this is my kinda menu, my kinda place.  although it was pretty cold inside, overall very decent.

wine - a sangiovese from alexander valley.  went well with everything (except dessert obviously)

starters - broccoli and cheddar soup...it tasted perfect, although it could have been extra hot.  goat cheese souflee...spot on, with mixed greens and a crostini smeared with olive tapenade.

main - gnocchi with red sauce and house made caprese sausage...so this was one of the best entrees i have had in a long time.  the gnocchi werent the best i ever had, but they were still excellent.  it was all about the sausage.  absolutely perfect.

dessert - peanut butter ice cream means im happy.
author: Robert S.

description: I do believe Street just cooked up the best seared yellowtail tuna in my life tonight. Absolutely bursting with flavor, served up with a side of green beans and mashed potatoes. With each bite I was caught off guard by the bold flavor, and at the finish, felt confident in sharing with friends that indeed it was fantastic, perhaps the best ever. Everyone else commented that they also enjoyed their dish (mainly the strip steak) as well. An excellent meal.
author: Jason B.

description: Once again dissapointed with a restaurant found on yelp, guess I should read past all the 5 star reviews. Got here and realized right away how cramped everything seemed. The waitress seated the 3 of us (more like squeezed us) directly in between a guy alone and the back side of people at the bar while plenty of other more roomy tables were available. The tables literally have a hands length of space between neighboring tables. We finally asked to be moved, and then ordered. I got the burger which was one of the best burgers I've had and my sister in law said the same. My wife ordered the clams as an appetizer and a salad...of course they brought out the appetizer with all of our meals. After we all had our plates in front of us, the waitress said "oh I forgot your salad" not realizing we literally had no space on the small table for a 4 th plate.. so she brought it back and squeezed the salad on the corner of the table giving us zero space to even eat. Nice. Throughout our meal we were continuously interrupted, pestered, and rushed by the waiters and waitresses as they aimlessly loomed around our table to see if they could take anything...and then just stood there by the table looking out the window when they had nothing to do (really anoying). The waitress went to grab my wifes plate to take it away before she was done (yet again) and got an unpleasant "I'm not done" response from the wifey. I couldn't help but laugh cuz I think the waitress was pretty close to losing a hand by then lol. Overall the food is good, but the staff is clueless. Won't be going back again unless I get a burger to go.
author: Nate G.

description: We had dinner here on a Friday night. No reservations needed but it was only 7pm and we scored the last open table available. Standard California-American-Asian influenced cuisine. We started off with pork and shrimp wontons, which were okay at best. I had the crab cake dinner, which was delicious: the perfect blend of crunchy exterior and quality crab in the center. The BF had the prime rib. I tasted it and almost wished I had ordered it myself. We got the peanut butter ice cream for dessert, really made the meal and wished I saved room for it. The portions were healthy and the ambiance was urban and romantic with open exposed walls and dimly lit.
author: Heather A.

description: Made a recent visit to Street after a long break and loved it as much as ever.  There is a good variety of food choices and the service is good.  I had the new big salad with steak which was very good.  The Sangoivese that I had by the glass was decent.  We were seated quickly in the front window which I also liked.  This is on my list of key neighborhood restaurants for Russian Hill.
author: Tim S.

description: Don't go here if you're going to eat healthy. Go for pate, fried calimari, fried chicken, burgers, and lots of cocktails. If you commit to forgo thinking about calories and just enjoy the goodness, you will love Street.
author: Sarah R.

description:
street--i loved you so much, and then you had to go and hurt my feelings. 

this is one of the few restaurants in SF that i go back to. you can count on great food, reasonable prices and a really nice wait staff. soooo....

imagine my complete and utter dismay when i dined there last week and was treated pretty rudely. first off, i do give them credit for apologizing and getting us some free wine while we waited. but what happened NEVER should have happened. my group was the first group there waiting for a table. another group walked in about ten minutes after we did. they had one more person than we did. also they were older, like with gray hair and wrinkles older. i wonder if this had something to do with it? 

we had been told by one of their long-time waiters (who is super duper nice, by the way) that we would be seated first since we were there first. makes sense right? imagine my shock when another of their staff (a manager i think, though i had never seen her before) sat the other party before us! when i asked her why she did that when we were there first she looked at me blandly and replied that their entire party was there first. (which was complete bullshit.) then she said sorry like she really didn't mean it. 

i walked away for a few minutes, but my blood was boiling. and it doesn't typically do that. so i went back. when i do things like this the husband just sort of shakes his head. i think it reminds him of when his mom used to get mad and he was like eight, and he just had to deal with it. 

i was good tho, i didn't yell. i just told her that i was really upset still, that it was terrible service since we'd been told by another waiter that we would be seated first. she apologized again--but it just felt like she really didn't give 2 f*cks. or even one for that matter. altho a few minutes later she came over and poured us all more wine while we continued to wait. maybe her conscience finally kicked in. i don't know. but i forgive her. and i will go back, cause their food is great. and usually they are too.
author: rachel p.

description: I had a great steak here! Both visits, it was cooked to perfection, good booze selection, and we were able to eat fairly quickly on a Friday night!
author: Rene D.

description: Not bad, not good. Drinks were strong, and after 2 rum and cokes, the food was really the least of my concerns. It was just a way to kill time until we really wanted to start drinking.
author: Srinivas R.

description: It's a bit cramped here, but don't let that stop you from coming by Sunday night for an amazing fried chicken dinner (and be sure to get the equally amazing optional cornbread). That's Sundays only, kids. Someone in our group gave the peanut butter ice cream two thumbs up.
author: Maximillian M.

description: "Strong Food, Good Drinks" - I actually like their food much better than their house-made fruit-infused drinks, but this is a favorite spot of mine. Great food, fun atmosphere, wonderfully friendly staff.  Their Sirloin Burger is the BEST burger I have ever had ( you *must* try it), their soups are always awesome, their bread pudding will make a fan out of any skeptic and of course their fried chicken dinner on sundays is always something to look forward to. All around great spot.
author: B R.

description: I usually don't opt for fried fare, but GET THE FRIED CHICKEN if it's on the menu!  Good luck finding parking if you drive.
author: Angie C.

description: Great atmosphere and great food. This is down the street from my place and it is the most low key place on the block.  It has a very cool vibe and great food.  The menu is great, I have had several things now from the burger to the tuna and I have enjoyed each one.
author: Jaime C.

description: I've been here twice. A few of my friends live in the neighborhood at eat here all the time. It's great, I really love the neighborhood atmosphere they've got going on. The steak is awesome....and massive. Share with a friend. I have a friend who always gets the burger. Haven't had it yet, but it def. looks burgerlicious.....
author: Emily L.

description: The burger everyone raves about really is that good.  The other stuff I've had has been serviceable.  They've got some cool cocktails made with their own infused vodkas that are worth a look.  Wines by the glass are average and overpriced.  But oh, that burger.
author: Ficus K.

description: I didn't realize that this place has been open as long as it has.  It is a great place.  The service is very friendly, the food is made with happiness in mind.
author: Thadd L.

description: Found through Yelp...again.  Atmosphere is great and food good.  I went with the filet mignon,  and those around me had a burger that looked even better.  The price is right, unless you order multiple drinks and a few cocktails, then you will pay.
author: Andrew R.

description: I wanted to do something for M. to celebrate the year anniversary of the day we met.  Sadly, we'd met at a Marina bar, and I just didn't have it in me to go back to the triangle.  He has a thing for steak, so I took him to Street.  We shared the goat cheese appetizer, which was so rich and creamy, I wanted to curl up and take a nap in it.  As expected,M ordered the strip steak with gorgonzola butter, and says that it was one of the best he'd had in a long time.  I had crab cakes, which were also awesome.  The wine list was decent as well, and the prices are totally reasonable.  All in all, a great meal. We will definitely be back.
author: Amanda B.

description: Delicious food, accommodating staff, decent prices. Great for groups!
author: Amy J.

description: had their burger which was good, but not the best i've had.  cute restaurant and has decent american fare dishes.  it's a decent option for me since it's in my neighborhood but i wouldn't trek to go there again.
author: Helen T.

description: I was not too thrilled with this place.  The atmosphere is fun and we had no problem getting a table, but once we were seated it took so long for a waiter to come ask our orders that I finally had to ask a server if we could order.  I ordered some type of chicken dish with a mustard sauce and when it came out it was not at all what I expected.  The chicken was ground up into a sausage and had a very weird texture.  One of the people I was with had the Ahi and loved it.  For dessert, we split the Warm Chocolate Cake which was to die for- definitely would get that again!  Overall, the place was okay- good atmosphere but poor service and a little pricey.
author: Caroline Z.

description: I like this place.  I just wish they would switch up the simple menu.  Thye don't have that many fish and veggie options for dinner.
author: Tracy M.

description: A great place for dinner on its own, but they serve fried chicken, cornbread and cole slaw on Sunday nights that is finger licking good.
author: Raymond M.

description: A friend and I showed up at 9:30 on a Wednesday night and we were able to get the last open table. The menu is what drew us in, featuring basics with a twist. We both started with a good-sized salad, mine the mixed greens-it was yummy! My friend had the spinach salad, and she thought it was terrificc. We split the crab cakes, which were good, but very hot-spicy and in temperature. We had dessert, and split the bread pudding, it was tasty but a bit rich. The service was prompt, and the interior is great. The artist that they are currently showing is fantastic.
author: Leesa P.

description:
The fried chicken dinner on Sundays is amazing.  Definitely add the cornbread - it's the best cornbread I've ever had (sorry, Grandma).  The mixed greens with goat cheese custard is to die for.  I really loved the pork chop and mashed potatoes with cabbage.  As someone said, the bread pudding here is unlike any other.  It's in a league of its own.  The food is delicious, not necessarily for the health nut.  This isn't a sally salad chick restaurant - as they say, "strong food, real drinks."  

Best of all, great staff (our server last time was really awesome), family-owned, and inexpensive.  A long-time favorite of mine.

UPDATE - 9/2/2007:   I had to dock Street a star, as much as it smarts to do so.  My last 3 experiences (I've probably been about 20 times overall) have not lived up to the 5 stars I previously bestowed.  First, my husband's Bloody Mary a few visits ago was made with grapefruit juice!  When he complained, they brought another with grapefruit juice!  I know it's dark in there, but come on.  He ended up getting a beer, and Bloody Marys at Street are his raison d'etre - so he was sad.  The next time, my Wild Thing, my favorite drink in town, containing cherry infused vodka and a "secret ingredient" I know to be their amazing Anaheim Habanero infused vokda, was served without the Habanero vodka.  When I asked the young cheeky bartender chick, I was informed I was wrong about the Habenero.  Huh?  And our food on the same trip was not very good - it pains me to say that after nearly 4 faithful years of attendance, but so it was.  On my most recent trip, my Wild Thing did include the Habanero Vodka, and I got confirmation I was right that it's supposed to be in the Wild Thing.  Still, it took 15 minutes for our cocktails to arrive, then the waitress forgot to order our appetizer, so we ended up foregoing it.  (Meanwhile, the couple next to us ordered after us, but got all drinks AND their calamari appetizer, and ate and drank much of those things, before anyone bothered to put a drink in front of us.)  The forsaken app had been the goat cheese custard, about which I fantasized over an entire year of bike touring, so I was pretty disappointed about that..  While a brief apology was offered for these TWO significant screwups, nothing else was.  I've gone there for nearly 4 years, and having everything screwed up without any offer of compensation (hello, one free drink would have convinced me you cared???  after 2 screwups, shouldn't you offer something to show you actually care?) was disheartening.  Street, what's going on?  I know you still have it in you, 'cause the food is improving again.  I'm really hoping you step things back up, because you seem like nice folks and I've truly enjoyed your place over the years.  I still plan to go back - too many delicious and fun times have preceded, and I believe things are on the upswing at Street.
author: Jes H.

description: I met someone who shared a love for cheese and she told me I needed to try this place for its steak with the gorgonzola butter. I had also heard it had a good burger so it wasn't hard to get my boyfriend to go. Unfortunately, being on that side of Polk, parking was a nightmare! We probably drove around for half an hour before we found a spot. Luckily, there wasn't a wait even tho the place is kinda small. The steak wasn't bad, but I really did enjoy the taste of the gorgonzola butter melting over it. My boyfriend's burger was pretty good too, but our favorite thing was the apple cake. It was a nice change from the typical apple pie and was a great end. From what we were told by the people in the table next to us, we gotta go back and try the fried chicken.
author: Kim C.

description:
this place was delicious! started with the fried calamari and spicy hummus appetizer. the calamari is really lightly battered and fried so it doesn't come out super greasy and you don't feel so bad eating fried food. instead of the tradtional  tartar sauce it comes with a light thai dipping sauce. the hummus was also delicious and served with warm pita bits. 

then we had the burger, which yes, i agree with other yelpers is scrumptious! juicy and tasty. the chicken breast entree is tasty but doesn't wow. it was very good though. 

our server rafael was great, very personable and i love that he's honest about the cocktails and dishes we asked about. he'd let us know which ones he wasn't 'crazy about.' which is great. i hate it when i go somewhere and you ask the server about things and everything is 'really good. oh that one is great.' 

street was definitely a neighborhood restaurant and i'll definitely be back!
author: Angela W.

description: Great price and service for pseudo-gourmet gringo food. Incredibly hospitable service. Only gripe: bring your nightlight and blanky because you eat in the dark in this place. Cave dwellers won't have a problem. Otherwise, fab comfy food!!
author: Johnny C.

description: Street is a sleeper hit for me. I had no expectations of this place, but they had good wine and surprisingly awesome food for a tiny little "bar that has food" place. I would even go as far as to call it a restaurant. The hummus is amazing, which the waitress directed us towards, and therefore the service was great too. I will definitely be back! It had a lively, fun vibe to it!
author: Jamie C.

description: No reservations taken, but the wait during prime time on a Friday night couldn't have been more than 10 - 15 minutes. And once we were seated and ordered, the kitchen and servers perfectly spaced our courses so we never had to wait for anything. Me and my man shared an app, had our own mains and shared a dessert and I ended up pleasantly full. Flash fried calamari for app was standard, but the "Asian" dip with it was a delightful change-up. Yummy prime rib goodness for main course. Highlight was definitely the apple cake with caramel sauce and vanilla bean ice cream to finish. So good.
author: Carissa R.

description: I went here with two friends on a nice, warm sunday evening. We were seated immediately by a friendly hostess at a table by the window (+ all the stars right there). Neither of my friends enjoyed their food very much, and I have to agree with the one who got the homemade sausage with gnocchi, it just was not that good. I, however, LOVED my risotto with shrimp. Good lord, I would eat that every night if I could. Clearly, this place has some hit-and-miss dishes, but I would come back for that risotto, for sure. The decor was cute, and it seemed to be a nice balance between casual but still upscale. Definitely going on my list of cool Polk street haunts.
author: Jenna W.

description: The burger still reigns supreme, however, on my last visit I tried the homemade pasta which rivals anything served on Columbus Ave...
author: Nicolas H.

description: Hip place, decent for a weekday, but don't think I'll return.  The gnocchi was a bit bland and the accompanying sausage felt undercooked.  My wife's risotto was definitely better (lots of tasty seafood), but overly salted.  For the price, I think you can do better at a number of places down the street.
author: Graham M.

description: I would like this restaurant if it is in suburb, but I'd say no in the city. Everything is too salty and ingredients are okay quality.
author: Sachiko M.

description: This place has the worst service that I've eve been to. I came here with my boyfriend last night and we had to wait for at least 40 mins for our meal. The kitchen had forgotten our order and the waitor had to lie about the kitchen being slow; meanwhile, everyone else around us had their food way before us.  The food was not even that good. I would not recommend anyone to come here.  They have the ruddest manager ever. If you want lousy service and bad food then this is the place for you.
author: Mina T.

description: This is a fantastic neighborhood place.  Street serves up comfort food cooked with love and technique with super high quality ingredients.  The service is warm and attentive.  Paulette makes you feel like a local after one trip to Street.  If you're lucky enough to find these menu items served the day you go, try the calamari with Thai dipping sauce, fried chicken (skinless in a buttermilk breading) and the crab/sausage pasta.  Knocking off one star due price (its worth it but not a value) and lack of sub $30 wine options.
author: David C.

description:
I think if you go here you need to get the burger.  The friend I was with got it (meanwhile I was trying to be "healthy" by getting a mixed salad and the won tons - steamed, not fried) and he left me have a bite of it -- WOW, I don't even eat beef on a regular basis but that thing was good (and HUGE).  
We shared the calamari (so much for being healthy) which although was fried was surprisingly light and had a really good flavor.
The service was great.  No reservations at 8:00 on a Friday night and was quickly seated.  The bartender was also great -- when I was trying to pick between several of the house-infused vodkas she was more than willing to let me sample a few (I thought the sour cherry was the best of what I tried).  
I saw multiple groups/couples bring in their own bottles so I am not sure what Street's deal is on a corkage fee but it must be non-existent or minimal because too many people were bringing in bottles for it to be the standard fare.  Regardless of Street's corkage situation, they have an ample wine selection, including a good mix of wines by the glass.
author: Katie P.

description: This place is Deelish..had the Risotto that was YUM (Jon B).  Hummous was good...but not GOOOOD ...Great bar...this is a smaller rest - but nice neighborhood spot for Italian and more...you can get a jalapeno-tini and about 5 other wild ones
author: Rob C.

description: The Polk/Green Street area has undergone some nice upgrades in the past few years, giving more room for boutiques and mid/upscale eateries.  When my spouse and I stumbled into Street we were welcomed by the friendly staff and had two nice cocktails. I ordered a cucumber infused martini, and he ordered a Dark and Stormy, both were perfect.   I ordered the daily special of prime rib which was a reasonable portion and was cooked perfectly, (medium rare) with a delicious horseradish cream, and my spouse had a mixed grill of house-made sausage and pork chops which was also delicious.    Overall, a great neighborhood restaurant without any pretensions, we'd definitely come back!
author: QuodE D.

description: The bomb spot.  Always a crowd waiting to get in.  The cook is great - he recognizes you and gives you a "hey what's up!!!" whenever he sees you.  Food is fantastic, ambiance is perfect.  I love that they have alcohol soaked in fruits in jars overhead the bar.  Great touch...
author: Nathalie C.

description: I went to Street on a Wednesday for the first time and the food was great!  We started with a Pomegranate martini and the heirloom tomato salad with goat cheese, yum!  then we switched to a glass of red vino and had the Crab/Rock Shrimp cakes, which had a little tang to them, very good... We sat at the bar and the bartender was very attentive and nice.  I will definitely be back!
author: Michele G.

description: OK, I pretty much review only places I love, so everything is 5 stars.  I love Street because of the wait staff, who are ALWAYS nice and remember you; the gorgonzola steak which is so yummy; the fried chicken on Sundays that is AMAZING (definitely get the sour cream corn bread); the spanish wines; the mango martinis; and I just recently had the most awesome appetizer - caprese salad with heirloom tomatoes.  Maybe my favorite thing in the world now is eating a really great steak with red wine.  This place has that.
author: Priya R.

description: This place is so meh. The food is below average but the location is pretty happening which is why people probably go here. Won't be back.
author: Sadia J.

description:
I never noticed this place and I live a block away and walk by it all the time.  Its right next to the Buccaneer so maybe that explains why I pass by so quickly and without a second look. 
But last week my friend suggested it and we gave it a try.
The duck confit appetizer left something to be desired, but the rest of the food was very good.
The butternut squash soup and the bolognese entree were both very tasty.  My friend had the salmon and said that she enjoyed it as well.  Their specialty cocktails were creative and mostly yummy, too. I had one with blood orange that was good, but a little too sweet, but the next one that I tried (can't quite remember what it was called) was good.  
Our server was great.  We took forever to choose what to eat and she did not seem annoyed at all.  She had some recommendations and was very helpful when we asked questions.  
Overall, I really enjoyed this place.  The prices are a little higher than I would typically spend on a casual weeknight dinner, but the experience was worth it.
author: Stephanie S.

description: I have to review this place because they need to get their act together. The food - total rip off for this city. I can make better food at home. Their service was shitty. Really shitty. I can totally understand why people are into this place as a date spot - the waitresses, and there were 3 plus a bartender on a not-so-packed Tuesday night, were very busy chatting with each other while I was hoping just to get some water. First - she asked us for something from the bar and we said no. She walked off BEFORE we could even ask for water. Took awhile to come back. It was highly annoying (sorry I didn't want a drink!). Our appetizer came out AFTER our main course. HOW?? WHY?? I had ordered a steak salad. The salad was very obviously not the ingredients on the menu - i.e. the salad had cheap substitutions. I hate when this happens. Don't charge $20 for a salad that should have heirloom tomatoes and potatoes on it and then obviously substitute. I might have said something too, except the waitresses were not being freindly or in any way attentive. At one point a waitress, not ours (ours was no where in sight) came over and opened the window right behind me without saying anything. There was a super cold SF fog draft! So I shut it. She comes running out "I'm sorry but the kitchen is really hot right now!!!" and I was like ummm sorry? What am I supposed to do - pay an arm an a leg for a dumb salad and freeze? Also, my dining partner totally got sick that night. This place sucked for us. I understand it might not always suck, but if anything I hope that other diners out there feel me - substitutions are not ok!! Not at finer establishments in the agricultural capital of the west.
author: K T.

description: The food here was good and the service was fast and attentive, albeit a little disruptive at times.  I had the gnocchi and the fried calamari, both of which were enjoyable.
author: Kelvin K.

description: Everyone loves getting recognized by staff and a consistent menu.  That's what you get from Street - one of my favorite neighborhood go-to's. The burger with Gruyere is absolutely perfect. Their soups (right now is butternut squash) are always delightful & the homemade peanut butter ice cream with mocha meringue has the perfect and delicious creamy-crunch balance. Hummus, Calabrese sausage with gnocchi and the prime rib can't be beat either. Try a Cherry Soda cocktail- their sour cherry infused vodka with a splash of 7up.  It's an absolute tasty treat.   Go before 7 for a table.  It can pack in quickly.
author: Natalie P.

description:
street was ok.  maybe i need to try the burger.  

i wasn't that hungry so i ordered the risotto with shrimp. it was good, little salty but overall ok.

the vibe was good and overall it's a good place to go if you're going out on polk st after.
author: cristina t.

description:
Typical SF restaurant - a chicken dish, a hamburger, some steak, some tuna, and a few signature appetizers.  The food is good, the decor gets the job done, and the staff are friendly.  It can get busy later at night, but even when its busy, the service doesn't suffer too much.

I've had the hamburger, and the tuna. Both met my needs.

Good job Street.
author: Ian C.

description:
We visited Street this Sunday and arrived close to the closing of the kitchen. There were 7 of us and the waitress was very accommodating. We didn't order drinks, so I can't rate those, but the food, for the most part was good. The portion sizes were about right. I ordered the Ahi with green beans and mashed potatoes. The Ahi was good but there was waaay too much aoili so that had to be scraped off. They lose a star for their mashed potatoes. I hate to say it, but they truly tasted like the just-add-water potatoes from a box. The BF ordered the fried chicken and thoroughly enjoyed it. Others ordered the risotto and steak salad- all good there.
We shared the peanut butter ice cream, chocolate cake and bread pudding desserts. All were fantastic. It would be ideal for the chocolate cake to come with the peanut butter ice cream rather than vanilla, just saying.
Service was fantastic- water glasses were always full and our waitress was very sweet. I'd go back but I wouldn't order anything with mashed potatoes.
author: Liz L.

description:
BUMMER.

Went here once, and really liked it. Thought my steak was tasty, enjoyed the beet salad and loved their pork belly. I was super happy to come back again.

But unfortunately, the past few times my husband or I have been - the food has been really lacking.

This week - The woman who fixed me a Manhattan at the bar was incredibly sweet and the cocktail was great.

But down hill from there - specifically the lentils under the pork belly were extremely undercooked (ick.) and my huband's gnocchi was very heavy & potatoe-y. Gnocchi can be light and fluffy and this stuff just sank your palate and coated your tongue. The tomato sauce was bland and didn't add the acidity to balance the pasta.

I enjoyed my steak and the beet salad is done very well.

One big miss was that my husband ordered their hot cider and really didn't  like it. It was cold when he got it...and he tried to get the waitress' attention, to no avail She came by and just picked it up about 10 mins later- no question about why he had barely touched it.

The table service and food were lacking, and I'm disappointed. I thought for sure this was going to be a consistent place!
author: Lady L.

description: Stopped by Street over the weekend with my boyfriend in hopes of scoring some dessert...we SCORED! As usual we bickered about what dessert to order before finally deciding on the braeburn apple cake. A well-sized slice of of apple cake greeted us with a perfect scoop of vanilla ice cream drizzled with caramel. The main reason this was not my first choice is that usually cake=dry. Definitely not the case here. The cake was unbelievable and even though I hate the word moist I will say it for the cake...it was moist. If there food is anything like their dessert then they have found a fan in me.
author: Sugey G.

description: Good, reliable, American fare in a comfortable setting.  The burger here is the best thing on the menu, and the lemon cheesecake is pretty damn good too.  I never need a reservation, but always seem to grab one of the last tables, though it never seems too full.  The salad with gorgonzola is good too.  We always have a nice meal here.
author: Ashley S.

description:
I really like this place. The food is good, they have a nice variety of options for a relatively small menu (it's rare that you see Grilled Hawaiian Ahi Tuna on the same menu as Fried Chicken, but somehow it works). My ahi tuna was melt-in-your-mouth perfection...done exactly to my liking and with just the right amount of seasoning. So many restaurants overseason fish to the point that you can't even tell what you're eating, but Street does a good job of keeping their flavors simple and letting quality ingredients speak for themselves. 
I was also really impressed with our server when we were here last-- we were there with a group of five people and we were trying to decide on what bottle of wine to order. She offered to bring over a taste of three different wines for us to try before we ordered a bottle of it. SO nice, totally unexpected and allowed us to order a bottle that we knew we all liked. 

My one gripe with Street is that they don't accept reservations, which is why I dinged them 1 star. I can say we would honestly eat here so much more often if we could reserve a table and know we wouldn't have to wait. Something to consider, Street!
author: Leah K.

description:
This is a tough one...but here's the scoop on Street: 

Food A 
Service D
Wine D 

I've been here a number of times. My most recent visit was typical. The food was great. We went for Dine About Town, a promotion for which their menu prices aren't really suited. Basically, if you put their most expensive appetizer, entree and dessert together you save a few bucks--and that appeared to be about what they were offering. So, we ordered off the main menu, which was fine as their food is so good. The appetizers were good. We all had their famous Fried Chicken for entree, which was superb! For dessert, we shared the bread pudding, which also totally rocked. Really tasty! 

Unfortunately, the wine we ordered with dinner was awful. It wasn't corked, but just so lame I left wondering if the person putting their list together cares about this important part of the dining experience. 

Anyway, the service that night was terrible. Our waiter did all the stuff that sucks like ignoring our table when having long chats with other guests, failing to fill water glasses, etc. etc. They were busy, so at the end of the meal we finally got her attention--and were clearly being rushed to get out so she could turn the table. What really bugged me though is that one of our party members asked if she could get a side of lentils that weren't on the menu--but were being served as a side with another dish. The waiter grumpily went back to ask if that was possible and returned to brusquely tell us "No." I guess it saved them some hassle, but in this city with so many options, I certainly won't rush back to Street if they're so inflexible and rude with customers.
author: Dave B.

description: If you enjoy fried chicken and mashed patatoes, go to Street on Sundays. It melts in your mouth!! Street also offers everything from steak to gnocci to ahi tuna...plus a super friendly staff.
author: A D.

description: You would probably walk right by this place, and never know it was there...but trust me...don't. This place is very cozy, and the food is wonderful. Even the fried food (such as calamari) was a nice "clean" fry...fresh oil and high heat! I tried the tomato soup, which was perfect, and the spinach, beet and goat cheese salad...no complaints at all! I would be willing to go back there and try everything on the menu, as I was dining with someone who goes there 3 nights or more a week and raves about everything! The place is run by a very pleasant husband and wife (the husband cooks) and he is very passionate about food, and it shows! I have also heard this is the BEST, BEST, BEST place to get a burger in town...I think most nights they run out!?
author: Rita M.

description: I enjoyed my dinner (crab cakes and fries), but honestly I enjoyed the juicy conversation of the couple sitting next to me more.  You're so crammed in that you can't help but hear (and listen) to what the people around you are talking about.  They seemed like a really nice couple, I hope they make it work.  My husband got the house made sausage and gnocchi and was underwhelmed.
author: Alison P.

description:
This place is FABULOUS!!!!

Order the Ahi Tuna. Its absolutely delicious. I'm still craving it! The crab cakes and calamari are also incredibly tasty. The wine is very well priced and allllll of the desserts are yummy. The cocktails are also very well made... LUV THIS PLACE!!!


Only complaint: The space is tight and the server asked us to keep the noise level down, when were really weren't very loud to begin with.
author: Vic M.

description: Crowded on the weekends with a very loud dinner setting.  Seating is jammed next to each other, with no personal space.  Food is very good, but a bit pricey.
author: Eric W.

description:
I really like Street. The food is very tasty, and seems appropriately/ reasonably priced, the staff has always been nice, the bar is fully stocked - and they have lots of fun drink suggestions, or you can go with your standard martini. Dinner at the bar is great - you can chat with the friendly bartenders (if you want to - they're not pushy) and you get super fast service. The only downside is that it can get really loud, and the chairs aren't all that comfortable - meaning, it's not a place I'd want to go for dinner and then end up staying for a bunch of drinks. But they probably don't want me to stay for many drinks, either! They've got tables to turn over!
I recommend this spot.
author: Jessica F.

description:
I have had some good times in this fine neighborhood establishment. Granted, I have not extensively sampled the menu (read: I only go here when my craving for high-quality red meat overpowers me and I race here to devour their burger and imbibe several cocktails in the process). 

Anyway, the dark loud cozy atmosphere is great, although I think I prefer sitting at the bar to sitting at the tiny tables- the bartenders are super-sweet and attentive, and I think the acoustics are slightly more favorable near the back. 

This is my favorite neighborhood weeknight treat- I always have a great time, but the cozy atmosphere and accurately billed "strong drinks" make it such a chill fun experience.
author: Jessi C.

description: I love this place. Everything I have had here is so good (and any place that serves tasty fries always gets extra points from me). This place infuses its own vodka and their martinis are great. My fav is the apricot martini which comes with a dried apricot.
author: Teresa B. H.

description: OMG, Street was amazing! My husband and I were visiting from LA and not sure what to do for dinner. I hopped on yelp and low and behold came across Street Restaurant, 2141 Polk Street, San Francisco. Their motto is "Strong Food/Real Drinks" and they lived up to it!  It is now on our list and I want to go back to SF now just to eat there. It's a comfortable restaurant, owner works the dining room, staff is great. Plenty to order from the wine list. We started sharing their Pork & Shrimp Won-tons and Flash Fried Calamari, we then shared the Local Mixed Greens apples, Gorgonzola, spiced pecans and sherry vinaigrette salad. I ordered the Hand Cut Fettuccine with John's Sicilian Sausage and White Prawns and my husband ordered the John's Sicilian Sausage house made gnocchi, San marzano tomato sauce & reggiano. They had a amazing Peanut Butter ice cream with mocha merange'. Can't wait to visit again.
author: Beth G.

description: Street is AWESOME. Their Burgers are to die for - I get mine with gruyere cheese, avocado, and grilled onions. I also really like the pork and shrimp wontons. They have great beer and the staff (bartenders, busers, wait staff, cooks, and owners) are all extremely friendly and wonderful. I would highly recommend this place!
author: Allison K.

description: Had a quality meal here last night, although it was a bit rushed.  They try to turn their tables as fast as possible since it's a smaller place, meaning that the wait staff can be somewhat in your face and a little pushy (in a nice way though).  ah, the economics of running a restaurant in a high-rent district of SF. No reservations, which means you may need to wait at the bar for a while.  Which is fine, because they make good cocktails (my Manhattan got me sufficiently loosened up for dinner).  We shared the calamari and the wontons as appetizers; both good but not exceptional.  Apparently Street has a reputation for making a great burger, so I felt compelled to order it... not the best burger I've ever had (the Martini House still retains that distinction), but very good nonetheless (it was, however, topped with some of the best bacon I've ever had.  just awesome).  I had a taste of their housemade Calabrese sausage over gnocci and it was great; I'll definitely try that the next time I eat here.  No room whatsoever for dessert, so I can't really comment... but it looked like there were some good options on the menu (i.e., Bread Pudding).
author: Andrew E.

description: My favorite restaraunt in the city.  We have loved everything we have ordered and go there often.  Great staff.  My usual: the big steak salad! Satisfied... yes, guilty... no.
author: Melissa L.

description: this is a *great* first date spot.  it's elegant and full of good looking people, which is definitely impressive.  moreover, it's romantic (and nicely lit) but bustling enough not to be excessively intimate.  most of all, it's really reasonably priced for the location/ambience!  the service was really friendly and efficient, the drinks were good (i got one big ass mojito!), and the food was quite good too (the cuisine wasn't all that creative but well made nonetheless).
author: Roshni R.

description: With so many bars and restaurants on Polk it is hard to have a standout on cocktails, but Street has it.  Friday night bartender is a real pro.  If you are tired of tacos and pizza at the end of the night, start with dinner at Street:  crab and sausage fettucine.
author: SF A.

description: Best handburger in town!!!  Can enjoy a nice evening sipping fun infused vodka and chilling in this polk street favorite
author: Amelia H.

description: I was pretty impressed with this place.  Needed a place to get an easy quick bite to eat with a friend in Russian Hill and I was sick of Rex's.  We walked in to discover that the place was actually kind of swanky looking, dimly lit., sort of like a place in NY.   I was afraid it wouldn't be quite so easy but actually it wasn't difficult to sit down nor was it overly expensive.  We were immediately seated and I was so pleased to discover (as always) that they had Prosecco by the glass.  Since I hadn't drank anything in 10 days (well almost) because of stupid antibiotics I was very excited to have the nectar of the gods only to discover they were out of Prosecco by the glass.  Since I wasn't at the point of drinking the bottle myself (have to ease back in ya know) the waitress suggested their Sparkling Pinot Grigio which ended up being quite tasty.  Ok, enough about the alcohol situation, they also had darn good food.  The hummus appetizer was really delicious as was the chocolate cake with vanilla ice cream.  The caesar salad looked amazing (tons of parmesan sprinkled on top like snow) but it actually wasn't all that tasty.  Nonetheless, I will definitely be back to try the fried chicken and hamburgers which looked very good (since I am rude and stare at other people's food).
author: Lindsay P.

description: A great neighborhood place that feels like much more. The food, wine and ambiance all just feel right, like that comfortable pair of shoes that you wear a little too often, but love too much to stop.
author: Saamra M.

description: Had a friend in from Pasadena on a architectural photography assignment to take shots of One Market Plaza.  Staying over at my Edwardian Flat on Nob Hill, guest suggested we go out to dinner for Italian or Chinese.  I countered with, "How about fried chicken at Street?"  Guest concurred and we ambled over a few blocks to "Street" a little before 6pm.  It was kind of empty and the attractive waitress very responsively took our order for the Sunday buttermilk marinated fried chicken with scratch mash,  gravy and corn off the cob.  $15 for all this seems about right and pretty much everyone who sauntered in was ordering it.  Since we were on a bit of an eat and run mission, we skipped all of the other amenities, well we did split the cornbread which adds a couple of bucks to the bill but all in all we were pretty much happy campers and I would recommend.  I say take the seats facing the door because the street action in kind of fascinating.  It gets a bit noisy if you want to carry on a deep conversation but then you should know that "Street" on Sunday night is not a place to carry on deep conversations.  It's a made from scratch fried chicken with light dinner patter place, like, okay?
author: Terry A.

description: This is by far the best restaurant on the strip of upper Polk.  Everything on the menu is great.  The steak salad is always a hit, the won tons are incredible as well as the house made sausage.  It's one fot he few places you can get a great set of crab cakes that are made mostly of crab (no cheap bread filling here).  Simple menu, the space is clean, unassuming yet with good style.  The owner and cook John and his wife run the place so you know that the owners are there every night, part of the reason I consistently have quality, tasty meals at a reasonable price.
author: Ashley K.

description: cute neighborhood place.  get there early, b/c it gets CROWDED.  i had the chicken w/ chilled garlic noodles and peanut-lime sauce, and the noodles were so good that all my friends were picking them off my plate.  i hear the burgers here are good.
author: Helen T.

description: i had a really lovely date night here recently. the owners work in the restaurant and are very sweet and caring toward their customers. they made some adjustments to my meal for me with the attitude of "no sweat!". their hummus is really as good as everyone says it is! our wine was great. all in all a delightful experience.
author: lisa w.

description: One of the best restaurants in the city - it is a great local spot with excellent food, service and atmosphere. Get there early (they don't take reservations) on a Tuesday night with a date and sit at the bar for dinner - you will be very happy!
author: Becky Z.

description: Very good, great neighborhood place. The food was great-had the shrimp/crab cakes-excellent. Always have dinner here at least once while we are in SFO.
author: audrey v.

description: My friend & I decided to head over to Polk since we're rarely over that way to check out the scene. We were walking down the street (ha!) and started reading the menu at this place. A passerby raved about this place & suggested we eat here, so we gave it a go. Good call, random dude.  They have an interesting drink list. My friend & I both had the cucumber-infused vodka martini--it's like an alcoholic version of spa water & you can't go wrong when they combine two of my favorite things. We weren't feeling too creative that night, so we each had the burger and split the large order of the Kennebuc fries--I have no idea what makes them "Kennebuc" since they pretty much tasted like most french fries.  It was very filling & the burger was worth forgoing my 'no red meat unless it's grass-fed' rule. Great atmosphere--the place was packed not too long after we got there. Service was good, non-descript, but nothing wrong with that in my book. I'll definitely be back; just want to try a few more food options before giving it 5 stars.
author: Kelley B.

description: One of the best dinner options on Polk Street.  The steak (strip or filet) and the risotto dishes are always crowd-pleasers.  The Buttermilk Panna Cotta is an excellent light dessert.  The Street is close to earning five stars, but I just feel like nearby Pesce is a slightly better dinner option.
author: Luke P.

description: i really like this place. it's a good location, and the inside is very cute.  quaint and candlelit.  the hamburger (with apple-smoked bacon and sharp white cheddar) is delicious!  definitely one of the best burgers in the city.  the service was really good as well - our waitress was cute and attentive.  the ahi wasn't the best though. it wasn't bad, but it wasn't quite as good as expected - a little too chewy for ahi.  the apple cake was pretty good, but not phenomenal.  the ahi and the apple cake are the only reason i didn't give five stars. they were good, but not five star worthy.  just get the burger, you'll like it. and the fries are tasty too.
author: Amanda M.

description: All you people who actually like this place obviously don't really know what good food is.  The place is a dump with HORRID service and overly salted boring food I've ever eaten.  BLAH!  Waste of time and money.
author: April H.

description:
i went here last time i was in san francisco. i think it's the old tablespoon - i could be wrong. i liked the place. i happen to be in sf when it was usually warm out and we sat near the windows overlooking polk street. it was nice. 

i wasn't too thrilled about the food. i ordered crab cakes and they were a little too fishy for me. i usually love crab cakes but something was a little off about this dish. i'm not convinced about this place. i most likely won't go here again with sooo many other great places in sf to check out.
author: Miss O.

description: My husband & I loved it! We started with drinks- he had the dark & stormy (homemade ginger ale), I had a martini with the lemon vodka & basil.  He had the buger (pepper jack, fire roasted onion & a side of fries - amazing fries),  I had the goat cheese, pear & arugula ravioli w/ pine nuts - very good!!  The spicy hummus appetizer was very good as well! No room for dessert - sorry we couldn't taste that.
author: Tricia I.

description: i almost fell in love with a girl here, but LD relationships don't work, so i realized that it was infatuation.  the food and service is good here too.
author: Pickle R.

description: Went to Street last night for my B-day with a party of 9. Got there early and had cocktails and wine at the bar. Their infused vodka drinks are AWESOME. Wine list seemed good. Tried a $35 bottle of Pinot, which was so-so. Our table was ready on time and we were seated. The ambiance is nice, but it is kind of dark, dinner by candle light kind of thing. For dinner we had the Hook and Ladder Cabernet, which was awesome. Calamari and Won-tons for appetizers, both were fine. Not amazing, not bad. I had the steak, my wife had the Gnocchi, sister had the Ahi Tuna, and the in-laws had the Crab cakes. My steak was good. I ordered it medium rare and it was. Not too tough, good quality meat. I usually prefer baked or mashed potatoes, but their Kennebec fries were pretty damn good. Tried the wife's Gnocchi with Sausage and red sauce. The dumplings were good, not the best I've ever had, but close. Didn't love the red sauce or the sausage. Tried the tuna, seemed a bit dry to me, but I prefer it seared and the Sis got it medium rare. Tried the crab cakes, AWESOME!! Super tasty, maybe a bit salty, but great overall. Moved on to dessert. I had the bread pudding with pecans and caramel sauce. Really good, probably the best bread pudding I have ever had (I haven't had much.) Everyone else seemed to like their desserts. Coffee was good. The service overall was pretty good. They had a hard time figuring out who ordered what, but it wasn't a huge deal. They brought out dishes two at a time, so a few of us had to wait to begin. But we had a party of 9, so I guess it wasn't too bad. All in all it was a good experience. There isn't much seating so definitely call ahead for reservations. For parties of two I would recommend just showing up and sitting at the bar, which looked kind of fun. The menu is a bit limited, mostly meat dishes, not much pasta, and is priced fairly. Expect to spend between $18 - $25 for an entree. Salads were $8, appetizers were $10+. For wine, appetizers, salads, entrees, and desert, we spent $46 per person, which included the tip. Definitely a fair price. So all and all, FOUR STARS. Definitely not a five star restaurant, but doesn't have a five star price.
author: David J.

description: I have no clue why this place has such a high review with so many reviewers.  We came here for bday celebration dinner and it was a pure let down.  I should have known that the reason why this place is so liked is becuase most people are reviewing about their burgers.  But come on, if you are paying $10+ for any burger, it better be good, its hard to fuck that up.  We tried their calamari and goat cheese custard appetizers.  Calamari was sincerely not good at all, not special and felt like they took prepackaged ones and fried it up.  Cheese custard was decent.
